12 M Lev 2 Inspect of HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carried out and that
(a) The General Section of the above job has been completed
and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring all cabling, connections and
installation meet the AS 3000 standard.
4. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each
Circuit Breaker and Isolator.  [_ _]
5. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations
including date of test, ground and weather conditions are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an
earthing resistance test in accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for
tightness of connections, and the condition of system
components e.g. Earthing electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
6. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance
and cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are
clean and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion.  Clean and tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal and battery voltage and
battery temperature prior to commencing the test as
well as at completion of test.  Where the battery or
terminal voltage at completion of test is less than
80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of it's serviceable life and
replacement options should be recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i)  Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for
damage etc.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Related Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
8. At Substations fill-in the log book.   [_ _]

3. Refer to Manual: Thytec 30KVA UPS 12 Pulse
[ M-MCL-ME20000/20011 ] Manual.
4. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
5. At By-pass Switch (Wall Mounted)
(a) Press the TRANSFER button, on the UPS control panel, to
transfer the UPS  to the by-pass mode.
(b) Wait until the amber By-Pass led is illuminated.
(c) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet<(>,<)>
to the OFF position, to isolate the batteries.
(d) Press the OFF button, on the UPS control panel,  to
switch OFF the UPS unit.
(e) Switch the EXTERNAL BY-PASS switch (wall mounted above
UPS) to the BY-PASS position.  The UPS unit is now
by-passed.
WARNING: DO NOT USE THE INTERNAL BY-PASS SWITCH, AS THIS
SWITCH IS NOT INTERLOCKED.
(f) Switch the EXTERNAL by-pass switch to the NORMAL
position.
(g) Press the ON button, on the UPS control panel.  An UPS
start is initiated.
(h) Wait for INV. ON green led to illuminate.
(i) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet<(>,<)>
to the ON position to connect the batteries to the UPS.
(j) After about 30 secconds the BYPASS led will go OFF and
the INVERTER led will illuminate, indicating the load is
on the inverter.  A noticeable change in the operating
noise of the UPS will also indicate the change of load.
6. UPS Unit.
(a) Do not operate the EMERGENCY STOP push button, on the
front of the UPS Panel, unless in extreme emergency, as
damage to the UPS electrical equipment can occur.
(b) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.
[_ _]
(c) Remove the air filter, clean and re-install, ( replace
air filter if necessary )   [_ _]
(d) Check for air flow above grills on top of the panel.
( with fan in operation )   [_ _]
(e) Visual Inspection of capacitors for any oil leaks.  [_ _]
(f) Switch OFF the ""MAIN UPS"" electrical supply.  The load
should then transfer to the UPS, supplying from the
batteries.
(g) Check and monitor, on the UPS display, the load current
(max. 42A per phase 30kVA UPS or max 55A per phase 40kVA
UPS).
(h) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
(i) Leave the UPS supply the load for at least ten minutes.
(j) Switch the Normal electricity supply isolator to the ON
position.  The load will revert to the Normal power
supply.
7. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
Batteries.
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on Panel
Door, is in the upright position and is not tripped.
[_ _]
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 270V. )    [_ _]
8. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the "" Work
Done "" area of the job sheet.
9.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
Works completed as above work plan

01 W Inspect & report of Egress tunnel features
Before you start the inspection, make sure that you are carrying the
camera, so that you can take any photographs of your observations.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this work.
2. Have the Traffic Control Room turn all lights on.
3. Enter the Burnley Tunnel Emergency Egress Tunnel (EET) at the Burnley
Stairwell and
carry out the following inspections over the entire length of the
EET.
4. Visually inspect the EXIT signs for operation (12 off).  Record on
the form ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 any  EXIT
sign that is not functioning correctly.
5. Visually inspect the stairwell and EET lighting for operation.
Record  on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
all instances of three (3) successive light fittings not functional.
6. Visually inspect all signage for cleanliness, damage and or damage
tofixings. Record
on the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly
Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 any signage requiring further attention.
7. Visually inspect walls, floors and roofs for ground water leaks.
Record on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
any leaks. Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage), LEAK TYPE
(Drip, Spray,
Running), POSITION (Roof, North wall, South wall, Floor).
8. Visually inspect floor for Trip Hazards e.g. raised grates,
accumulated debris, deposits of
leak sealant, water puddles etc.  Remove temporary hazards and
recordall occurrences
of hazards and their location on the form  ""Emergency  Egress Tunnel
Inspection Record  -
Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
9. Visually inspect
(a) and operate all emergency egress doors (e.g. Tunnel to EET - at
each cross passage
and
(b) doors within egress tunnel - for operation and or damage and
(c)  ensure all doors to equipment rooms are locked.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""  TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the
door location and a description of the repairs required.
10. Visually inspect all drainage and pits for evidence of blockage and
water over the floor.
Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage) TYPE (Pit, Drain, Pipe)
POSITION (North side, South side, Centre).  Record on the form
""Emergency Egress
Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
the location and
description of any blockage or flooding.
11. Visually inspect all EET and Stairwell fitments for damage,
corrosion, trip hazards,
obstructions (from walls or roofs) that are apparent.  Record on
the form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
and a description of the repairs and or obstruction.
12. Visually inspect for evidence of rodent infestation.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
of any sightings.
13. Remove all accumulated debris from the egress tunnel.
14. On completion have the Traffic Control Room switch all lights OFF.
15. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any abnormal
parameters found.
Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
16. Ensure the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  -
Weekly  Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 is returned to the CIVIL team leader or his
representative for
evaluation and recording of new leaks onto the Burnley Tunnel
Emergency Egress
Tunnel Leak Repair programme.  The Civil team leader is to ensure
any
outstanding works are scheduled.
17. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the work."

ASSET CONDITION RATING
Rate the Condition of the Asset.
Note:
[ 1 ] - Excellent.
Asset is new or in as new condition
[ 2 ] - Good.
Asset is fully operational, well presented, performing
it's intended function.
[ 3 ] - Fair.
Asset is functional and operational but showing signs of
deterioration that will result is some intervention
works possibly within the next 12 months. May not be
performing it's intended function to the full degree.
[ 4 ] - Poor.
Asset is functional and operational but showing major
signs of deterioration that will require intervention
works within the next 3 months. Not performing it's
intended function.
CONDITION RATING SCORE [_ _]
If the condition of asset is 3 or 4, record your observations
in the Work Done area of the job sheet(photograph if possible).

06 W Meas, report on BT V-Ntch  flow, GW & DW Pits, Bore Lvl
** Prior to commencement Maintenance Crew to be issued white
disposable overalls to be worn  whilst carrying out Tunnel
Drainage tasks.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 21, 22, 25, 26
3. Reference:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Operation & Maintenance Manual - Tunnel Drainage Stage 2
Design Report R-STG-EN-006 Rev 1.
4. Civil Team Leader or representative is to:
(a) Select groundwater and dirty water pits to be inspected
on forms BURNLEY TUNNEL GROUND WATER INSPECTIONS
TMF-3012-OP-0232 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTIONS
TMF-3012-OP-0253 respectively.  Selection should be with
the knowledge of past results and a random selection
including examination of previous inspections carried out
as part of the V Notch and Bay Flow inspections
(b) Previous inspection forms are to be issued to the
maintenance crew to compare results when carrying out
inspections.
(c) V-Notch Pits 14A, 66, 204 & 237 shall be inspected on
each occasion.
5. (a) Inspect the groundwater pits circled on BURNLEY TUNNEL
GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION""  TMF-3012-OP-0232.
(i) Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits
for cleanliness and the accumulation of calcites.
(ii) Record the build up of calcites in the pipes and pits
in Millimetres (mm).  When a build up of 50mm occurs
in a 200mm pipe or a 25mm in a 100mm pipe.  Cleaning
is required.
(iii) Record a description of the calcite. e.g. slimy,
milky or hard etc.
(iv) Record the results on form BURNLEY TUNNEL GROUNDWATER
PIT INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0232.
(b) Inspect the Dirtywater pits circled on BURNLEY TUNNEL
DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0253. Use a torch
to inspect each pipe and associated pits for cleanliness
and the accumulation of debris.  Record the related
details regarding accumulation of silts, debris, and
other foreign materials within pits on the form.
(c) Ensure pit covers are replaced and seated correctly after
each pit inspection.
6. V-Notch Readings
(a) Prior to taking readings of dirty water (Right hand side
of tunnel) pit numbers 14A & 66 and Ground water (Left
hand side of tunnel) pit numbers 204 & 237, ensure the
V-notch  weir is clear of calcites and debris.  Clean
thoroughly if required.
(b) Use a measuring stick obtain the depth of the V-notch
flow by
(i) Place the stick in the cup
(ii) Remove the stick and measure the height of the water
mark on the stick.
(c) Record the depth of water flowing over the V-Notch weir
in mm on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT
FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & RATE OF RISE
TMF-3012-OP-0234.
(d) If readings differ markedly from previous readings, then
take measurement again to confirm results.
(e) Note that inspection V-Notch pits is to be carried out
as per step 5.
7. Swan Street Groundwater Pit Inflow Readings
(a) Once V-Notch 221has been read, then proceed to the Swan
Street Pumping Station to take the rate of inflow
reading.
(b) Proceed to the Pump Control centre
(c) Notify the TCR that all pumps are to be switched OFF.
(d) Switch OFF all pumps (Have an electrician perform this
duty).
(e) Return back to the sump pumping room and close all three
gate valves.
(f) Return to the pump control centre and start by recording
the sump level, then 10 minutes later take another
reading of the sump level.
(g) Record the sump start and finish level, in millimetres,
on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS,
GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & RATE OF RISE TMF-3012-OP-0234.
(h) Record on the inspection sheet any thing out of the
ordinary.
(i) Return all gate valves to their normal OPEN condition and
switch the pumps back to automatic operation. Then
proceed with the rest of the readings and inspections.
8. Burnley Tunnel Groundwater Bore Level  (located between fire
cabinets B45 & B46 RHS).
(a) Remove the BT bore-hole cover, then lower a string with a
weight attached into the bore-hole until the weight
touches the bottom of the bore-hole.
(b) Mark the string with a marker or pen, ensuring that the
weight is just touching the bottom and that there is no
undue slack in the string.
(c) Measure and record the total length of the string (Total
depth of bore-hole in millimetres)
(d) Measure and record the total length of the string that
was submerged in the bore-hole water (Depth of
groundwater in bore-hole in millimetres).
(e) Record the details on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE -
SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & RATE OF RISE
TMF-3012-OP-0234.
(f ) Ensure the cover is replaced and seated correctly.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
10. Ensure a completed copy of the forms BURNLEY TUNNEL
GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0232, BURNLEY
TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTIONS  TMF-3012-OP-0253 and
BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE
LEVELS & RATE OF RISE TMF-3012-OP-0234 are forwarded to the
Civil Team Leader or representative on completion of the job
and prior to end of shift.  Civil Team Leader or
representative is to record and sign off each form and raise
any actions (job sheets) for further inspection or cleaning
Increases in the flows measured in groundwater pits 204 &
237 should be followed up with a piezometer measurement for
the Burnley Tunnel.

03 M Inspect & Clean TSH Equipment and Bldgs
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the
cleaning and inspections of the Building and Electrics<(>,<)>
prior to leaving the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum
Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and
external lighting, Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material<(>,<)>
Ladders, Silicon Lubricant Spray, Rodent Bait Station
This job should be carried in conjunction with the Monthly
job at the Technical Shelters
A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the
electrical installations of Technical Shelters, as well the
cleaning, inspections and maintenance of the relevant
areas.
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( Technical Shelters TSH1-6, TSH10-14 )
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the relevant Technical
shelters.
2. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere<(>,<)>
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events.  [_ _]
3. At Technical shelters, fill-in the log-book [_ _]
4. Check the interior and external lighting for operation<(>,<)>
including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace
faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of
ambient plus 10°C should be considered abnormal and must be
noted in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of
the abnormality. Raise a new job sheet for any corrective
action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all
cables, terminals, equipment and components  for evidence
of burn marks, unusual odours and overheating.  Record
anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job
Sheet and raise a new jobsheet for any corrective action.
Ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of
the abnormality.  [_ _]

03 M inspect of Liebert A/C units accessed via the tunnel
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Set up the traffic control measures as per Work Instruction,
Traffic Control, MI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 20
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at  Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
shown on unit  is consistent with new setpoint and
verify temperature is consistent with ambient
(+ or - 1 deg) using portable  thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when the new
setpoint is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm..   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. - Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347.  Ensure the form Equipment Room
Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347 is returned to the Electrical
Electronics Supervisor or his representative.  Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Supervisor or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9.0. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Check of Vent Station Smoke Damper Actuators
These checks are carried out to verify the operability of the
Ventilation Station smoke duct damper actuators for each
Ventilation Station.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. In conjunction with Traffic Control Room Operators set TCR
PMCS system smoke damper actuator controls for manual
operation
3. Open a minimum of 4 smoke duct dampers upstream of the
ventilation station to prevent negative pressure being
generated in the smoke duct, from the normal ventilation
system, when smoke dampers are opened.
4. Open and close each damper at least  twice and observe the
panel for indications of non- standard operation such as
dampers that open or close sluggishly, or fail to open or
close completely.
5. Close the Ventilation station smoke duct dampers.
6. Close tunnel smoke duct dampers.
7. Record in Work Done area of the Job Sheet those dampers that
have suspect operation.
8. Notify the control room om completion of the job.

03 M Inspection of substation 5 air handling unit
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Refer to reference manual, Operating and Maintenance Manual
for Mechanical Services at Melbourne Citylink Tunnels
M-STG-ME-27400.
3. Work plan for SF-SS5-1.
(a) Access the fan from from ERW 00, above Olympic Park portal
(b) Switch the fan OFF using the circuit breaker in cabinet
(SUB 5 A/C 5B MEB).   [_ _]
(c) Open the fan enclosure door, ensuring it is safely secured
in the open position.
WARNING:  IF THE FAN IS RUNNING THE DOOR IS OPENED UNDER
NEGATIVE PRESSURE.  USE THE HANDLES PROVIDED TO PULL THE DOOR
OPEN.  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY BETWEEN THE DOOR AND
THE DOOR FRAME.
(d) WHEN REPLACING THE FILTERS ROAD TRANSPORTS PASS CLOSE BY
OUTSIDE.
It is advised to use full face protection.
Replace the filters.   [_ _]
(e) Check that the inlet mesh is clear of debris and not
damaged.   [_ _]
(f) Using a torch and a mirror, through the inlet cone,
inspect the fan and the attenuator for damage or
blockages.   [_ _]
(g) Switch the fan ON using the circuit breaker in cabinet
(SUB 5 A/C 5B MEB).   [_ _]
(h) Check the fan for unusual noises or any vibration while it
is running.   [_ _]
(i) Check the fan motor bearings and lubricate if
required.   [_ _]
(j) Switch the fan OFF using the circuit breaker in cabinet
(SUB 5 A/C 5B MEB).   [_ _]
(k) Close and latch the fan chamber door.
(l) Switch the fan ON using the circuit breaker in cabinet
(SUB 5 A/C 5B MEB).   [_ _]
WARNING: THE DOOR WILL CLOSE WITH GREAT FORCE UNDER HIGH
SUCTION PRESSURE IF THE FAN IS OPERATING.  TAKE CARE NOT TO
HAVE ANY PORTION OF THE BODY BETWEEN THE DOOR AND THE DOOR
FRAME WHEN CLOSING THE DOOR.
4. Check that the outlet grills in lower substation 5A and 5B
are clear
5. Work plan for EF-SS5-1.
(a) Switch the fan OFF using the circuit breaker in cabinet
SUB 5 A/C 5A MEB.   [_ _]
(b) Check that the exhaust grilles in each UPS room are clear
of debris and not damaged.   [_ _]
(c) Check the air supply grilles in each room are clear of
debris and are not damaged.   [_ _]
(d) Switch the fan ON using the circuit breaker in cabinet
SUB 5 A/C 5A MEB.   [_ _]
(e) Check the fan for unusual noises or any vibration while
it is running.   [_ _]
(f) Check the fan motor bearings and lubricate if
required.  [_ _]
6. Repeat step 5 for EF-SS5-2.   [_ _]
7. (a) Using a torch, in the UPS rooms, check the fire dampers
(2 in each UPS rm) in each inlet and exhaust grill for
damage or premature operation.  [_ _]
(b) Using a torch, in the substations 5A & B, check the fire
dampers (1 in each substation) in the supply air inlet
and the exhaust grill for damage or premature
operation.  [_ _]
8   (i) Sweep and clean the Substation room(s) and associated
switchrooms as well as the  Emergency Egress Stairway :
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
(ii) Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces
that will collect dust deposits.   [___]
(iii) Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
(iv) Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
(v) Note and record any evidence of water or drainage
problems.  Clear any blockages.
(vi) Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
9. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Substation rooms and
equipment etc, in the Work Done section of the job sheet
and report to the Team Leader or his representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
10. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
11. Prior to leaving the substation notify the traffic control
room operators.  [_ _]

Rate the Condition of the Asset.
Note:
[ 1 ] - Excellent.
Asset is new or in as new condition
[ 2 ] - Good.
Asset is fully operational, well presented, performing
it's intended function.
[ 3 ] - Fair.
Asset is functional and operational but showing signs of
deterioration that will result is some intervention
works possibly within the next 12 months. May not be
performing it's intended function to the full degree.
[ 4 ] - Poor.
Asset is functional and operational but showing major
signs of deterioration that will require intervention
works within the next 3 months. Not performing it's
intended function.
CONDITION RATING SCORE [_ _]
If the condition of asset is 3 or 4, record your observations
in the Work Done area of the job sheet(photograph if possible).

01 W Inspection of  WL2 Toll gantry Blue Lighting
Make sufficient copies of form:
TMF-3012-OP-0381 Three arm blue light inspection sheet
1. Inspect the Blue lights installed at each toll point for
operation, as listed below for lamps that have failed.

3N North Bound (Dudley St.  - 3B)   [_ _]
2N North Bound (Macaulay Rd - 2B)   [_ _]
2S South Bound (Macaulay Rd - 2A)   [_ _]
3S South Bound (Dudley St - 3A)   [_ _]
2. As a minimum, personnel are to wear safety vest and use
vehicles equipped with rotating vehicle hazard light.
Vehicle hazard light must be operating when travelling in the

emergency lane to carry out further inspections.

representative.

representative shall schedule the replacement of lamps and or

01 M Check of  Burnley Vent Station Primary Axial Fans
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Works to carried out at non-peak times.
2. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3, the
ventilation rooms and to interrupt operations.
3. Inform the control room prior to commencing the work and
brief TCRO's on interruptions and expected alarms.  Maintain
radio contact at all times.
4. Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual (M-STG-VE-26058)
5. At the PMCS in the control room.
(a) Check the motor balance vibration readings on the PMCS
for all fans.  If any reading is in excess of 6.5mm/s<(>,<)>
record the result in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet for further action.   [_ _]
(b) Check the trend log for the last month, looking for
abnormal events.   Any events and or trends that are
abnormal are to be recorded in the work done area of the
Jobsheets and a new job sheet raised to investigate and
correct the abnormality.  [_ _]
(c) Check the running current and record in the "Work Done"
area if greater than Primary fans FLC 349A    Secondary
fans FLC 310A.
(d) Check the drive and non drive end bearing temperatures
for the operating fan motor.  Record the details for
those bearings with a temperature greater then 80°C in
the "Work Done" area of the job sheet for further
action   [_ _]
(e) Record Hours run in Work Done.  [_ _]
6. Access to the  Burnley ventilation station is through the
locked airlock on stairway adjacent to the south west corner
of the Burnley vent stack.  Access to substation 3 is via
external doors adjacent to the Burnley Portal.
WARNING:
DO NOT CARRY OUT THESE CHECK WHENEVER MORE THAN 2 FANS ARE
OPERATIONAL
DO NOT ENTER THE ACCESS AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM
ALONE.  TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT WHENEVER WORK IS
BEING CARRIED OUT IN THIS AREA.  OBSERVE ALL NOTICES ON THE
AIRLOCK DOORS.
7. In substation 3;
(a) Switch the Main Isolator for EFE 01 OFF.  (NOTE:- The
order of fan selection is dependant on fan requirements.
A minimum of one fan must be running at any time).  Open
the starter cubicle & inspect the cubicle & wiring
connections.  Upon completion close the door, and return
the Main Isolator to the ON position.  [_ _]
(b) Switch the Main Isolators for all the other non
operational axial fans, one at a time EFE 02 thru to
EFE10 to the OFF position, then inspect the starter
cubicles.  Once the inspections are complete, ensure the
cabinet doors are closed and the isolators are returned
to the ON positions.  [_ _]
8.1 Fan Room Access
(a)  Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after
equalizing differential pressure in the airlock.
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1 METRE OF
AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD, AS THE AIR IS FLOWING AT APPROX
35kmh .
8.2 Static Checks
(a) Press the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton adjacent to the
motor.
(b) Check the condition of anti-vibration mountings and
ensure that the rubber bushing is moved freely, adjust if
required.  [_ _]
(c) Examine the grease that has been discharged from the
motor bearings for any noticeable colour changes.  [_ _]
(d) Open the local electrical junction box, inspect the
electrical wiring and connections, inspect all glands for
tightness.  [_ _]
(e) Visually inspect the motor for evidence of condensation<(>,<)>
white powder or similar.  Record in the "Work Done" area
of the Job Sheet any evidence of condensation, powder and
the like and notify the Team Leader or his
representative.  [_ _]
(f) Carry out the following insulation/resistance test of the
motor and heater windings.
(i)  Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has
been isolated and is to remain isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motor windings and the winding heater bridge.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out an Insulation resistance
test between this common bridge and earth.  Record
the result in the "Work Done" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) If the heater was connected on arrival, then
re-instate the heater connections, otherwise leave the
motor winding heater terminations isolated.
(vii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(viii) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than
2 megohm, then Record in the "Work Done"area of the
Job Sheet and raise a new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
"Related Job" field as well as in the alternate.
Notify the Team Leader or his representative of any
outstanding works.
8.3  Running Checks.
(a) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton and contact the TCR
to start the fan.  [_ _]
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(c) Check the fan for any abnormal noise or vibrations.  _ _]
(d) Check the flexible connections for wear and leakage of
air.  [_ _]
(e) Check anti-vibration mountings for operation and
structural soundness [_ _]
(f ) Check the operation of the local vibration
monitor.   [_ _]
(g) Record any abnormalities in the "Work Done" area of the
Job Sheet for further action.  [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the Local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
8.4 Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) On completion of  the Static Fan Checks, return to
substation 3, then remove the safety tags, in accordance
with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then remove the fan motor
isolation at the MCC.
Note: Ensure that only one non-operational fan is
isolated at any one time.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF
position to the MANUAL and the  REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switch from the REMOTE position to the LOCAL
position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room; there start the fan<(>,<)>
that is being maintained, by releasing the local STOP
pushbutton at the fan and then pressing START
pushbutton.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(e) Add Shell Stamina RL2 grease or equivalent, to the
bearings, only while the fan is running.  Ten pumps per
bearing.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the
bearings, using the retrieval system.  Examine the
grease for changes of colour.   [_ _]
(g) Check the fan for any abnormal noises or
vibrations.     [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
9. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 02.  [_ _]
10. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 03.  [_ _]
11. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 04.  [_ _]
12. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 05.  [_ _]
13. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 06.  [_ _]
14. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 07.  [_ _]
15. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 08.  [_ _]
16. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 09.  [_ _]
17. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 10.  [_ _]
18. (a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are
disengaged.  [_ _]
(b) Collect all tools and materials, leave the fan room<(>,<)>
again equalise the corridor and the fan room pressures.
19. (a) Check the lighting within the fan chamber for
operation.  [_ _]
(b) Repair any light found to be not operating or raise a
new jobsheet for the repair of the fan chamber lighting.
20. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done'
section of the Job Sheet.
21. Notify the control room on completion of work.
22. Return to the control room and ensure all fans are
operational.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident has
occurred requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
Note:  Depending on the position of an event, Substation 1 may be
inaccessible.
1. If Substation 3 is not accessible
(a). If a fan that is being checked is running,  advise the
traffic control room that the fan  is running under
LOCAL control. Unless advice is received, from the
control room,  that fan should remain under LOCAL
control.
(b). Vacate the ventilation fan chamber, ensuring the sliding
door to the airlock is closed and sealed.
(c). Advise the traffic control room when all personnel are
in or have left the air lock.
2. Substation 3 is accessible
(a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are disengaged
(b) Return to substation 3 and switch all the fan
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switches to the REMOTE position
and switch all the fan  AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switches to
the AUTO position.
(c) Notify the traffic control room operators that they have
control of the fans.

03 M Inspect Clean Emergency stairways thru'out the project
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Stairway and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for
fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting, Brooms,
Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders, Silicon Lubricant Spray,
Rodent bait station, Cold Gal.
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
installations and cleaning of the stairway areas.
A  INTRODUCTION
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. This Job is for the inspection and clean of the emergency
stairways e.g. External and Internal stairway to YC Pump Stn,
External Stairway to SUB 04, External Stairway to
SUB 05.   [_ _]
3. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere,
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events.  [_ _]
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace or
repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
2. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit
lighting) and lens of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
3. Check and clean cable trays for accumulated debris.  Record
anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the job sheet and
inform the Team Leader or his representative of outstanding
actions.  [_ _]
C  Stairway Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture
ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record any
details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check that the relevant stairway(s) are not obstructed by
furnishings and or stored items.  Remove any
obstruction.  [_ _]
3. Check the doors for damage and operation, lubricate and
repair as required and record in the Work Done area of the
Job Sheet.  Inform the Team Leader or his representative
of any outstanding works.  [_ _]
4. Clean dust and remove cobwebs from interior walls and
ceilings.  [_ _]
5. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris,
including accumulated leaves and debris at top of
stairways.  [_ _]
6. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces and stairs.  [_ _]
7. Clean hand rails (if applicable) of dust and dirt.  [_ _]
9. Visually inspect all metalwork for damage or corrosion.
Repair and or remove corrosion and clean then cover with
Cold Gal.  [_ _]
10. Carry out Exterior Checks of relevant area(s) (where
applicable).
(a) Visually inspect the exterior surfaces of the building
(if applicable) for damage, erosion,  graffiti,
corrosion.  [_ _]
(b) Visually inspect the building (if applicable) walls,
roof, guttering and and downpipes for damage, leaks and
or blockages, remove any debris or materials that could
cause a blockage.  [_ _]
(c) Inspect (if applicable) the general area surrounding the
building for erosion and damage to surfaces, fences,
gates, pavements   [_ _]
11. Remove any accumulated debris from the building surrounds
(where appropriate).  [_ _]
12. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service
e.g. Fans, Air Conditioners.  [_ _]
(b) All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
13. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to departing.

03 M Inspection of Smoke Exhaust Fans Olympic Park
WARNING:
ELECTRIC MOTORS CAN OPERATE AT A TEMPERATURE WHICH MAY CAUSE BURNS.
EXERCISE CAUTION WHEN ABOUT TO TOUCH MACHINERY WHICH MAY BE HOT.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to ventilation rooms and to
interrupt operations.
2. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
3. Reference manual, Fantech Pty Ltd. Olympic Park Portal Centrifugal
Fans.  Operations and
Maintenance Manual. M-STG-VE-26200.
4. Check the fan outlet stacks and the protective mesh for accumulated
debris that may restrict
outlet damper operation.  Use an extension ladder.  (3m. wall)  in
accordance with work    instruction TM1-3012-SA-0121 Ladders- Safe use
to remove any debris.  [_ _]
3. Fan Operation
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
CAUTION:  DO NOT RUN MORE THAN 2 FANS AT ANY TIME.
Request the control room to open at least four tunnel smoke inlet
dampers.
CAUTION:  A MINIMUM OF 4 INLET DAMPERS MUST BE OPEN BEFORE
OPERATING
THE  FANS.
(a) Switch the fan AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position and start
the fan using the START/STOP/RESET pushbutton.  Run the fan
for 30 minutes.
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens fully.  [_ _]
The following checks shall be made using touch, sight and hearing.
Perceived problems
will be further investigated using instrumentation.
(a) Check the fan bearings for uneven rumbling or hammering noise.
[_ _]
(b) Check the fan bearings for overheating by using hand held
infrared temperature sensor.              [_ _]
(c) Check the fans for excessive vibration (surging or beating
sound) shuddering on start
up or run down.   [_ _]
(d) Check the safety guards and other safety features for safe
operating condition.  [_ _]
(e) Check the flexible connection of ducting, for leaks, tearing
andfraying.  [_ _]
(f ) Check the drive belts for condition.   [_ _]
4. Motor Operation
(a) Check the motor bearings for noisy running and excessive
vibration.  [_ _]
(b) Check the motor and the bearings for excessive heating.   [_ _]
(c) Check that external ventilation airways are clear. [_ _]
5. On completion of all checks switch the fan OFF using the
START/STOP/RESET pushbutton.
Check that the outlet damper closes fully on shutdown.   [_ _]
6. Record ""Hours Run""  for fan in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job
Sheet.
7. Request the control room to close the inlet smoke dampers.  [_ _]
8. Ensure the fan AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switches are set to the AUTO
position.  [_ _]
9. Ensure the fan station is clean and remove all accumulated debris andrubbish.
[_ _]
10. Record anything outside normal parameters, in the ""Work Done""
areaof the job
sheet.  [_ _]
11. On the completion of the job notify the control room.  [_ _]
12. On completion of the job, the ""Hours Run"" detail, for each fan is
to be entered into the
hours run table in Plant Item.  Select the Plant Item,  then right
mouse click, select
""Open"" and then select  ""Meter Readings"".  Select edit mode and
enter reading.
Record Readings Below
Hours Run  [         ]
Bearing Temp.    [         ] deg. C.
"

01 M Inspection & test running of the WL TSH generators
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode.   [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. Refer to reference manual Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
5.   (a) Check that the generator was left in  "AUTO" [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuel and water.   [_ _]
(c) Check oil level.   [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates.  [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ).   [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts   [_ _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the "Work Done" area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap, as the gauge could be
misleading.  [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry.  [_ _]
6. Reference manual, Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP
Electrical Pty Ltd Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI
[M-MCL-ME-20016]
7.  (a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch on the generator
DC panel to "" RUN "" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch
back to "" AUTO ""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from "" AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST
"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature.   [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to " AUTOMATIC CONTROL" the generator will continue to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping.   [_ _]
(g) Record the hours run, from the hours run meter,  in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet.
8.  (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises.  [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages  [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet.  [_ _]
9. Fill in the Generator Log Book and record anything outside
normal parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet.  Raise a new job for any works requiring further
repairs.  Priority High P1.
10.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
11.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
12.Record the Hours run in Mainpac under "Plant" use RH mouse
click then select "Open"      then select "Meter
Readings" in edit mode add the Meter Reading for the
appropriate TSH Generator.

03 M Inspect, Test & Clean Burnley Pump Station
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths,
lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting,
Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders, Silicon
Lubricant Spray, Rodent Bait Station
A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the pumps, Pump
station, Pump Station electrical installation as well the
cleaning, inspections and maintenance of the related controls.
B PUMPS AND PUMP STATION OPERATION
1. Notify control room before entry.
2. Access to wet well and valve pit is via gatic covers in the
pathway on south side of Burnley Portal.
WARNING:  THE WET WELL AND VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED CONFINED
SPACES AND MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED SPACE
CONDITIONS.
3. Inspect Local Control Panel
(a) Check  switchboard, situated in Sub-station 3,  for
local alarm conditions.
(b) Carry out visual internal and external inspection of the
control panel for damage, evidence of insect infestation,
ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as required)
(c) Check cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect electrical control
equipment.   [_ _]
(d) Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet the hours
run from the meter on the switchboard.     [_ _]
4. Inspection of pump wet well and valve pit.
(a) Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the
valve pit, inspect both the wet well and the valve pit
for general cleanliness and debris.  Clean if
required.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of  the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks.  [_ _]
5. Check the operation of pump PSBLYP1 (A1 Starter) by switching
the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position and starting the pump by pressing the
START/STOP/RESET button.
(a) Measure the operating current and compare with the rated
current. (FLC 22A.).  Record in the Work Done area of the
job sheet if results are outside normal limits.   [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running or
vibration and abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it
is clear from possible damage.   [_ _]
CAUTION:  Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low
level alarm point as lack of submergence may cause
pumpset damage
6. Check non-return valve operation on shutting off pump by
pressing START/ STOP/RESET button.  Full valve closure will
be indicated by;
(a) closing with an audible sharp metallic sound.
(b) backflow through pump should cease within 30 seconds
Valve closing with a duller sound or excessive backflow
(longer than 30 seconds) occuring may indicate debris
jammed in valve preventing full closure.  Pump should be
re-started,  run for 2 minutes and non-return valve
operation check repeated.
If faulty closure is still suspected, report for
corrective maintenance.  [_ _]
Return AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to AUTO
position.  [_ _]
7. Repeat steps 5 and 6 for pump PSBLYP2 (B1 Starter). [_ _]
8. Check operation of float switches, manually tripping floats
from ground level by lifting up High/High float and Low/Low
floats respectively  and checking alarms are received at O&M
Control Room.  [_ _]
9. (a) Check operation of level controller by pumping until pump
stops. Compare actual level with capacity meter on
switchboard.   Wet well pump stop level is 4.6 m. below
top deck which equals 31% capacity.   [_ _]
(b)  Lift level controller sensor out of conduit and
carefully and gently clean recess in base.
10. Test operation of isolating valves by partial opening and
closing only.    [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Pump stations and
equipment etc,
in the Work Done section of the job sheet and report to
the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done area
of the job sheet.   [_ _]
13. Notify control room that inspection is completed.
C  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. On entering pump station, temporarily switch OFF ventilation
fans, if operating.   [_ _]
2. On accessing the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere,
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events.  [_ _]
3. Check the interior lighting for operation, replace faulty
lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
4. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within control panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient
plus 10°C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the abnormality.
Raise a new job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
5. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and components  for evidence of burn
marks, unusual odours and overheating.  Record anything
abnormal in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new jobsheet for any corrective action.  Ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc.  [_ _]
7. Visually inspect the enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions.  [_ _]
8. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
9. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for
dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures of any
accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
10. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.
Clean or replace filters as required.  [_ _]
11. Inspect systems, mounted within the control panel(s), for
faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions.   [_ _]
12. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged
in the work done area of the job sheet and a new job
sheet raised to investigate and correct the
error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris.  [_ _]
13. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.
14. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader
or his representative of any corrective actions.  [_ _]
D. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel interior for evidence of moisture
ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record any
details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check that the control panel is not obstructed by furnishings
and or stored items.  Remove any obstruction.  [_ _]
3. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets,
ledges, cable trays, cables, etc.   Note: Dust will settle on
all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets, tops of
cabinet doors, tops of meter escutcheons etc.  [_ _].
4. Clean all exterior surfaces of cabinets using approved
cleaning materials .  [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from cabinets, light fittings, cable
trays.  [_ _]
6. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris.  [_ _]
7. Sweep and vacuum the floor surface at the control
panel.  [_ _]
8. Visually inspect rodent bait station for bait.  Replace bait
station if bait is near exhausted.  [_ _]
9. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of the
job sheet.  Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions.  [_ _]
10. Remove any accumulated debris from the building
surrounds.  [_ _]
11. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service
e.g. Fans, Air Conditioners.  [_ _]
(b) All Enclosures are closed and locked.  [_ _]
(c) All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
12. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader
or his representative of any corrective actions.  [_ _]
13. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to departing.

12 M Routine Maint. of Swan St  Vent Station Fans
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
WARNING:
1.    CHECKS SHOULD NOT BE CARRIED OUT IF MORE THAN 1 FAN IS OPERATING
IN THE
SWAN ST SHAFT VENT STATION.
2.    NO PERSON SHALL ENTER THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM ALONE.
TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT AT ALL TIMES WHEN WORK IS BEING
CARRIED OUT IN ANY CHAMBER OF THE VENT STATION
3.    TAKE HEED OF NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS.
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 2,  the Swan Street
ventilation rooms and to
interrupt operations.
2.  Inform the control room prior to commencing work.   Maintain radio
contact at all times.
3.  Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
(M-STG-VE-26058)
4. Carry out the monthly checks on the PMCS in the Traffic Control Room.
5. Access to the ventilation fan is via ladders in the Swan Street Shaftlift
well and Substation 2
is accessed from Swan Street.
6.(a) On the MCC in Substation No 2,  select ONE axial fan to be
operational while
the maintenance is being carried out  on other fans.  Switch
the nominated
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the MANUAL position and the
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switch to the REMOTE postion, then press the START
pushbutton.
(b) Switch ALL non-operational axial fans OFF, by switching the
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector
switches to the OFF position.  All electrical isolation
procedures are to be in
accordance to Work Instruction TMI -3012-SA -0103,  Low
VoltageIsolation Procedures.
7. In Substation No 2
(a) Measure the insulation resistance of the motor stator windings
and record in the ""Work
Done"" section of the Job Sheet.   [_ _]
(b) Measure the current of the anti-condensation heater and compare
with the rated current.
(c) Inspect the motor control panel both internally and externally
for damage, corrosion,
evidence of overheating,  ingress of moisture, dust and grime
(clean or repair if required).
8. (a) The fan rooms which are on levels 4, 5 & 6 are accessed from the
Note: HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN IN ANY
VENTILATION
FAN CHAMBER.
(b) Measure the CO levels in the fan rooms, through the doorway,
prior to entering the fan
room, then at regular intervals during the fan checks.
(c)  WARNING:  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN
1 METRE OF AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD.
Airflow velocity nears 35 km/h.
9. Static Fan Check.
(a) Ensure that the fan selected for maintenance is electrically
isolated,  press the START
pushbutton on the local push button station at Level 5.  The
fan should not start.
(b) On level 5 open fan blade inspection hatch.
(c) Examine the impeller for
(i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
[_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips   [_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges   [_ _]
(iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub   [_ _]
(d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage dueto
fraying, scuffing or
similar and for damage at locations where the cables
penetratepanels or
housings.    [_ _]
(e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
excessive.   [_ _]
(f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticable colour change.
Ensure that the grease
nipples are clean.  [_ _]
(g)  Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
(h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motorwindings and the
winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
each phase winding and earth.  Record results in the Work
Done area of the
Job sheet.
(vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(x)  Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
""Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
(i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately.  [_ _]
(j)  Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.
(k ) Remove any mechanical interlocks blocking the fan operation.
[_ _]
10. Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation
3and remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then removethe
fan motor isolation
at the MCC.
Note:  Ensure that all non-operational fans are isolated, in
accordance
TMI-3012-SA-0103, and that the only fan not
isolated, is the fan to be maintained.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the MANUAL
position, then switch the REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch
from the REMOTE
position to the LOCAL position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room and start the fan, that is
beingmaintained, by releasing
the Local STOP pushbutton, then pressing the START
pushbutton.
Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
(e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr  Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or
equivalent only.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the bearings
using the retrieval
system.  Examine the grease for changes of colour.  [_ _]
(g) Monitor the fan and motor for abnormal noises.      [_ _]
(h) Stop the fan motor using Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
11. On completion, collect all materials and leave the fan room after
equalizing the
differential pressures.
12. In Substation No 2
(a) Remove all safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103,
then remove the
motor isolation for all the fans at the MCC.  Return all
theREMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switches to the REMOTE position,  and the
AUTO/OFF/MAN  fan selector
switches to the AUTO position.
(b) Check that one fan is operational and no alarms are present
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done' sectionof
the Job Sheet.
14. Notify the control room on the completion of the job.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident
hasoccured requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
1. Immediately leave the fan chambers on Level 4 and Level 6 and ensure
the doors to the lift
shaft are secured.
2. Notify TCR Operator when Level 4 and level 6 have been evacuated so
that smoke
extraction can commence.
3. If  the fan being checked is running, advise TCR that it is
currentlyrunning under LOCAL
control and will be returned to AUTO control.  Stop  the fan using
the Emergency STOP
pushbutton on Level 5.
4. Release the STOP pushbutton and leave Level 5 ensuring that the door
to the lift shaft is
secured
5. If the fan is isolated or not running, vacate all fan chambers
immediately and secure doors.
6. Notify TCR when all personnel have left the fan chambers, the doors
secured and all the
personnel are accounted for and in the lift shaft.
7. Only if a fan was running and operational - In Substation 2  switch
the
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to the REMOTE position, as well
switch the
AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the AUTO position.
8. Stop the operational fan then return the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector
switchto the AUTO
position and restart the fan.
9. Notify TCR Operators that they have control.

01 W Mon, m'sure & report  YC pump stn flows"
The measure of  water flowing from the Yarra Crossing pump
station is a measure of all the water collected in the Domain
tunnel drainage systems, from both dirty and clean water
sources.
Note: NEW CHANGES TO ITEM 4
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. For detail of Job, refer to Work Instruction, DOMAIN TUNNEL
DRAINAGE TMI-3012-OP-0025.
3. The Civil Team Leader is to provide a copy of the previous
DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOW TMF-3012-OP-0203 for details of
the previous readings.
4. Record the Time and the Total Flow at Magflow 1 (in K.litres)
and the Total Flow at Magflow 2 (in m3) for the pump station,
on form  DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS TMF-3012-OP-0203.
5. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
6. Ensure a copy of the form  DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS
TMF-3012-OP-0203 is forwarded to the Civil Team Leader for
evaluation on completion of the job.
Note:  An increase or decrease in the pump station outflows
in excess of 0.5 litres/s could indicate a problem.  Raise a
job to investigate to check the various bay flows for
the reason to the change in water flowrate.
"

03 M SL Gate inspections
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this Job.
2. Inspect and check access gates as set out on the form
TMF-3012-OP-0308  SL Gate Inspection.
3. At each gate:
(a) Check the gate for damage
(b) Unlock the gate and check for operation
(b) Check the gate hinges for fixings and operation
(c) Check the gate locking method for security and correct
lock.
(d) Check the area for accumulated debris and graffiti.
(e) Visually check the pavement (where fitted) for damage
(f)  Using a Graphite dust puffer, apply Graphite dust to
key entry and to shackle entries, then exercise lock
and key to distribute Graphite dust.
(g)  Replace missing or damaged locks as required.  Lock to
be issued by Translink Operations Traffic Control room
4.  For each gate, record the result of the inspections on the
form SL Gate Inspection - TMF-3012-OP-0308.
5. Notify control room when inspection is complete.
6. Ensure the completed job sheets and the form  SL Gate and
Fence Inspection - TMF-3012-OP-0308 is returned to the Civil
Team Leader or his representative.
7. The Civil Team Leader or his representative is to raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works that requires further
attention.

infestation and discard the previously used Silica Gel

packs.    [_ _]

housing cover visually inspect the condition of cables
and connections and clean, if required, within the camera
enclosure    [_ _]

seal is effective.   [_ _]

supply to the camera.  [_ _]

aligned.   [_ _]

public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.

attention of the Electrical Supervisor or his
representative.  [_ _]

01 M Inspection & test running of the WL TSH generators
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode.   [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. Refer to reference manual Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
5.   (a) Check that the generator was left in  "AUTO" [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuel and water.   [_ _]
(c) Check oil level.   [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates.  [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ).   [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts   [_ _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the "Work Done" area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap, as the gauge could be
misleading.  [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry.  [_ _]
6. Reference manual, Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP
Electrical Pty Ltd Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI
[M-MCL-ME-20016]
7.  (a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch on the generator
DC panel to "" RUN "" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch
back to "" AUTO ""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from "" AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST
"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature.   [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to " AUTOMATIC CONTROL" the generator will continue to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping.   [_ _]
(g) Record the hours run, from the hours run meter,  in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet.
8.  (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises.  [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages  [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet.  [_ _]
9. Fill in the Generator Log Book and record anything outside
normal parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet.  Raise a new job for any works requiring further
repairs.  Priority High P1.
10.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
11.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
12.Record the Hours run in Mainpac under "Plant" use RH mouse
click then select "Open"      then select "Meter
Readings" in edit mode add the Meter Reading for the
appropriate TSH Generator.
"

David,
Saturday Nights Smoke Duct leak repair report,
Repaired 4 x leaks locations were Arch joint 78 + Crack , Arch joint 80
, Arch joint 81 and Arch joint 82.
Carried out full Tunnel inspection and found the following leaks
requiring repair,
Right side of Tunnel, Arch joints,
7,8,15,17,21,32,42,101,123,137,161,172 and crack at B32 Total = 13.
Left side of Tunnel, Arch joints, 15,19,22,41,43,75,132,139 and crack at
B44 Total = 9.
There are still a couple of drips requiring diversions ( Troughs ) at
B20 and B35 need to monitor to see if there causing issues to the public
until we can get to them next closure 20th September.

DEPARETMENT). The amount of leaks and severity has escalated due to the
excessive rain falls and rise in the water table.

and purchased in the event another leaks develop into waterfalls over
the roadway (as the previous 4 last month) to divert the leaks from
falling on top of motorists.

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carried out and that
(a) The General Section of the above job has been completed
and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring all cabling, connections and
installation meet the AS 3000 standard.
4. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each
Circuit Breaker and Isolator.  [_ _]
5. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations
including date of test, ground and weather conditions are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an
earthing resistance test in accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for
tightness of connections, and the condition of system
components e.g. Earthing electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
6. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance
and cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are
clean and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion.  Clean and tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal and battery voltage and
battery temperature prior to commencing the test as
well as at completion of test.  Where the battery or
terminal voltage at completion of test is less than
80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of it's serviceable life and
replacement options should be recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i)  Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for
damage etc.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Related Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
8. At Substations fill-in the log book.   [_ _]

04 M Insp/cln of  WL CCTV cams, EWP, Centre of Road"
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the right hand
lane or mounting the median strip
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane Closure: RHS lane
(d) Electrical Cabinet Location: Tollway
3. Set up the lane closure as per  Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and Translink  Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and the equipment mounted in the
cabinet is secure.  [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary.  [_ _]
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and are securely
fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.
(e) Check if surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is lit, if
not record the fact, for later replacement.  [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO  that picture vision is OK.  If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM  90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly  to the lead from the camera).
Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT300
module and is secure.  [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V supply to the PTZ controller and disconnect
(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing.  This will prevent movement
of the PTZ .  [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation.  Surface insect
spray may be applied if necessary to the housing exterior
but must not be applied to the interior of the housing or
to the housing glass.  If ingress of moisture or insect
infestation is evident then carry out
steps (d) and (e).  [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
"Rain-X " cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater thermostat
(HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the operation of the
heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
8. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
re-instate the 240V power supply to the PTZ
controller.  [_ _]
9. Notify the control room on completion and check the PTZ for
full movement and pre-programmed positions.  If camera fails
to respond press the reset button on the PT 300 and wait 2
minutes then check again.  [_ _]
10. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job sheet.
