03 M inspection of Refuge 3 air handling unit
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job
2. (a) Refer to Maintenance Manual, ""Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical
Services - MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation
commissioning tests.
3. Access Refuge 3 via substation 2, at ground level in Swan Street,
then down the stairwell to
the tunnel level.
4. Ensure supply fan SF-SS2-1 situated on roof of Substation 2 is
operating and normal air
supply to the ventilation shaft and refuge area is being maintained.
5. Check the grill, supplying air to the refuge area, in the
ventilationshaft is clear of debris that
will restrict air flow.   [_ _]
6. Ensure the door between the Burnley Tunnel and the Refuge area is
closed.
7. Prior to entering the refuge, have the traffic control room operator
check the CO and NO levels
and the temperature of the refuge.  Record in the ""Work Done"" area
of the jobsheet if the
ambient conditions are within required safety standards. If the air
quality is below standards, arrange for the control
room to refresh the air in the refuge by operating the fan until
suitable air quality is
achieved.  [_ _]
8. Inspection and checks of the Refuge and shaft area.
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN WORKING IN THE
VICINITYOF
THE OPERATING FAN.
(a) Check the
(i) exhaust vent on the duct   [_ _]
(ii) the return air grill on the fan unit    [_ _]
(iii) The fire damper and motorised damper exhaust grills in
the access shaft to
tunnel to ensure they are free of debris that would
restrict the free flow of
air.   [___]
Note: The air damper on the fan return air grill is
non-functional.
(b) Check the fire damper for damage, loose linkages and premature
operation.    [_ _]
(c) Arrange the traffic control room operator to operate the fan.
Check the operation of the fan
ensuring the air flow is from the duct outlet into the refuge.
[_ _]
(d) Note: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire brigade. It
will register on the local FIP
and CCCS as a local alarm.
Remove the smoke detector access cover and spray ""test
smoke"", from a smoke
generator, as specified on the container, onto the smoke
detector (on the inlet duct).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local  fire indicator
panel.  [_ _]
(e ) With the supply air fan SA-SD3-01 operating record the
differential pressure, if less than
50Pa in the ""Work Done area of the job sheet.  Advise the
superintendent for further
investigation.   [_ _]
(f) Arrange the refuge door catch to be non-functioning, then using a
spring balance,
measure the force required to open the door. Record the results
in the ""Work Done""
area of the job sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required,
advise the superintendent
for further investigation.   [_ _]
(g) Chock the door open, then using an anemometer, measure the
velocity of air out of the
open door.  The reading should be with the door fully open and
no obstructions.
Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet
ifa velocity is less than
1 metre per  sec.  Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
corrective actions
required.   [_ _]
(h ) After closing the door, measure the time taken for the air
pressure to return to the static
reading.  Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the
job sheet if the time taken is
greater than two minutes.  Raise a new job sheet for any
outstanding corrective action
required.   [_ _]
( i ) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and vibrations.   [_ _]
( j ) Check the fan and motor bearings for noise.   [_ _]
(k) Check the fan plenum for damage, corrosion, missing panel
fixings, as well as
checking unit fixings for security.  [_ _]
( l ) Measure the motor current and compare with the rated current.
[_ _]
(m ) Check the filter elements for cleanliness and replace if
required.  ( 4 off 600x600x100mm)
and ( 4 off 600x300x100mm)    [_ _]
9. Ensure the action of opening the Refuge door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive pressure in
the Refuge.
(c) To replicate the action of the smoke detector, temporarily
removethe relay ""Refuge
Supply Air Fan No 3"" mounted in the rear compartment of the
fire indicator panel.  The
fan should stop after about two and a half minutes.  Replace
the relay on
confirmation.   [_ _] (A local alarm will register on the CCCS.
The fire brigade will not
be called)
10. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both the open
and the closed
position.
11. Clean the refuge:
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated webs from the walls.   [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish.   [_ _]
12. On completion of job record anything outside normal parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the refuge etc,  in the
""Work Done""
section of the job sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
13. Request the traffic control room to shut the fan down and to turn
off the lighting after
leaving the Refuge, ensuring that the door to the tunnel is
closed.
14. Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done"" area
of the Job Sheet.
15. Ensure the door between the Refuge and the Burnley Tunnel is closed.
16. Notify the Control Room on completion of the job."

12 M Inspection of  Merlin Gerin UPS system
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Involve the Transfield Maintenance Staff  in the UPS Switching to
maintain UPS switching
knowledge and awareness.
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work
2. The Galaxy UPS system 12 monthly inspection shall be carried out by
the sub-contractor in
the presence of the electrical / electronic technician.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual E-6739380XT/FA,
M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel Electrical Services
Training Notes,
M-STG-EL-24001, Section 9.
4. Record measurments on form 12 M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Inspection and Test
TMF-3012-OP-0200.
5. Check all the indicators on the hidden control panel.  Record any
alarm conditions in
the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet and raise a Job sheet to havethe
alarm condition
attended to.  [_ _]
6. Inspect the UPS and the batteries cleanliness, cracks, corrosion etc.
[_ _]
7. Measure and record the DC voltage of each battery. (Use Maintenance
application)
8. Measure and record (Use Maintenance application)
UPS input voltage
UPS output voltage
Battery voltage
Check the balance of each output phase and ensure the UPS is not
overloaded.
Check for correct UPS calibration. Maintenance Program required.
Peak and RMS loading.
Output current and voltage wave shapes.
AC capacitor current balance.
9. Isolate the UPS by switching to Maintenance Bypass.  [_ _]
10. Measure and record the temperature of the AC and DC filter
capacitors.  [_ _]
11. Measure and record the current flowing in various branches of the
battery circuits.  Ensure
each path is providing an equal or representitive portion of the
load.
12. Using an optical thermometer, measure the temperature of current
carrying connections,
during or following a current carrying period.  Terminals or
connections found with a
temperature which is greater than ""room  temperature plus 5
degrees) should be
investigated.  Repair any connections found to be faulty and
record in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet any repairs carried out..   [_ _]
13. Open the Battery Circuit Breaker and using a DC voltmeter, measure
the leakage
voltage between battery terminal positive and earth then between
battery terminal negative
and earth to ensure that there is no electrical leakage from the
batteries to earth.
THE BATTERY BANK IS ENERGISED EVEN WHEN THE RECTIFIER / CHARGER AND
INVERTER HAVE BEEN STOPPED AND THE BATTERY CIRCUIT BREAKER OPENED.
BATTERY MAINTENANCE SHOULD BE PERFORMED BY QUALIFIED TRADESPERSONS
IN ACCORDANCE WITH APPLICABLE SAFETY REGULATIONS.  INSULATED TOOLS,
GLOVES AND SAFETY GLASSES SHOULD BE USED.   WITH THE BATTERY
CIRCUIT
BREAKER CLOSED, THE BATTERY TERMINALS HAVE A RELATIONSHIP TO EARTH.
14. Measure and record the string DC voltages.  If the voltage differs
by ± 5% from the
expected voltage, carry out a discharge / cycling test.
15. Visually check the UPS circuit boards and components for conditions
that will lead to
failure of the UPS.
e.g. Security of PCB's and Ribbon cables
Cables and connections
Capacitors (Premature swelling, leakage)
Evidence of overheating.
Fuses are secured
General cleanliness of the UPS.
Replace or correct any fault found,  Record in the Work Done Area
ofthe Job Sheet any
repairs carried out
16. Return the UPS to normal operation.  FOLLOW THE CORRECT SWITCHING
SEQUENCE.
17. Check the UPS readout and program software for correct operation.
(Using Maintenance
application)
18. Simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the UPS
operation will change to
the batteries.
19. Measure and record (Using Maintenance application) the battery
voltage, at 5 sec
intervals, for a 15 minute period.  Plot results to obtain a
Discharge Characteristics Curve.
Compare curve with previous curves for evidence of battery
failure.  Record in the
Work Done Area of the Job Sheet any descrepancies and raise a Job
sheet for the
descrepancy to be attended to.  [_ _]
20.  Return the UPS system to its normal operational state.  [_ _]
21.  Notify the control room on completion of the job.  [_ _]"

12 M Inspection of Cast Resin HV Transformers
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All work on High Voltage equipment must be carried out in
accordance with Transfield's procedure number TMI-3012-SA-0102
High Voltage Safety Work Instructions.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers 1A, 1B, 2A,2B, 3A, 3B, 4A,
4B, 5A & 5B)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals,
cable connections, for partial discharge, ingress of
moisture or damage.
(b) Inspect Operation of the Winding temperature sensor.

and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic Control
Room.

evidence of overheating of broken strands. Tighten
connections where necessary.

of corrosion, dirt, or foreign material buildup.  Clean
coils , core and frame and treat and recoat any surface
rust spots.

results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
Job Sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team

01 M Inspection & test running of the WL TSH generators
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode.   [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. Refer to reference manual Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
5.   (a) Check that the generator was left in  "AUTO" [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuel and water.   [_ _]
(c) Check oil level.   [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates.  [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ).   [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts   [_ _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the "Work Done" area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap, as the gauge could be
misleading.  [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry.  [_ _]
6. Reference manual, Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP
Electrical Pty Ltd Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI
[M-MCL-ME-20016]
7.  (a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch on the generator
DC panel to "" RUN "" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch
back to "" AUTO ""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from "" AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST
"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature.   [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to " AUTOMATIC CONTROL" the generator will continue to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping.   [_ _]
(g) Record the hours run, from the hours run meter,  in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet.
8.  (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises.  [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages  [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet.  [_ _]
9. Fill in the Generator Log Book and record anything outside
normal parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job

03 M Inspect, Test & Clean Cremorne St Pump Station"
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning
and inspections of the Building and Electrics, prior to leaving
the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for
fluorescent, Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material, Ladders
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. On access the pump station control panel, be aware of the
atmosphere, use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to
monitor any abnormal events.  [_ _]
3. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of
the job sheet.   Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions.  [_ _]
4. Reference Manual TOJV Pump Station Operation and Maintenance
Manuals - M-STG-ME-20001. Volume 3.
5. WARNING:  BOTH THE WET WELL AND THE VALVE PIT ARE DESIGNATED
CONFINED SPACES AND  MUST ONLY BE ENTERED UNDER CONFINED
SPACE CONDITIONS.
Refer to Work Instruction, Confined Space Entry
TMI-3012-SA-0015.
6. At the Local Control Panel
(a) Check the switchboard, situated beside the pump station,
for local alarm conditions.   [_ _]
(b) Carry out visual inspections both internally and
externally of the control panel for         vandalism,
damage, corrosion, insect infestation, moisture ingress,
dust and grime (clean as required).   [_ _]
(c) Check the cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect the electrical control
equipment.   [_ _]
(d) Record the pump hour run meter reading in the Work
Done area of the job sheet.
7. Inspection of pump wet well and valve pit.
(a) Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the
valve pit, inspect both the wet well and the valve pit
for general cleanliness and debris.  Clean if
required.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of  the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks.  [_ _]
8. Switch the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position.    [_ _]
(a) Check  the position of the  pump non-return valve
counterweight before starting the pump.   [_ _]
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running or
vibration and abnormal noises. [_ _]
(c) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it
is clear from possible damage.   [_ _]
CAUTION:  Do not pump the wet well below the Low/Low level
alarm point as lack of submergence may cause
pumpset damage.
9. Start the pump PSCR1 by pressing the START button.
(a) Record the operating current of the pump in the Work
Done area of the job sheet.  (FLC 52A.).
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and abnormal noises.    [_  _]
(c) Observe the level controller readout for variations,
with respect to the operation of the pump.    [_  _]
(d) Assess the pump discharge rate by observing that outflow
issuing from the outlet pipe into the river.   [_ _]
(e) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton.  Check
the operation of each non-return valve (NRV), as the
water flow stops.  Indicators to the correct operation
of the NRV would be, the NRV closing with an sharp
audible metallic sound, the counterweight returning to
its original position or lower , as well, backflow
through the pump should cease within 30 seconds.  If a
faulty closure is suspected, the pump should be
re-started,  operated for 2 minutes and  the operation
of the NRV should then be monitored again.  If a faulty
closure is still suspected, report for corrective
maintenance.    [_ _]
(f ) Visually check the operation of the flap valve on the
riverbank.  The valve should operate freely and shut
tight to prevent backflow of any water  from the
river.   [_ _]
10. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position.   [_ _]
11. Check the operation of  the float switches in the wet well.
Manually trip the floats using hook bar from the surface,
lifting up the High/High float and Low/Low floats
respectively, then checking that the alarms were received at
the Control Room.  [_ _]
12. When this job falls in either January, February or March.
Lift the level controller sensor out of the protective
conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the sensor base
of all dirt and debris.   [_ _]
13.Test the operation of riverbank isolating valve by partially
closing and then fully opening.  [_ _]
ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. Check the interior lighting for operation, replace or repair
any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
2. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within the control
panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient
plus 10°C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
3. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
equipment and components for evidence of burn marks, unusual
odours and overheating.  record anything abnormal in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
4. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc.  [_ _]
5. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions.   [_ _]
6. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
7. Inspect the electrical enclosures internally for dust, grime
and condensation, clean enclosures of any accumulated dust,
dirt and debris.  [_ _]
8. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
obstructions.  [_ _]
9. Visually inspect systems, mounted within the control panel,
for faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp replacement
or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding actions.   [_ _]
10. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following.
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged in
the work done area of the job sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris.  [_ _]
11. Clean lighting diffusers  and lens of accumulated dust and
debris.  [_ _]
12. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.   Record
anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the job
sheet.   Record anything abnormal in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his
representative of outstanding actions.  [_ _]
Building (Control Panel) Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel interior for evidence of moisture
ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record any
details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform
the Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check the doors and windows for damage, operation, lubricate
and repair as required and record in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet.  Inform the Team Leader or his
representative of any outstanding works.  [_ _]
3. Clean and remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of
cabinets, ledges, cable trays, cables, etc.
Note: Dust will settle on all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops
of cabinets, tops of cabinet doors,  tops of meter
escutcheons etc.  [_ _].
4. Clean exterior surfaces of cabinets where necessary.  [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets and
ceilings.  [_ _]
6. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris.  Empty
rubbish bins and replace liners.  [_ _]
7. Sweep and remove all accumulated dirt and dust from control
panel interior.  [_ _]
8. Carry out Exterior Checks of control panel.
(a)  Visually inspect the exterior surfaces of the control
panels for damage, erosion, graffiti.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect (if applicable) the general area surrounding the
building for erosion and damage to surfaces, fences,
gates, pavements   [_ _]
9. Remove any accumulated debris from the surrounds.  [_ _]
10. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service e.g.
pumps etc.  [_ _]
(b)  All Enclosures closed and locked.  [_ _]
(c)  All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Pump Station and
equipment etc,  in the Work Done section of the job
sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done area
of the job sheet.       [_ _]
13. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspection of WIM & TCS Systems on the SL Tollway
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating<(>,<)>
symbolic worker, lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction , Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 0002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12 or Plan 142.
3. Reference: Central Weighing Australasia, Roadside Maintenance
Training Manual, Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1631, Rev 0 and for operation
of laptop computer, Weigh-in-Motion & Counting Stations<(>,<)>
Operator's  Manual for WIMS Front End Computer<(>,<)>
Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1630, Rev A, Section 3 Telecom- DOS
operator's Manual . (Status Information 6.1.2 page 145)
4. At SL WIM/TCS Systems 2205B control cabinet, check the
following;
(a) Internal and external condition of the cabinet.   [_ _]
(b) Check wiring for tightness and for any evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
(c) Check that the Tx and Rx LEDs (on the modem) flash at
least each minute.  [_ _]
(d) Check that the battery charger LED is ON.  [_ _]
(e) Using a vacuum cleaner, clean the cabinet
interior.   [_ _]
5. Use laptop computer to carry out the following:
(a) Plug the 9 pin serial lead from the computer to the
controller input/output board.
(b) Switch ON the computer.
(c) Click on Telecom WIMS Icon
(d) Select Comms by pressing the 'C' Key
(e) Select LOGGER/ONLINE, then press Enter.
(f) Check that the laptop computer communicates with the
logger correctly.  [_ _]
(g) Confirm the logger parameters, shown in the CURRENT
SITE (MCL) on page no. 1, area match those listed in
the document  Site Configuration and Set up Details
(stored cabinet).  [_ _]
(h) Press key Page Down to go to screen page 2. [_ _]
(i) Record on the form attached loop frequencies and weigh
responses.  [_ _]
(j) Record value of Power Status on page 2 of the
computer screen.  The battery should read approx 13
volts. [_ _]
(k) When a truck crosses the sensors check on page 2
(computer screen) that all sensors, in each lane are
operating correctly (an asterisk will appear momentarily
alongside the appropriate loops as the truck crosses).
This check should only be done with trucks and not cars
(weighing sites only), as all sensors may not be displayed
for cars.  [_ _]
(l) Select LOGGER/OFFLINE, then press Enter
(m) Select 'Quit', then press Enter
(n) Then select 'Quit' again, press Enter again.
(o) Select 'Yes' to quit Telecom system.
6. Switch computer OFF and then unplug the 9 pin serial
lead. [_ _]
7. From the side of the road, visually check the conditions of
the road sensors, for condition, no (loose bolts) metal
vibration or exposed wires visible. [_ _]
8. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
9. Notify the control room  prior to departure.

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carried out and that
(a) The General Section of the above job has been completed
and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring all cabling, connections and
installation meet the AS 3000 standard.
4. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each
Circuit Breaker and Isolator.  [_ _]
5. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations
including date of test, ground and weather conditions are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an
earthing resistance test in accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for
tightness of connections, and the condition of system
components e.g. Earthing electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
6. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance
and cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are
clean and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion.  Clean and tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal and battery voltage and
battery temperature prior to commencing the test as
well as at completion of test.  Where the battery or
terminal voltage at completion of test is less than
80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of it's serviceable life and
replacement options should be recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i)  Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for
damage etc.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Related Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
8. At Substations fill-in the log book.   [_ _]

06 M clean of tunnel lighting photometers
At the photometer **COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. This job is to be carried out during a tunnel shut.
3. Clean the external surfaces, including glass window, of
accumulated dirt and dust.  Use Rain-x and soft cloth.
4. Visually inspect the mounting components for damage,
corrosion (Remove and repair any corrosion found) and
security of fixings.
5. Visually check the cabling to the photometer for damage or
any required repairs (Repairs as required).
6. Check the general alignment of the Photometer for accuracy.
Methodology for Alignment Check:
**The alignment point needs to be defined by taping the distance
betweenthe walls of the Tunnel entrance to identify the centre, then
taping from the pavement upto 1.5m above. The target needs to be
this point, taking into account that the laser beam would be generated
parallel to the centre of the photometer.
At the photometer, a laser level needs to be placed on top of the
photometer and the unit then needs to be adjusted until the beam hits
the target. The process must be repeated with the laser placed on each
side of the unit, meaning the adjustment on the target**
7. Record any outstanding works required.
8. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
9. Notify the TCRO on completion of the Job

06 M clean of tunnel lighting photometers
At the photometer **COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. This job is to be carried out during a tunnel shut.
3. Clean the external surfaces, including glass window, of
accumulated dirt and dust.  Use Rain-x and soft cloth.
4. Visually inspect the mounting components for damage,
corrosion (Remove and repair any corrosion found) and
security of fixings.
5. Visually check the cabling to the photometer for damage or
any required repairs (Repairs as required).
6. Check the general alignment of the Photometer for accuracy.
Methodology for Alignment Check:
**The alignment point needs to be defined by taping the distance
betweenthe walls of the Tunnel entrance to identify the centre, then
taping from the pavement upto 1.5m above. The target needs to be
this point, taking into account that the laser beam would be generated
parallel to the centre of the photometer.
At the photometer, a laser level needs to be placed on top of the
photometer and the unit then needs to be adjusted until the beam hits
the target. The process must be repeated with the laser placed on each
side of the unit, meaning the adjustment on the target**
7. Record any outstanding works required.
8. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
9. Notify the TCRO on completion of the Job

03 M Inspection and Clean Equip Rooms ERE 00 & ERE17
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning and
inspections of the Building
and Electrics, prior to leaving the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum
Cleaner, Cloths,
lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting, Brooms,
Rubbish bags, Filter
material, Ladders, Silicon Lubricant Spray, Rodent Bait Station
A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the instrumentation
installations of
Equipment Rooms ERE 00 & ERE17as well as the cleaning, inspections and
maintenance
of the relevant areas.
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( Equipment Rooms ERE 00 & ERE 17)
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the Equipment rooms.
2. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere, use your
senses of sight, smell
and hearing to monitor any abnormal events.  [_ _]
3. Check the equipment room interior lighting for operation, including
the operational tube
within EXIT signs, replace faulty lamps or repair any faulty
lighting fixture.  [_ _]
4. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all accessible
equipment and
components within all switchboards and distribution panels. (Opsis
Air monitoring
equipment is not maintained by Transfield)
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient plus
10°C should be
considered abnormal and must be noted in the ""Work Done"" area of
the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. Raise a new
job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
5. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and
components  for evidence of burn marks, unusual odours and
overheating.  Record
anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and
raise a new jobsheet
for any corrective action. Ensure the Team Leader or his
representative is informed of
the abnormality.  [_ _]
6.  While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering,
arcing etc.  [_ _]
7. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware, gaskets,
seals and escutcheons
for serviceability and general operation, lubricate as required.
Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding actions.  [_ _]
8. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
9.  PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators found to
indicate abnormal
conditions are to be logged in the work done area of the job
sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw
connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and module
security screws are not
loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the enclosure andPLC
modules
are cleaned of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
10. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for dust,
grime and condensation,
clean enclosures of any accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
11. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.  Clean
or replace filters as
required.  [_ _]
12. Inspect systems, mounted within the equipment room(s), for faulty
indicators,
faulty meters, damaged switches and buttons etc, carry out repairsor
indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding actions.
[_ _]
13. Inspect the door alarm switches at all external doors for operation
and security.  Check
with the Traffic Control Room Operator to confirm the receipt of
analarm.  Repair
faulty of defective switches.  Record details of outstanding
defects in the ""Work Done""
area of the Job Sheet.  [_ _]
14. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the ""Work
Done"" area of the
Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative of any
corrective actions.
Include in the ""Related Job"" field of the new and this job, the
job number number of
the alternate Job.   [_ _]

1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture ingress.

any water.  Record any details in the ""Work Done"" area of the job

01 W Inspect & report of Egress tunnel features
Before you start the inspection, make sure that you are carrying the
camera, so that you can take any photographs of your observations.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this work.
2. Have the Traffic Control Room turn all lights on.
3. Enter the Burnley Tunnel Emergency Egress Tunnel (EET) at the Burnley
Stairwell and
carry out the following inspections over the entire length of the
EET.
4. Visually inspect the EXIT signs for operation (12 off).  Record on
the form ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 any  EXIT
sign that is not functioning correctly.
5. Visually inspect the stairwell and EET lighting for operation.
Record  on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
all instances of three (3) successive light fittings not functional.
6. Visually inspect all signage for cleanliness, damage and or damage
tofixings. Record
on the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly
Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 any signage requiring further attention.
7. Visually inspect walls, floors and roofs for ground water leaks.
Record on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
any leaks. Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage), LEAK TYPE
(Drip, Spray<(>,<)>
Running), POSITION (Roof, North wall, South wall, Floor).
8. Visually inspect floor for Trip Hazards e.g. raised grates,
accumulated debris, deposits of
leak sealant, water puddles etc.  Remove temporary hazards and
recordall occurrences
of hazards and their location on the form  ""Emergency  Egress Tunnel
Inspection Record  -
Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
9. Visually inspect
(a) and operate all emergency egress doors (e.g. Tunnel to EET - at
each cross passage
and
(b) doors within egress tunnel - for operation and or damage and
(c)  ensure all doors to equipment rooms are locked.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""  TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the
door location and a description of the repairs required.
10. Visually inspect all drainage and pits for evidence of blockage and
water over the floor.
Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage) TYPE (Pit, Drain, Pipe)
POSITION (North side, South side, Centre).  Record on the form
""Emergency Egress
Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
the location and
description of any blockage or flooding.
11. Visually inspect all EET and Stairwell fitments for damage,
corrosion, trip hazards<(>,<)>
obstructions (from walls or roofs) that are apparent.  Record on
the form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
and a description of the repairs and or obstruction.
12. Visually inspect for evidence of rodent infestation.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
of any sightings.
13. Remove all accumulated debris from the egress tunnel.
14. On completion have the Traffic Control Room switch all lights OFF.
15. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any abnormal
parameters found.
Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
16. Ensure the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  -
Weekly  Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 is returned to the CIVIL team leader or his
representative for
evaluation and recording of new leaks onto the Burnley Tunnel
Emergency Egress
Tunnel Leak Repair programme.  The Civil team leader is to ensure
any
outstanding works are scheduled.
17. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the work."
Work completed as above work plan.

M-MCL-ET-1225.

lane closure as per work instruction TMI-3012-OP-0002 and the
TLO procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 17, 18 and Plan 12 for the
left hand side access.
Note: In locations where a rear gantry exists the 400W VDC
lamps are located and accessed via the rear gantry structure.
Note: Any changes made to the closure in Work Done area of
the Job Sheet.
4. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment and
or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.
Adhere to safety instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 ""Working on
Gantry Structures"".

Preventative Maintenance No:
1201: Inspect electrical Pump set
1202: No procedure to check bolts are tightened.  Visually
check accessible bolt markings to ascertain if any movement,
inspect for corrosion.
1204: Inspect cabinets for cleanliness, corrosion , damage,
evidence of possible electrical malfunction, Inspect for
corrosion, ingress of moisture, insect infestation, damage
and security of all fasteners
1205: Checking VDC sensors and connectors.
The following Task is to be also carried out using extreme
care to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter the Fibre
Optic connectors or cables, ensure sufficient fibre optic
cable is available to allow removal of the fibre optic
connector (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
NOTE: Ensure the fibre Optic Connector remains free of
foreign matter.
Carefully remove the Fibre Optic Connector, clean the
connector body of any deposits. Take care to not touch the
Fibre Optic pins within the connector (if touched or dirty,
clean pins with Fibre Optic cleaner).
Apply a light  coating of silicon spray to a cloth and wipe
onto the Fibre Optic connector body, replace and exercise the
Fibre Optic Connector release collar.
Where connectors cannot be easily removed, record details in
the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and report the fact
to the Team Leader or his representative.
1206: Clean VR Sensor Unit Vent with brush or similar
7. Record in the area of the Job Sheet below any outstanding
works requiring further attention.  Create a new Job sheet
for any outstanding works and notify the Team Leader or his
representative of the outstanding works.  Record the New job
number in the "Work Done" area of this job sheet and in the

01 M Inspection of  Grant St. Vent Station Axial Fans
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Works to be carried out between 21:00 & 05:00. Three day notice of
pending works to
be given verbally to TLO Maintenance Manager.
2. Obtain the Permit to Work for entry to the ventilation rooms and to
interrupt  operations.
TLO Maintenance Manager to sign Work Permit and works to be carried
only within times
approved on the Work Permit.
3. Inform the control room prior to commencing the work and brief
TCRO'son interruptions
and expected alarms.
4. Reference Manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
(M-STG-VE-26059).
5. At the PMCS in the control room
(a) Check the motor balance vibration reading on the PMCS for all
fans.  If any  reading is in
excess of 6.5mm/s record the result in the ""Work Done"" area
of the job sheet  for further
action.    [_ _]
(b) Check the trend log for the last month, looking for abnormal
events. Record any
abnormalities in the"" Work Done"" area of Job Sheet.  Report
any events and or trends to
the Maintenance Superintendent  that may suggest some abnormal
function.  [_ _]
(c) Check  the running current and record in the ""Work Done"" area
if greater than
FLC 349A for further action.[__]
(d) Check the drive and non drive end bearing temperatures for the
operating fan motor.
Record the details for those bearings with a temperature
greater than 80°C in  the
""Work Done"" area of the job sheet  for further action.  [_ _]
(e) Check the CO levels in the tunnels and the Grant Street Stack on
PMCS screen in the
control room and ensure less than 30ppm prior to commencing
work.  [_ _]
6. Access to the Grant St ventilation station, on the mezzanine level,
is via the Grant St.
stairwell adjacent to the vent stack.  Access to substation 1 is
through the mezzanine
level walkway, north of the smoke duct, then crossing over the smoke
duct twice using
the service ladders to the roof of the substation, then down a
serviceladder  to the tunnel
and then along the tunnel walkway to the substation.
WARNINGS:
DO NOT CARRY OUT THESE CHECKS  WHENEVER THERE ARE MORE THAN 2 FANS
ARE OPERATIONAL.
DO NOT ENTER THE AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM ALONE. TWO OR
MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT WHENEVER ANY  WORK  IS CARRIED OUT IN
THIS AREA.  OBSERVE ALL NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS
DO NOT ENTER A SMOKE DUCT UNLESS A PERMIT HAS BEEN OBTAINED FOR
WORK  IN THIS AREA.  TO CROSS THE DUCT A SERVICE LADDER MUST BE USED
AT ALL TIMES
7. Prior to entering the Grant St Stairwell, contact the TCR and requestthey
select manual
control for all Grant St fans and to lock in fan EFW 01 for
continuing operation.
(NOTE: There must be at least one fan operation at all times).
8. Fan Chamber  Access
(a) Enter the fan room airlock from the mezzanine floor, not the
smoke duct.  To open the
airlock doors will require considerable force.  Equalise
thepressure in the air lock
and the fan room using the hatches in the wall before
entering the fan room.   [_ _]
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN, WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1  METRE OF AN
OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD,  AS THE AIR IS FLOWING AT APPROX  35 kph
9. Work plan for fan EFW 02.
9.1 Fan Room Static Checks
(a) Engage the EMERGENCY STOP button adjacent to the motor.  [_ _]
(b) Check the condition of anti-vibration mountings and ensure
that the rubber bushing
is moved freely, adjust if required.  [_ _]
(c) Examine the grease that has been discharged from motor
bearings for any noticeable
colour change.   [_ _]
(d) Open local electrical junction box e.g. : 1A EFW 02 JB-2
Inspect electrical wiring and
connections, inspect all glands for tightness.  [_ _]
(e) Visually inspect the motor for evidence of condensation, white
powder or similar.
Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any
evidence of condensation,
powder and the like and notify the Team Leader or his
representative.  [_ _]
(f) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and
heater windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motorwindings and the
winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
theheater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(vii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(viii) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
""Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
9.2 Running Checks.
(a) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton and contact the TCR to
start the
fan.  [_ _]
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
[_  _]
(c) Check the fan for abnormal noise.    [_ _]
(d) Check the flexible connections for wear and leakage.    [_ _]
(e) Check the anti-vibration mountings for operation and
structural soundness.    [_ _]
(f ) Check the operation of the local monitor.    [_ _]
(g) Record any abnormalities in the ""'Work Done"" area of Job
Sheet for further
action.    [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the Local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(f  ) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
9.3 Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) On completion of  the Static Fan Checks, return to
substation1, then remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then remove
the fan motor isolation
at  the MCC.
Note:  Ensure that only one non-operational fan is isolated at
any one time.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the MANUAL and
the  REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch from the REMOTE position
to the LOCAL
position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room; there start the fan, that is
being maintained,  by                     releasing the lo cal STOP
pushbutton at the fan and then pressing START pushbutton.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(e) Add Shell Stamina RL2 grease or equivalent, to the bearings,
only while the fan is
running.  Ten pumps per bearing.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the
bearings, using the retrieval
system.  Examine the grease for changes of colour.   [_ _]
(g) Check the fan for any abnormal noises or vibrations.     [_
_]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
10. Repeat step 9  for fan EFW 03.   [_ _]
11. Repeat step 9  for fan EFW 04.   [_ _]
12. Repeat step 9  for fan EFW 05.   [_ _]
14. Contact the TCR and request they start fan EFW 05.  [_ _]
13. Repeat step 9 for fan EFW 01.   [_ _]
15. (a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are disengaged.    [_ _]
(b) Collect all tools and materials, leave the fan room, again

fan room pressures.  [_ _]
16. At Sub 1, inspect the fan starter cabinet for loose connections, hot

20. Contact the TCR and request the TCR to start an additional fan from

21. Once the additional fan has started, request the TCR to stop EFW 05.
[_ _]
22. Repeat step 16 for fan EFW 05.   [_ _]
23. (a) Check the lighting within the fan chamber for operation.  [_ _]
(b) Repair any light found to be not operating or raise a new
jobsheet for the repair of
the fan chamber lighting.
24. Notify the control room on completion of the work and advise that
the fan control has been
returned to the TCR and that automatic operation can be resumed.
[_ _]
25.  Return to control room and ensure all fans are operational.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident hasoccurred

use of fans for smoke extraction.
1. Ensure all emergency stop buttons are released and that all fans are

operation.  [_ _]
2. Advise the TCR of any abnormal condition that will restrict

3. Vacate the ventilation fan chamber immediately, ensuring the sliding
door to the airlock is
closed and sealed.   [_ _]
4. Advise the traffic control room when all personnel are clear of the

04 M Insp/cln of  WL CCTV cams, EWP, emerg lane & Grdn bed"
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane or entering the garden bed area.
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane Closure: Emergency Lane or on Garden Bed.
(d) Electrical Cabinet Location:
WL Tollway - exception CCAM 526 & 542 are behind the
noise wall.
SL Tollway - exception CCAM 914 & 915 are behind the
noise wall.
3. Set up the lane closure as per  Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and Translink  Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12, 13, 14, 143.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and the equipment mounted in the
cabinet is secure.  [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary.  [_ _]
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and are securely
fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.
(e) Check if surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is lit, if
not record the fact, for later replacement.  [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO  that picture vision is OK.  If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM 90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly  to the lead from the
camera).
Ensure the   co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT300
module and is secure.  [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V supply to the PTZ controller and disconnect
(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing.  This will prevent movement
of the PTZ .  [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation.
Surface insect spray may be applied if necessary to the
housing exterior but must not be applied to the interior
of the housing or to the housing glass.  If ingress of
moisture or insect infestation is evident then carry out
steps (d) and (e).  [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X  cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater
thermostat (HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the
operation of the heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
8. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
re-instate the 240V power supply to the PTZ
controller.   [_ _]
9. Notify the control room on completion and check the PTZ for
full movement and pre-programmed positions.  If camera fails
to respond press the reset button on the PT 300 and wait 2
minutes then check again.  [_ _]
10.On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.

03 M Inspect of Liebert AC units accessed via the EE Tunnel.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.   [_ _]
2. Access is via the Emergency Egress Tunnel from the entry
adjacent to the Burnley Vent Station stack.
(a) Arrange for the control room to start Supply Air fan
ESFP01. ESFP01 is the Supply Air for the Emergency Egress
Tunnel.
(b) Arrange for the control room to switch on the Emergency
Egress Tunnel lighting prior to entering the tunnel.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
shown on unit is consistent with new setpoint and
verify temperature is consistent with ambient
(+ or - 1 deg) using portable  thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm.   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary.  Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.
4.6. Restart  unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage
problems.  Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0 Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record the
results on form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347.
Ensure the form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347
is returned to the Electrical Electronics Supervisor or his
representative.  Raise a new job for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters  in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Supervisor or his representative and raise a
new job for any outstanding  repairs.
9.0 Notify the control room on completion of the job and arrange
for the control room to switch off the emergeny egress
tunnel lighting as well as the supply air fan.

04 M Inspect & clean of AIDS , EWP, Southbank area"
This group of AIDs are around the Southbank area, and may
require refinement.
AID 602 is on the Power St Overpass Looking at the Grant St
Portal.
AID 604 is located on the on the Westgate looking westbound at
the Kingsway exit..
AID 605 is on a pole mounted in the central median strip looking
westbound.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the lane to
service the camera..
2.  Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane closure: LHS & RHS Lanes.
(d) Electrical cabinet location: Tollway.
3. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plans 1, 2, 3.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage,  corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and check that the equipment mounted
in the cabinet is secure. [_ _]
(c) Check the cables and terminations for signs of
degradation, re-terminate if necessary.
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and securely fastened
to the PT140 and the LED is green, if the LED is red
there is no signal from the camera.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF THE FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE, AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.  [_ _]
(e) Check that the surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is
lit, if not record the fact, for later
replacement.  [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO  that picture vision is OK.  If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM  90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly  to the lead from the camera)
.  Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT140
module and is secure.  [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V power supply to the camera heaters.
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
(a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, external
evidence of moisture and any insect infestation.  Surface
insect spray  may be applied if necessary to the housing
exterior but must not be applied to the interior of the
housing or to the housing glass.
If there is evidence of insect infestation or moisture,
then open camera housing and carry out steps 7. (d) and
(e)  [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts.   [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X  cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(d) Check that the camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.  [_ _].
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Jell pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Jell pack.
8. Re-instate the 240V power supply to the camera
heaters.  [_ _]
9. Check with the control centre that the AID camera is
functioning correctly and that the MASK is aligned.   [_ _]
10. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
11. Notify the control room on completion.

12 M Inspection of Cast Resin HV Transformers
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All work on High Voltage equipment must be carried out in
accordance with Transfield's procedure number TMI-3012-SA-0102
High Voltage Safety Work Instructions.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers 1A, 1B, 2A,2B, 3A, 3B, 4A,
4B, 5A & 5B)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals,
cable connections, for partial discharge, ingress of
moisture or damage.
(b) Inspect Operation of the Winding temperature sensor.
Carry out functional testing to ensure correct Alarming
and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic Control
Room.
(c) Check tightness (Torque test) of all earthing and cable
connections (MEN, Bushings and tank) and inspect for
evidence of overheating of broken strands. Tighten
connections where necessary.
(d) Inspect transformer coils, core and frame, for evidence
of corrosion, dirt, or foreign material buildup.  Clean
coils , core and frame and treat and recoat any surface
rust spots.
3. Record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
Job Sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Releated Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]

on the HV terminal and the tapping link bars

M8                    9.8Nm
M10                  19.6Nm
M12                  34.3Nm
M14                  58.8Nm

for the LV bars (Both Nut and Bolts).

M12                 44.0Nm

12 M Minor inspection & test run of each WL TSH generator
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The generator minor service ""TYPE A"", as set out in the
Cummins Maintenace report, shall be carried out by the
sub-contractor on the WL technical shelter generators access
gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Minor Service ""TYPE A"" Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's
Manual 960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012].
The sub-contractor shall carry out the service as per items
listed on the maintenance report column ""A"" and test as per
par 5.
4. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch on the generator DC
panel to ""RUN"" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch
back to ""AUTO""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY &
TEST"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature    [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switch board back
to ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" the generator will continune to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping.  [_ _]
5. Fill in the Generator Log Book
6. Record the
(a) Sub-contractors Maintenance Report No   [____________]
(b) Sub-contractors  Field Report No    [__________]
(c) Generator Hours run ( from the hour run meter )
[__________].  Enter the Reading of the hours run meter
into the meter readings screen on the Plant usage Tab.
7. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
8. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
"

06 M Inspect & Clean the Tunnel air velocity and Temp sensor
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1 Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference manual Erwin Sick Operating Instructions - Flowsic 200
AirVelocity of Flow
Measuring Device - [M-STG-EL-24004].
3. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic Control
TMI-3012-OP- 0002 and
Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 23 & 24 (or to be defined).
4. Tunnel Sending/Receiving sensor units.
WARNING:
DO NOT LOOK INTO THE LASER LIGHT USED TO ALIGN TRANSDUCERS.  THE
LASER
LIGHT CAN CAUSE DAMAGE TO EYES.
WARNING:
DO NOT PUT YOUR EARS INTO THE ULTRASONIC SIGNAL PATH.  ULTRASONIC
SIGNALS CAN DAMAGE HEARING.  IT IS ADVISED TO WEAR HEARING
PROTECTION
WHEN WORKING IN THE VICINITY OF THE TRANSDUCERS.
CAUTION:
FIT PROTECTIVE CAPS TO THE SAFETY TUBES OF THE SENDER AND RECEIVER
DURING CLEANING.
PROTECT THE ULTRASONIC  TRANSDUCER FROM WATER AT ALL TIMES.
DO NOT TOUCH THE ULTRASONIC TRANSDUCERS EITHER BY HAND OR WITH ANY
CLEANING MEDIUM.
(a) Inspect both the sending and receiving for damage and or
corrosion.  [_ _]
(b) Using a cap, cover the safety tube that protects the transducer,
then clean the external
surfaces of the Flowsic 200 with a cleaning cloth, optical
cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(c) Remove the safety tube cap, then clean the internal surfaces of
the safety tube as well
as the transducer surface using a gentle stream of air ONLY.
[_ _]
(d) Check that the cable connection to the sensor unit is tight and
that the cable is suitably
supported and secure.  [_ _]
(e) Check that the mounting bracket and the bolts holding the unit
are secure.  If any of the
bolts need to be tightened, the alignment of the sensors must
be checked.  Alignment
is confirmed using a laser pointer and must be within the
range of 1º in all planes.   [__]
( f) Check with the control room that system is functioning
correctly prior to leaving the
unit.  [_ _]
5.  Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done "" area
of the job sheet.
6.  Notify the Control room on completion of the job."

01 W Inspect & report of Egress tunnel features
Before you start the inspection, make sure that you are carrying the
camera, so that you can take any photographs of your observations.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this work.
2. Have the Traffic Control Room turn all lights on.
3. Enter the Burnley Tunnel Emergency Egress Tunnel (EET) at the Burnley
Stairwell and
carry out the following inspections over the entire length of the
EET.
4. Visually inspect the EXIT signs for operation (12 off).  Record on
the form ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 any  EXIT
sign that is not functioning correctly.
5. Visually inspect the stairwell and EET lighting for operation.
Record  on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
all instances of three (3) successive light fittings not functional.
6. Visually inspect all signage for cleanliness, damage and or damage
tofixings. Record
on the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly
Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 any signage requiring further attention.
7. Visually inspect walls, floors and roofs for ground water leaks.
Record on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
any leaks. Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage), LEAK TYPE
(Drip, Spray,
Running), POSITION (Roof, North wall, South wall, Floor).
8. Visually inspect floor for Trip Hazards e.g. raised grates,
accumulated debris, deposits of
leak sealant, water puddles etc.  Remove temporary hazards and
recordall occurrences
of hazards and their location on the form  ""Emergency  Egress Tunnel
Inspection Record  -
Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
9. Visually inspect
(a) and operate all emergency egress doors (e.g. Tunnel to EET - at
each cross passage
and
(b) doors within egress tunnel - for operation and or damage and
(c)  ensure all doors to equipment rooms are locked.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""  TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the
door location and a description of the repairs required.
10. Visually inspect all drainage and pits for evidence of blockage and
water over the floor.
Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage) TYPE (Pit, Drain, Pipe)
POSITION (North side, South side, Centre).  Record on the form
""Emergency Egress
Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
the location and
description of any blockage or flooding.
11. Visually inspect all EET and Stairwell fitments for damage,
corrosion, trip hazards,
obstructions (from walls or roofs) that are apparent.  Record on
the form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
and a description of the repairs and or obstruction.
12. Visually inspect for evidence of rodent infestation.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
of any sightings.
13. Remove all accumulated debris from the egress tunnel.
14. On completion have the Traffic Control Room switch all lights OFF.
15. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any abnormal
parameters found.
Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
16. Ensure the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  -
Weekly  Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 is returned to the CIVIL team leader or his
representative for
evaluation and recording of new leaks onto the Burnley Tunnel
Emergency Egress
Tunnel Leak Repair programme.  The Civil team leader is to ensure
any
outstanding works are scheduled.
17. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the work."

12 M Routine Maint. of Burnley Vent Station Fan
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
WARNINGS:
1. CHECKS SHOULD NOT BE CARRIED OUT IF MORE THAN 2 FANS ARE OPERATING IN
THE SECONDARY VENT STATION.
2. NO PERSON SHALL ENTER THE ACCESS AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM
ALONE.
TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT AT ALL TIMES WHEN WORK IS BEING
CARRIED OUT IN THE AIRLOCK OR VENT STATION
3. TAKE HEED OF NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS.
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3,  the ventilation
rooms and to interrupt
operations.
2.  Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.  Maintain
radiocontact at all times.
3.  Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
(M-STG-VE-26058)
4. Access to the Burnley ventilation station is through a locked airlock(Key2-LV)
on the
stairway  adjacent to the south west corner of the Burnley vent
stack.
Access to substation 3 is via external doors adjacent to the Burnley
Portal.
5. Ensure the 3 monthly check of the fans, carried out at the PMCS,
havebeen completed.
6. At the MCC in Substation No 3
Select one axial fan to be operational while the maintenance is being
carried out on
the other fans.  The fan selected can be any fan other than the fan
to be maintained
(preferably a fan located the furthest from the fan to be
maintained).
(a) If the selected fan is not running, then have the TCR start the
selected fan.
(b) Isolate the remaining non-operational axial fans, by switching
the AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switches to the OFF position.  Carry out the
electrical isolation procedures
as defined in the Work Instruction TMI -3012-OP - 0103,  Low
Voltage Isolation
Procedures.
7.  Electrical checks in Substation No 3
(a)  Measure the insulation resistance of the stator windings and
record in the ""Work Done""
section of the Job Sheet.  [_ _]
(b)  Measure the current of the anti-condensation. Heater current
isapprox. 1 amp.
(c)  Visually inspect both internally and externally, the control
panel for damage, corrosion
as well as the ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as
required)
8. (a) Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after equalizing
pressure in airlock.
WARNING: HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION SHOULD BE WORN IN
VENTILATION
FAN CHAMBER
(b) Check CO levels in fan room through doorway before entering and
at intervals during
fan checks.
(c)  WARNING:  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1
METRE
OF AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD.  Airflow strength 35 km/h.
9. Static Fan Checks for each fan.
(a) Confirm that both the fan and motor are electrically and
mechanically isolated prior to
commencing any work on the fan or the motor.
(b) Enter the fan inlet cowl via the entry cowl safety grill hatch.
(c) Examine the impeller for
(i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
[_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips   [_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges   [_ _]
(iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub   [_ _]
(d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage due
to fraying, scuffing or
similar and for damage at locations where the cables penetrate
panels or
housings.    [_ _]
(e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
excessive.   [_ _]
(f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticeable colour change.
Ensure that the
grease nipples are clean.  [_ _]
(g)  Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
(h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the motorwindings
and the
winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
each phase winding and earth.  Record results in the Work
Done area of the
Job sheet.
(vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(x)  Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
""Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
(i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately.  [_ _]
(j) Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.
(k ) Remove any mechanical interlocks blocking the fan operation.
[__]
10. Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation
3and remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then
removethe fan motor isolation
at the MCC.
Note:  Ensure that all non-operational fans are isolated, in
accordance
TMI-3012-SA-0103, and that the only fan not
isolated, is the fan to be maintained.
(b) Return the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the AUTO position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room and have TCR start the fan,
thatis being maintained.
Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
(e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr  Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or
equivalent only.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the bearings
using the retrieval
system.  Examine the grease for changes of colour.  [_ _]
(g) Monitor the fan and motor for abnormal noises.      [_ _]
(h) Stop the fan motor using Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
11. On completion, collect all materials and leave the fan room after
equalizing the
differential pressures.
12. In Substation No 3
(a) Remove all safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103,
then remove the
motor isolation for all the fans at the MCC.  Return all
theREMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switches to the REMOTE position,  and the
AUTO/OFF/MAN  fan selector
switches to the AUTO position.
(b) Check that one fan is operational and no alarms are present
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done' sectionof
the Job Sheet.
14. Notify the control room on the completion of the job.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident
hasoccurred requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
1. If the fan being checked is operating, advise the traffic control
room  that it is currently
operating under LOCAL control and will be returned to AUTO control.
Stop fan using
the Emergency STOP pushbutton adjacent to the fan.
2. Release the STOP pushbutton .
3. Leave the fan chamber immediately by either the north or south exit

that the door to the stairwell airlock is secured.
4. Advise the traffic control room when all personnel are all accounted

adjacent to the Burnley Vent Stack.
5. In Substation 3 Switch the REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to the
REMOTE position,
as well switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN fan selector switch to the AUTO

6. Switch the operational fan AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch to the AUTO
position and start
the fan.
7. Notify TCR Operators that they have control.
On completion of the job, the ""Hours Run"" detail, for each fan is to
