03 M Load test of the MGE UPS
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the work.
2. Check with the control room if any UPS alarms are relevant.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual
E-679380XT/FA, M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel
Electrical Services Training Notes, M-STG-EL-24001,
Section 9.
WARNING
THE UPS BATTERY POTENTIAL IS APPROXIMATELY 380 VOLTS AND IS
EARTHED.  THE BATTERIES CAN DELIVER A FAULT CURRENT OF
APPROXIMATELY 9000 AMPS.  EXPOSED BATTERY TERMINALS ARE
DANGEROUS AND MUST NOT BE TOUCHED.  IN THE VICINITY OF THE
BATTERIES USE ONLY TOOLS WHICH ARE FULLY INSULATED.
SAFETY GLASSES MUST BE WORN WHEN CARRYING OUT  MEASUREMENTS
ON THE BATTERIES.
4. Check the UPS control panel readout for alarms and or normal
status.  If an alarm is found, record the alarm in the Work
Done Area of the Job Sheet. Do Not Continue with this Job if
an alarm is present.  [_ _]
5. Record measurements on form 03 M MGE Uninterruptible Power
Supply Battery Inspection and Test, TMF-3012-OP-0099.
6. Measure and record the UPS room temperature.   [_ _]
7. Check and record DC voltage and AC ripple voltage for each
bank of batteries.  If a discrepancy is found then record in
the Work Done Area of the Job Sheet.  Do Not Continue
this job sheet if there is a discrepancy in the readings
recorded and the readings expected.  [_ _]
8. To simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the
UPS operation will change to the batteries.  [_ _]
9. Operate the UPS, in this mode, for at least 10
minutes.  [_ _]
10. Measure and record the DC voltage for each shelf of the
battery banks.
11. Measure and record the DC current flow in each battery bank.
12. Return the UPS to normal operation by closing Mains 1
Isolator Q1.  [_ _]
13. With an Optical thermometer measure the temperature of the
batteries and their inter-connections.  Temperature readings
should approximate ambient room temperature.  When a
connection is found to having a temperature greater than 5
degrees above room  temperature, in the Work Done Area of
the Job Sheet, record the battery location, terminal
identification, measured  temperature.  [_ _]
14. With an Optical thermometer measure the average temperature
of the two (AC & DC) capacitor banks and record the result.
15. With an anemometer measure and record the airflow from each
of the UPS cooling fans.
16. With the Optical thermometer measure and record the
temperature of each of the UPS cooling fans.  [_ _]
17. Ensure Normal operation of the UPS.  [_ _]
18. Sweep and clean the UPS room:
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated webs from the
walls.   [___]
Sweep the control panel room floors as well, vacuum the
control panel enclosures and any surfaces that will collect
dust deposits.   [___]
Clean the front panel of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish.   [_ _]
19. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the UPS room and
equipment etc,  in the "Work Done"section of the job
sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
20. Leave a duplicate 03M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Battery Inspection and  test form in the UPS room.  Compare
previously recorded data and record in the Work Done
Area of the Job Sheet any data that shows any degradation.
21. Notify the control room on completion of the job."

use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events.  [_ _]
4. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace
faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.  Use an Infra-red temperature
sensor.  Temperatures of ambient plus 10°C should be
considered abnormal and must be noted in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team Leader or his
representative is informed of the abnormality.  Raise a new
job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and components for evidence of burn
marks, unusual odours and overheating.  Record anything
abnormal in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new jobsheet for any  corrective action. Ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
7. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc.  [_ _]
8. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions.  [_ _]
9. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
10. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for
dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures of any
accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
11. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.
Clean or replace filters as required.  [_ _]
12. Inspect systems, mounted within the building or room(s), for
faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp replacement
or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions.   [_ _]
13. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged
in the work done area of the job sheet and a new job
sheet raised to investigate and correct the
error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw  connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated
dust and debris.  [_ _]
14. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.  [_ _]
15. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader
or his representative of any corrective actions.  [_ _]
C. Control and pump room Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture
ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record any
details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check that the room(s) are not obstructed by furnishings and
or stored items.  Remove any obstruction.  [_ _]
4. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets,
ledges, cable trays, cables, etc.   Note: Dust will settle on
all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets, tops of
cabinet doors, tops of meter escutcheons etc.  [_ _].
5. Clean all exterior surfaces of cabinets using approved
cleaning materials .  [_ _]
6. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets, light
fittings, cable trays and ceilings.  [_ _]
7. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris.  [_ _]
8. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces.  [_ _]
9. Visually inspect rodent bait station for bait.  Replace bait
station if bait is near exhausted.  [_ _]
10. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.
Record any abnormal parameter in the Work Done area of the
job sheet.   Raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
corrective actions.  [_ _]
11. Remove any accumulated debris from the building
surrounds.   [_ _]
12. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service
e.g. Fans, Air Conditioners.  [_ _]
(b) All Enclosures are closed and locked.  [_ _]
(c) All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
13. Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader
or his representative of any corrective actions.  [_ _]
14. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to departing.

12 M Minor inspection & test run of each WL TSH generator
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The generator minor service ""TYPE A"", as set out in the
Cummins Maintenace report, shall be carried out by the
sub-contractor on the WL technical shelter generators access
gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Minor Service ""TYPE A"" Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's
Manual 960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012].
The sub-contractor shall carry out the service as per items
listed on the maintenance report column ""A"" and test as per
par 5.
4. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch on the generator DC
panel to ""RUN"" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the ""RUN / OFF / AUTO"" Switch
back to ""AUTO""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY &
TEST"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature    [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switch board back
to ""AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" the generator will continune to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping.  [_ _]
5. Fill in the Generator Log Book
6. Record the
(a) Sub-contractors Maintenance Report No   [____________]
(b) Sub-contractors  Field Report No    [__________]
(c) Generator Hours run ( from the hour run meter )
[__________].  Enter the Reading of the hours run meter
into the meter readings screen on the Plant usage Tab.
7. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
8. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

03 M Safety inspection of Refuge 1&2 air handling units
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Obtain a Right hand lane closure approval for Burnley Tunnel
2. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job and again prior
to entering the refuge.
3. (a) Refer to the Maintenance Manual, ""Operation and Maintenance
Manual for Mechanical
Services -MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400 and Drawing No.
EQP-ME-27410.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation
commissioning tests.
4. The vent for Refuge 1 is situated in Olympic Park adjacent to the
Ticketek office (enter via
gate 2 in Swan Street).
The vent for Refuge No 2 is on the North Embankment of  the Yarra
River, 200m east of the
Swan Street Bridge.
(a) Before entering the tunnel, check the inlet vent cowls for
damage and remove any
debris that may restrict free air flow into the Refuge below,
prior to entering
the tunnel.   [_ _]
(b) Prior to entering the refuge, have the traffic control room
operator check the CO and NO
levels and the temperature in the refuge.   Record in the
'Work Done"" area of the job
sheet if the ambient environment is not fresh.  If the air
quality in the refuge is below
standards, arrange for the control room to refresh the air in
the refuge by operating the
fan until suitable air quality is achieved.    [_ _]
5. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic Control
TMI-3012-OP- 0002
and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 22.
6. Ensure the door between the Burnley Tunnel and the Refuge area is
closed.
7. Inspection and checks of the Refuge.
(a) Ensure that the door between the Burnley Tunnel and the Refuge
area, along with
ERE 06(07)  to the refuge door is closed.  Check the door,
hinges, handles, catches and
closer for damage and efficient operation.  Record anything
outside normal parameters
in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet.   Advise the
superintendent for further
investigation.    [_ _]
(b) Check the
(i) exhaust vent on the duct
(ii) the return air grill on the fan unit and
(iii) the fire damper and motorised damper, over the doorway,
for debris that may restrict
airflow.   [_ _]
Note: Air damper on fan return air grill is non-functional.
(c) Check the motorised damper, above door head,  for operation,
damage and loose
linkages.   [___]
(d) Check the fire damper for damage and loose linkages and premature
operation.   [___]
(e) Arrange the traffic control room operator to operate the fan.
Check the operation of the
fan ensuring:
(i) Damper over doorway closes.  Damper will modulate if  CO
andNO levels are
excessive [_ _]
(ii) Air flow is from the duct outlet into the refuge.   [_ _]
(f) NOTE: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire brigade. It
will register on the local FIP
and CCCS as a local alarm.
Remove the smoke detector access cover and spray ""test smoke""
from a smoke
generator, as specified on the container, onto the smoke
detector (on the inlet duct).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local fire indicator panel.
[_ _]
(g) With the supply air fan (SD-SS2-01(02))REF 01 P01 & REF 02 P02
operating
record the differential pressure, if less
than 50Pa in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet .  Advise
the superintendent for
further investigation.  [_ _]
(h ) Arrange the tunnel to refuge door catch to be non-functioning,
then using a spring
balance, measure the force required to open the door.  Record
results in the ""Work
Done area of the job sheet if a force greater than 11kg is
required.   Raise a new job
sheet for and outstanding corrective action that is required.
[_ _]
(i ) Chock the tunnel to refuge door open, then using an anemometer,
measure the
velocity of air out of the open door.  The reading should be
with the door fully open and
no obstructions.
Record results in the Work Done area of the job sheet if less
than 1 metre/sec. Advise
the superintendent for further investigation.   [_ _]
(j ) After closing the refuge door, check the time taken for the air
pressure to return to the
static reading.  Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job
sheet if the time is greater
than 2 minutes.  Raise a job sheet for any outstanding
corrective actions
required.   [_ _]
(k ) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and vibrations.   [_ _]
( l ) Check the fan and motor bearings for noise.   [_ _]
(m ) Check the fan plenum for damage, corrosion, missing panel
fixings, as well as
checking unit fixings for security.  [_ _]
(n) Measure the motor current and compare with the rated current.
[_ _]
(o) Check the filter elements for cleanliness and replace if required.
( 4 off 600x600x100mm)
and ( 4 off 600x300x100mm)    [_ _]
8. Ensure the action of opening the Refuge door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive pressure in
the Refuge.
(c) To replicate the action of the smoke detector, temporarily removerelay
""Refuge Supply
Air  fan No. 1 (2) "" mounted in the rear compartment of the
fire indicator panel.  The fan
should stop after about two and a half minutes.  Replace the
relay on
confirmation.   [_ _] ( The fire brigade will not be called)
9. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both the open
and the closed position.
10. Clean the Refuge:
Sweep the floor and clean the walls of accumulated cobwebs    [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish.   [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the refuge etc  in the
""Work Done""
section of the job sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Repeat steps 6 to 11 for the fan in refuge 2 and the cleaning of
refuge 2.
13. Inspect the gas detector, dust filter for cleanliness, install a
newfilter if required.   [_ _]
14. Request the traffic control room to shut the fan down and to turn
ofthe lighting after
leaving the Refuge, ensuring that the door to the tunnel is closed.
15. Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done"" area

01 W Inspect & report of Egress tunnel features
Before you start the inspection, make sure that you are carrying the
camera, so that you can take any photographs of your observations.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this work.
2. Have the Traffic Control Room turn all lights on.
3. Enter the Burnley Tunnel Emergency Egress Tunnel (EET) at the Burnley
Stairwell and
carry out the following inspections over the entire length of the
EET.
4. Visually inspect the EXIT signs for operation (12 off).  Record on
the form ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 any  EXIT
sign that is not functioning correctly.
5. Visually inspect the stairwell and EET lighting for operation.
Record  on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
all instances of three (3) successive light fittings not functional.
6. Visually inspect all signage for cleanliness, damage and or damage
tofixings. Record
on the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly
Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 any signage requiring further attention.
7. Visually inspect walls, floors and roofs for ground water leaks.
Record on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
any leaks. Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage), LEAK TYPE
(Drip, Spray,
Running), POSITION (Roof, North wall, South wall, Floor).
8. Visually inspect floor for Trip Hazards e.g. raised grates,
accumulated debris, deposits of
leak sealant, water puddles etc.  Remove temporary hazards and
recordall occurrences
of hazards and their location on the form  ""Emergency  Egress Tunnel
Inspection Record  -
Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
9. Visually inspect
(a) and operate all emergency egress doors (e.g. Tunnel to EET - at
each cross passage
and
(b) doors within egress tunnel - for operation and or damage and
(c)  ensure all doors to equipment rooms are locked.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""  TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the
door location and a description of the repairs required.
10. Visually inspect all drainage and pits for evidence of blockage and
water over the floor.
Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage) TYPE (Pit, Drain, Pipe)
POSITION (North side, South side, Centre).  Record on the form
""Emergency Egress
Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
the location and
description of any blockage or flooding.
11. Visually inspect all EET and Stairwell fitments for damage,
corrosion, trip hazards,
obstructions (from walls or roofs) that are apparent.  Record on
the form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
and a description of the repairs and or obstruction.
12. Visually inspect for evidence of rodent infestation.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
of any sightings.
13. Remove all accumulated debris from the egress tunnel.
14. On completion have the Traffic Control Room switch all lights OFF.
15. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any abnormal
parameters found.
Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
16. Ensure the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  -
Weekly  Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 is returned to the CIVIL team leader or his
representative for
evaluation and recording of new leaks onto the Burnley Tunnel
Emergency Egress
Tunnel Leak Repair programme.  The Civil team leader is to ensure
any
outstanding works are scheduled.
17. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the work."

12 M Inspection & calibration of WIM & TCS Systems
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Access keys for the WIM/TCS controller cabinets are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to accessing the WIM/TCS
equipment.
3. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating<(>,<)>
symbolic worker, lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction , Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 00002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
4. Reference Transfield Procedures TMI -3012-OP-0045  WIMS -
Speed Calibration and TMI-3012-OP-0046  Weigh in Motion
Calibration.
5. Re-calibrate the weigh sensor, using both a 6 axle
articulated vehicle and the Transfield Services street
sweeper vehicle.
6. Re-calibrate speeds using a hand held laser gun. Use the
average of ten runs per lane for each calibration vehicle.
7. At the counting sites, re-calibrate the speed using a hand
held laser gun.  Use the average of ten runs per lane for
each calibration vehicle.
8. The results of test are to be recorded on forms WIMS Speed
Calibration TMF-3012-OP-0361 and  Weigh in Motion
Calibration TMF-OP-3012-0362.  A copy of the results are to
forwarded to the Electrical Electronics Team Leader on
completion of the job.
9. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.  [_ _]
10.Notify the control room  prior to departure from the WIM/TCS
site.

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carried out and that
(a) The General Section of the above job has been completed
and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring all cabling, connections and
installation meet the AS 3000 standard.
4. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each
Circuit Breaker and Isolator.  [_ _]
5. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations
including date of test, ground and weather conditions are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an
earthing resistance test in accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for
tightness of connections, and the condition of system
components e.g. Earthing electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
6. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance
and cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are
clean and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion.  Clean and tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal and battery voltage and
battery temperature prior to commencing the test as
well as at completion of test.  Where the battery or
terminal voltage at completion of test is less than
80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of it's serviceable life and
replacement options should be recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i)  Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for
damage etc.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Related Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
8. At Substations fill-in the log book.   [_ _]

**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
installations of
Equipment Rooms, as well the cleaning, inspections and maintenance of
the relevant areas.
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( Equipment Rooms ERE01 - ERE 16 and ERW 01 - ERW 06)
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the Equipment rooms, Technical
shelters and
Substations.
2. On entering switchrooms, temporarily switch OFF ventilation fans, if
operating (fans not
required to be  switched OFF in technical shelters and appropriate
equipment
rooms).   [_ _]
3. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere, use your
senses of sight, smell
and hearing to monitor any abnormal events.  [_ _]
4. Check the interior and external lighting for operation, including theoperational
tube within
EXIT signs, replace faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting
fixture.  [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all accessible
equipment and
components within all switchboards and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient plus
10°C should be
considered abnormal and must be noted in the ""Work Done"" area of
the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. Raise a new
job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and
components  for evidence of burn marks, unusual odours and
overheating.  Record
anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and
raise a new jobsheet
for any corrective action. Ensure the Team Leader or his
representative is informed of
the abnormality.  [_ _]
7.  While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering,
arcing etc.  [_ _]
8. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware, gaskets,
seals and escutcheons
for serviceability and general operation, lubricate as required.
Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding actions.  [_ _]
9. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and
damage.  [_ _]
10. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for dust,
grime and condensation,
clean enclosures of any accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
11. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.  Clean
or replace filters as
required. [_ _]
12. Inspect systems, mounted within the building or room(s), for faulty
indicators,
faulty meters, damaged switches and buttons etc, carry out
repairsor indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding actions.
[_ _]
13.  PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators found
toindicate abnormal
conditions are to be logged in the work done area of the job
sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw
connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and module
security screws are not
loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the enclosure and
PLC modules
are cleaned of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
14. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for accumulated
debris, evidence of water
accumulation, where applicable.
15. Inspect the door alarm switches at all external doors for operation
and security.  Check
with the Traffic Control Room Operator to confirm the receipt of
analarm.  Repair
faulty of defective switches.  Record details of outstanding
defects in the ""Work Done""
area of the Job Sheet.  [_ _]
16.   Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the ""Work
Done"" area of the
Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative of any
corrective
actions.  Include in the ""Related Job"" field of the new and
thisjob, the job number
of the alternate Job.   [_ _]
C. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture ingress.
Inspect for source of
any water.  Record any details in the ""Work Done"" area of the job
sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check that the room(s) are not obstructed by furnishings and or

any obstruction.  [_ _]
3. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets, ledges,

,cable trays and

10. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris.  [_ _]

equipment.  [_ _]
(d) Record the reading of the hour run meter, for the pump,
in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
7. Inspection of pump wet well and valve pit.
(a) Remove the gatic covers from both the wet well and the
valve pit, inspect both the wet well and the valve pit
for general cleanliness and debris.  Clean if
required.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the external condition of  the pipework and
valves for evidence corrosion and leaks.  [_ _]
8. Switch the pump AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the MANUAL
position.   [_ _] CAUTION:  Do not pump the wet well below
the Low/Low level alarm point as the lack of submergence may
cause damage to the pumpset.
(a) Check  the position of the counterweight for the pump
non-return valve (NRV) prior to starting the
pump.  [_ _]
(b) Check that the cabling to the pump for damage and that it
is clear from possible damage.   [_ _]
9. Start the pump PSCH1 by pressing the START button.
(a) Measure and record the operating current of the pump in
the Work Donearea of the job sheet.  (FLC 75A.).
(b) Observe the pump operation for smooth running, vibration
and abnormal noises.
(c) Observe the level controller readout for variations,
with respect to the operation of the pump.   [_  _]
(d) Stop the pump by pressing the STOP pushbutton.  Check
the operation of each non-return valve (NRV), as the
water flow stops.  Indicators to the correct operation
of the NRV would be, the NRV closing with an sharp
audible metallic sound, the counterweight returning to
its original position or lower , as well, backflow
through the pump should cease within 30 seconds.  If a
faulty closure is suspected, the pump should be
re-started, operated for 2 minutes and  the operation of
the NRV should then be monitored again.  If a faulty
closure is still suspected, report for corrective
maintenance.    [_ _]
10. Return the AUTO/OFF/MANUAL selector switch to the AUTO
position.   [_ _]
11. Check the operation of the  float switches.  Manually trip
the floats from the surface by lifting up the High/High
float and  the Low/Low float cables respectively with a hook
bar and then checking if the alarms were received at the
Control Room.   [_ _]
12. When this job falls in either January, February or March.
Lift the level controller sensor out of the protective
conduit, then carefully, clean the recess in the sensor base
of all dirt and debris.   [_ _]
13. Test the operation of the isolating valves by partially
closing and then fully opening. [_ _]
ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
1. Check the interior and external lighting for operation,
replace or repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
2. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient
plus 10°C should be considered abnormal and must be noted in
the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the Team
Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
3. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
equipment and components for evidence of burn marks, unusual
odours and overheating.  record anything abnormal
in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet and ensure the
Team Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
4. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc.  [_ _]
5. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware,
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and general
operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
actions.  [_ _]
6. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
7. Inspect the electrical enclosures internally for dust, grime
and condensation, clean the enclosure(s) of any accumulated
dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
8. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
obstructions.  [_ _]
9. Visually inspect systems, mounted within the building or
room(s), for faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged
switches and buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions.   [_ _]
10. PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following.
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators
found to indicate abnormal conditions are to be logged in
the work done area of the job sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated dust
and debris.  [_ _]
11. Clean lighting diffusers (including emergency and Exit
lighting) and lens of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
12. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.  Record
anything abnormal in the Work Done area of the job
sheet.  Record anything abnormal in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his
representative of outstanding actions.  [_ _]
Building (Control Panel(s) Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the control panel for evidence of moisture ingress.
Inspect for source of
any water.  Record any details in the Work Done area of
the job sheet and inform the Team Leader or his
representative.  [_ _]
2. Check the doors and windows for damage, operation, lubricate
and repair as required and record in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet.  Inform the Team Leader or his
representative of any outstanding works.  [_ _]
3. Clean and remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of
cabinets, ledges, cable trays, cables, etc.   Note: Dust will
settle on all ledges and surfaces, e.g. Tops of cabinets,
tops of cabinet doors,  tops of meter
escutcheons etc.  [_ _].
4. Clean exterior surfaces of cabinets where necessary.  [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets and
ceilings.  [_ _]
6. Remove from site all accumulated rubbish and debris.  Empty
rubbish bins and replace liners.  [_ _]
7. Sweep, vacuum and remove all accumulated dirt and dust from
the control panel interior.  [_ _]
8. Carry out Exterior Checks of Control panel.
(a) Visually inspect the exterior surfaces of the control
panel(s)  for damage, erosion,  graffiti.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect (if applicable) the general area surrounding
the control panel for  erosion and damage to surfaces,
fences, gates, pavements   [_ _]
9. Remove any accumulated debris from the surrounds.  [_ _]
10. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a) All plant turned OFF has been returned to service e.g.
pumps etc.  [_ _]
(b) All Enclosures closed and locked.  [_ _]
(c) All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures leaks
lighting faults, door damage, evidence of structural damage
to the Pump Station and equipment etc, in theWork Done
section of the job sheet and report to the Team Leader or
his representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
12. Record any corrective action required, in the Work Done
area of the job sheet.  [_ _]
13. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspection of WIM & TCS Systems on the SL Tollway
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating,
symbolic worker, lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction , Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 0002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12 or Plan 142.
3. Reference: Central Weighing Australasia, Roadside Maintenance
Training Manual, Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1631, Rev 0 and for operation
of laptop computer, Weigh-in-Motion & Counting Stations,
Operator's  Manual for WIMS Front End Computer,
Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1630, Rev A, Section 3 Telecom- DOS
operator's Manual . (Status Information 6.1.2 page 145)
4. At SL WIM/TCS Systems 2205A control cabinet, check the
following;
(a) Internal and external condition of the cabinet.   [_ _]
(b) Check wiring for tightness and for any evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
(c) Check that the Tx and Rx LEDs (on the modem) flash at
least each minute.  [_ _]
(d) Check that the battery charger LED is ON.  [_ _]
(e) Using a vacuum cleaner, clean the cabinet
interior.   [_ _]
5. Use laptop computer to carry out the following:
(a) Plug the 9 pin serial lead from the computer to the
controller input/output board.
(b) Switch ON the computer.
(c) Click on Telecom WIMS Icon
(d) Select Comms by pressing the 'C' Key
(e) Select LOGGER/ONLINE, then press Enter.
(f) Check that the laptop computer communicates with the
logger correctly.  [_ _]
(g) Confirm the logger parameters, shown in the CURRENT
SITE (MCL) on page no. 1, area match those listed in
the document  Site Configuration and Set up Details
(stored cabinet).  [_ _]
(h) Press key Page Down to go to screen page 2. [_ _]
(i) Record on the form attached loop frequencies and weigh
responses.  [_ _]
(j) Record value of Power Status on page 2 of the
computer screen.  The battery should read approx 13
volts. [_ _]
(k) When a truck crosses the sensors check on page 2
(computer screen) that all sensors, in each lane are
operating correctly (an asterisk will appear momentarily
alongside the appropriate loops as the truck crosses).
This check should only be done with trucks and not cars
(weighing sites only), as all sensors may not be displayed
for cars.  [_ _]
(l) Select LOGGER/OFFLINE, then press Enter
(m) Select 'Quit', then press Enter
(n) Then select 'Quit' again, press Enter again.
(o) Select 'Yes' to quit Telecom system.
6. Switch computer OFF and then unplug the 9 pin serial
lead. [_ _]
7. From the side of the road, visually check the conditions of
the road sensors, for condition, no (loose bolts) metal
vibration or exposed wires visible. [_ _]
8. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
9. Notify the control room  prior to departure.

12 M Inspection of Cast Resin HV Transformers
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All work on High Voltage equipment must be carried out in
accordance with Transfield's procedure number TMI-3012-SA-0102
High Voltage Safety Work Instructions.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers 1A, 1B, 2A,2B, 3A, 3B, 4A,
4B, 5A & 5B)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals,
cable connections, for partial discharge, ingress of
moisture or damage.
(b) Inspect Operation of the Winding temperature sensor.
Carry out functional testing to ensure correct Alarming
and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic Control
Room.
(c) Check tightness (Torque test) of all earthing and cable
connections (MEN, Bushings and tank) and inspect for
evidence of overheating of broken strands. Tighten
connections where necessary.
(d) Inspect transformer coils, core and frame, for evidence
of corrosion, dirt, or foreign material buildup.  Clean
coils , core and frame and treat and recoat any surface
rust spots.
3. Record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
Job Sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Releated Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
The following torque settings are:
Connections of HV connectors - Connections tightening torque
on the HV terminal and the tapping link bars
Bolts             Tightening Torque Nm
M8                    9.8Nm
M10                  19.6Nm
M12                  34.3Nm
M14                  58.8Nm
Connections of LV connectors - Connection tightening torque
for the LV bars (Both Nut and Bolts).
M8                  12.25Nm
M10                 24.5Nm
M12                 44.0Nm
M14                 68.6Nm
M16                 98.0Nm

04 M Insp & cln of AID cams with EWP in DT RHS lane
Perform this job at the same time as the CCTV, Speed cameras,
AID Equipment boxes and the AID Junction Boxes whilst a 2 lane
RHL closure of the tunnel is in place.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Work shall be carried out within designated times approved by
the TCRO.
2. Notify the control room prior to commencing the work.
3. Access to this camera group is:
(a) AID Cameras
801, 803, 805, 807, 809, 811, 813, 815, 817, 819, 821,
823, 825 and 827 are located over the right hand lane.
(b) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(c) Lane Closure: RH and centre lane
(d) AID Camera Equipment  Box Location:
Refer to Device Location Guide Ver 5.01 for locations.
4. Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 28 (40 kmh) and 40 (60kmh).
5. Reference Manual, Traffic Management Systems - CCTV & AID
Systems - Operators and Maintenance Manual,  (M-MCL-TM-1 511)
6. If it is necessary to isolate the camera power supply (24Vac)
can be switched off at a GPO mounted in the junction box that
services up to four AID cameras mounted locally to the
cameras.
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
(a) Visually inspect for vandalism, damage, corrosion,
external evidence of moisture and any insect infestation.
Surface insect spray  may be applied if necessary to the
housing exterior but must not be applied to the interior
of the housing or to the housing glass.
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to
mounts.   [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(e) Only If there is evidence of moisture and or insect
infestation within the camera housing, then open the AID
camera housing.  Remove any moisture or insect
infestation and discard the previously used Silica Gel
packs and replace with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel
packs.    [_ _]
Only if it has been necessary to remove the camera
housing cover visually inspect the condition of cables
and connections and clean, if required, within the camera
enclosure    [_ _]
Carefully replace the cover and ensuring the enclosure
seal is effective.   [_ _]
8. If the power has been isolated, re-instate the 24V power
supply to the camera.  [_ _]
9. Check with the Traffic Control Room that the AID camera is
functioning correctly and that the MASK is correctly
aligned.   [_ _]
10. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable,
Leaky Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework,
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and bring to the
attention of the Electrical Supervisor or his
representative.  [_ _]
11. On completion of job, record any outstanding works that
require further corrective works in the Work Done area of
the job sheet, raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding
works as required.
12. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Jet Fan maintenance and lubrication.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1.  Works to be carried out on one jet fan at a time so as to
not affect the operation of total tunnel ventilation
2.  Notify control room prior to commencing work.
3.  Set up lane closure as per Work Instruction TMI-3012-OP-0002
and Translink Operations Procedure PR-RS-OP-IR-020 Plan 27
or 28.
4.  Reference Manual;  Witt & Sohn, Operations and Maintenance
Manual , Certificate 18. (M-STG-VE-29047 )
5.  In associated equipment room switch jet fan AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switch to MAN and REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL switch to LOCAL
to enable control adjacent to jet fan.  [_ _]
6.  Running visual inspection
WARNING:  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF BODY IN INLET OR OUTLET
AIR STREAM WHEN FAN IS RUNNING.
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN.
(a) Start fan locally by pressing the START button on the
panel adjacent to the fan.   [_ _]
(b) Check for any abnormal noise or movement from the
fan.  [_ _]
(c) Check the fan unit vibration mountings and safety rods
for loose nuts and bolts.  [_ _]
(d) Stop fan locally with the EMERGENCY STOP button.  [_ _]
(e) If any non-conforming items are found, investigate
further in the static fan inspection.  [_ _]
7.  Static fan inspection
(a) Ensure the local  EMERGENCY STOP button is engaged. [_ _]
(b) Conduct a thorough visual inspection for damage and
corrosion of the silencers, impeller, inlet cone, cable
connections, mounting frame and vibration attenuators.
Any cracks identified in the vicinity must be noted in
the "Work done" area of the job sheet for
further investigation.   [_ _] Photo of Cracks found
will be required.
Any damage, especially to surface protection, must be
noted in the "Work done" area of the job sheet for
further investigation.   [_ _]
(c) Carry out careful inspection of all supporting hardware
and screw connections, including the eight vibration bracket
installations and the four safety rod brackets.  Using a
torque wrench, ensure that the accessible supporting screw
connections are secured and fixed with the correct torque
settings.  [_ _]
NOTE: Torque Settings
M10 = 37Nm
M12 = 65Nm
M16 = 150Nm
M20 = 300Nm      as per reference manual
in step 4
Bolts with Nylon washers should only be checked for
tightness. Do not torque as nylon washer get damaged
Do not torque anchor bolts in tunnel roof. Check for
tightness only.
(d) If any non-conforming items are found, record in the
"Work Done" area of the job sheet and rectify immediately
where possible to the requirements of the Witt & Sohn <(>,<)>
Operations and Maintenance Manual , Certificate 18.
(M-STG-VE-29047).   This inspection is carried out
externally via the inlet and exhaust ends using a
torch.  [_ _]
(e) Remove cover to motor junction box and check the cable
connections visually for tightness and evidence of
overheating.
8.  Lubrication
(a) Release the key operated EMERGENCY STOP button, restart
fan  locally.
(b) Regrease bearings using grease gun on nipples onside of
fan with  Mobilith SHC220 (TF000021) grease, 10 pumps of
hand grease gun per grease nipple.
Note:  Lubrication should be carried out between 3,000
and 4,000 hours running time when access is available.
Do not over grease.    [_ _]
(c) Stop fan using local EMERGENCY STOP button
(d) Release the EMERGENCY STOP button using a Key.  (Remove
the key)   [_ _]
9.  Equipment Room Control Panel.
(a) Switch fan REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to REMOTE to
enable control at panel
(b) Carry out visual internal and external inspection of the
control panel for damage evidence of insect infestation<(>,<)>
ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as
required).  [_ _]
(c) Check cable connections visually for tightness and signs
of overheating and inspect electrical control
equipment [_ _]
(d) Start fan with START pushbutton on panel and leave
running for approximately 5 minutes
(e) Check ammeter at electrical panel to verify fan is
operating within current limits FLC 100A.  [_ _]
(f ) Using an infra red thermometer check the temperature of
the connections and power cables to the motor.   Record in
the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet if the temperature
recorded is more that 10º to 15º C above ambient.   [_ _]
(g) Record the "hours run" from the Jet Fan hour run meter
on the panel door in the "Work Done"" area of the job
sheet.   [_ _]
Note:  Hour run meters are on the control panels for
non-reversing fans only.
Reversing fans hour run readings are obtainable
from the PMCS screens in the control room
10. Return the LOCAL/OFF/REMOTE switch to the OFF position and
the AUTO/OFF/MAN  fan selector switch to the AUTO
position.   [_ _]
11. Advise the Traffic control room operator that control of the
fan is returned to the control room.    [_ _]
12. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable<(>,<)>
Leaky  Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework<(>,<)>
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and bring to the attention
of the Team Leader Electrical or his representative.
13. Notify control room on completion of work.
14. Enter the hours run for the jet fan into the Plant item
screen, then select the usage tab.

operation of the heater. [_ _]

with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.

controller.   [_ _]

03 M Inspect of Liebert AC units accessed via the EE Tunnel.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.   [_ _]
2. Access is via the Emergency Egress Tunnel from the entry
adjacent to the Burnley Vent Station stack.
(a) Arrange for the control room to start Supply Air fan
ESFP01. ESFP01 is the Supply Air for the Emergency Egress
Tunnel.
(b) Arrange for the control room to switch on the Emergency
Egress Tunnel lighting prior to entering the tunnel.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
shown on unit is consistent with new setpoint and
verify temperature is consistent with ambient
(+ or - 1 deg) using portable  thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm.   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary.  Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.
4.6. Restart  unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage
problems.  Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0 Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record the
results on form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347.
Ensure the form Equipment Room Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347
is returned to the Electrical Electronics Supervisor or his
representative.  Raise a new job for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters  in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Supervisor or his representative and raise a
new job for any outstanding  repairs.
9.0 Notify the control room on completion of the job and arrange
for the control room to switch off the emergeny egress
tunnel lighting as well as the supply air fan.

03 M Inspection of Thytec UPS system in WL TSH's
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
3. Refer to Manual: Thytec 30KVA UPS 12 Pulse
[ M-MCL-ME20000/20011 ] Manual.
4. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
5. At By-pass Switch (Wall Mounted)
(a) Press the TRANSFER button, on the UPS control panel, to
transfer the UPS  to the by-pass mode.
(b) Wait until the amber By-Pass led is illuminated.
(c) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet<(>,<)>
to the OFF position, to isolate the batteries.
(d) Press the OFF button, on the UPS control panel,  to
switch OFF the UPS unit.
(e) Switch the EXTERNAL BY-PASS switch (wall mounted above
UPS) to the BY-PASS position.  The UPS unit is now
by-passed.
WARNING: DO NOT USE THE INTERNAL BY-PASS SWITCH, AS THIS
SWITCH IS NOT INTERLOCKED.
(f) Switch the EXTERNAL by-pass switch to the NORMAL
position.
(g) Press the ON button, on the UPS control panel.  An UPS
start is initiated.
(h) Wait for INV. ON green led to illuminate.
(i) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet<(>,<)>
to the ON position to connect the batteries to the UPS.
(j) After about 30 secconds the BYPASS led will go OFF and
the INVERTER led will illuminate, indicating the load is
on the inverter.  A noticeable change in the operating
noise of the UPS will also indicate the change of load.
6. UPS Unit.
(a) Do not operate the EMERGENCY STOP push button, on the
front of the UPS Panel, unless in extreme emergency, as
damage to the UPS electrical equipment can occur.
(b) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.
[_ _]
(c) Remove the air filter, clean and re-install, ( replace
air filter if necessary )   [_ _]
(d) Check for air flow above grills on top of the panel.
( with fan in operation )   [_ _]
(e) Visual Inspection of capacitors for any oil leaks.  [_ _]
(f) Switch OFF the ""MAIN UPS"" electrical supply.  The load
should then transfer to the UPS, supplying from the
batteries.
(g) Check and monitor, on the UPS display, the load current
(max. 42A per phase 30kVA UPS or max 55A per phase 40kVA
UPS).
(h) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
(i) Leave the UPS supply the load for at least ten minutes.
(j) Switch the Normal electricity supply isolator to the ON
position.  The load will revert to the Normal power
supply.
7. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
Batteries.
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on Panel
Door, is in the upright position and is not tripped.
[_ _]
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 270V. )    [_ _]
8. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the "" Work
Done "" area of the job sheet.
9.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
Works completed as above work plan
Neil Cottee/Thytec 16/9/14
"

03 M Maint of Gantry Tolling Equipment
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Carry out the three monthly planned maintenance defined in
the CML RSE Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
M-MCL-ET-1225.

3. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment
and or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.  Adhere to safety
instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 "Working on Gantry Structures
4. Notify Control Room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
5. Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
Preventative Maintenance No.0301
When carrying out the cleaning of VDC sensors (in 0301),
inspect the area around the connectors for evidence of
corrosion.
If corrosion is evident, then clean the area as described
below.
Where cleaning is to be also carried out, use extreme care
to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter any
connectors.
The Fibre Optic Connector is to be only removed on the
12 Monthly  Cycle (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
Prior to removing any connector or cover socket, clean
surface corrosion and deposits from around connectors,
socket covers and the surrounding surfaces use a tooth
brush to assist if necessary.
Remove the three socket covers (remove only if possible
using fingers) and apply a light spray of silicon to
the three (3) socket covers, replacing and exercising
the threads.
With all caps and plugs re-installed apply a light spray of
silicon to the area around the plugs and caps.
Check for silicon overspray on the VDC sensor window and
clean if necessary.
Where connectors or socket covers cannot be easily removed,
record details in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and
report the fact to the Team Leader or his representative.
0301: Check image quality and
,,,, alignment with CML Clean glass regardless of image.
,,,, Lubrication of mounting bracket carried out on removal
,,,, only.  Lightly spray with lubricant.
0302: Clean external glass of front and rear VR sensors.
Inspect mounting brackets and lubricate as required.
Ensure pins are cleaned and lubricated using silicon
spray prior to installing.
0303: Check VR Illuminator that there are less than 10%
defective IR LEDs,Advice CML if suspect below 10%
0304: Clean front surface of TRX, inspect mtg bracket and
lubricate as required
0305: Clean outside of glass cover of VDC, Replace failed
lamps, Lubricate arms as required.
Inspect VDC arm locating pins and chains. Record any
works required and report any equipment that needs
repair.
0306: Road Markers: Inspect for clarity & Cleanliness.( High ,,
,, contrast between marker & road). (If road markers need
to be changed, inform the Team Leader.)
0307: Clean the glass of VSS sensor
0308: Inspect Distribution Cabinet for loose or damaged   ,,
cables. Clean cabinet for insects or moisture.
6. Visually inspect the tape condition across the joint in the road
7. Record in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet any
outstanding works requiring further attention.  Create a
new Job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative of the outstanding works.
Record the New job number in the "Work Done" area of this
job sheet and in the "Related Job" field of both jobs.
8. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
Shelter."

(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing.  This will prevent movement
of the PTZ .  [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation.
Surface insect spray may be applied if necessary to the
housing exterior but must not be applied to the interior
of the housing or to the housing glass.  If ingress of
moisture or insect infestation is evident then carry out
steps (d) and (e).  [_ _]

mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X  cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater
thermostat (HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the
operation of the heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
8. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
re-instate the 240V power supply to the PTZ
controller.   [_ _]
9. Notify the control room on completion and check the PTZ for
full movement and pre-programmed positions.  If camera fails
to respond press the reset button on the PT 300 and wait 2
minutes then check again.  [_ _]

01 M L1 Inspect of fire doors within the OMB
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. This work is to be carried out by suitably qualified personnel.
2. This work is for the OMB building.
3. Inspect the OMB fire doors to AS 1851.7 Type 1 inspection.  The
inspection shall consist of
an examination of the condition of the door set and a check that it
is operating satisfactorily.
In particular, the following routine should be followed.
3.1 Inspect for any remedial work that is outstanding and unfinished andrecord
works to be
completed in the comments field.
3.2 Remove any obstructions or non-approved devices such as wedges,
heavy objects or
hooks that are used to hold the door open.
3.3 Check that the door and all it's components, hardware and functions
are correct.
3.4 While the door is open, check that all screws are firm in the
hinges, latch set faceplate,
striking plate and the door closer body and bracket.
3.5 Inspect that the door identification data notice, required by the
regulatory authority is firmly
attached.  The notice is generally mounted on the door edge and
onthe door frame.
3.6 Check the closing and latching action (on the closing), and that
thedoor stopping action
(fully open limit) is functioning (on the opening).
3.7 With the door closed, check that the leaf is a reasonably even fit
in the frame.
4. Record the result of the inspection for each door on ""Operations
& Maintenance Building
Fire Door Inspection"" form TMF-3012-OP-0279
5. (a) Check the fire hydrant at the property front entrance for damage
,leakage.   [_ _]
(b) Trim plants and foliage to allow identification and access to
the hydrant.   [_ _]
6. Record the details of any further works required in the ""Work
Done""area of the Job Sheet.
7. Raise a new  job sheet for any corrective action that is required.
P2 - Medium Priority."

03 M Inspection of WIM & TCS Systems on the SL Tollway
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane.
2. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating,
symbolic worker, lateral shift, vehicle arrow board and cones
as per Work Instruction , Traffic Control TMI-3012-OP 0002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
3. Reference: Central Weighing Australasia, Roadside Maintenance
Training Manual, Doc. PL-MCL-TM-1631, Rev 0 and for operation
of laptop computer,  Weigh-in-Motion & Counting Stations,
Operator's  Manual for WIMS Front End Computer,
Doc.   PL-MCL-TM-1630, Rev A, Section 3 Telecom- DOS
operator's Manual . (Status Information 6.1.2 page 145)
4. At SL WIM/TCS Systems 04A control cabinet, check the
following;
(a) Internal and external condition of the cabinet.   [_ _]
(b) Check wiring for tightness and for any evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
(c) Check that the Tx and Rx LEDs (on the modem) flash at
least each minute.  [_ _]
(d) Check that the battery charger LED is ON.  [_ _]
(e) Using a vacuum cleaner, clean the cabinet
interior.   [_ _]
5. Use laptop computer to carry out the following:
(a) Plug the 9 pin serial lead from the computer to the
controller input/output board.
(b) Switch ON the computer.
(c) Click on Telecom WIMS Icon
(d) Select Comms by pressing the 'C' Key
(e) Select LOGGER/ONLINE, then press Enter.
(f) Check that the laptop computer communicates with the
logger correctly.  [_ _]
(g) Confirm the logger parameters, shown in the CURRENT
SITE (MCL) on page no. 1, area match those listed in
the document  Site Configuration and Set up Details
(stored cabinet).  [_ _]
(h) Press key Page Down to go to screen page 2. [_ _]
(i) Record on the form attached loop frequencies and weigh
responses.  [_ _]
(j) Record value of Power Status on page 2 of the
computer screen.  The battery should read approx 13
volts. [_ _]
(k) When a truck crosses the sensors check on page 2
(computer screen) that all sensors, in each lane are
operating correctly (an asterisk will appear momentarily
alongside the appropriate loops as the truck crosses).
This check should only be done with trucks and not cars
(weighing sites only), as all sensors may not be displayed
for cars.  [_ _]
(l) Select LOGGER/OFFLINE, then press Enter
(m) Select 'Quit', then press Enter
(n) Then select 'Quit' again, press Enter again.
(o) Select 'Yes' to quit Telecom system.
6. Switch computer OFF and then unplug the 9 pin serial
lead. [_ _]
7. From the side of the road, visually check the conditions of
the road sensors, for condition, no (loose bolts) metal
vibration or exposed wires visible. [_ _]
8. Repeat steps 4 to 7 for WIM/TCS System 04B   [_ _].
9. Repeat steps 4 to 7 for WIM/TCS System 04C   [_ _].
10. Repeat steps 4 to 7 for WIM/TCS System 05A & B   [_ _].
11. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
12. Notify the control room  prior to departure."

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of HV system for operation & Faults
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor
under the supervision of an electrical/electronics
technician.
3. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carried out and that
(a) The General Section of the above job has been completed
and
(b) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring all cabling, connections and
installation meet the AS 3000 standard.
4. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each
Circuit Breaker and Isolator.  [_ _]
5. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations
including date of test, ground and weather conditions are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an
earthing resistance test in accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for
tightness of connections, and the condition of system
components e.g. Earthing electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
6. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance
and cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are
clean and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion.  Clean and tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal and battery voltage and
battery temperature prior to commencing the test as
well as at completion of test.  Where the battery or
terminal voltage at completion of test is less than
80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of it's serviceable life and
replacement options should be recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i)  Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for
damage etc.
7. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Related Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
8. At Substations fill-in the log book.   [_ _]

01 M Inspection & test running of the WL TSH generators
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode.   [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. Refer to reference manual Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
5.   (a) Check that the generator was left in  "AUTO" [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuel and water.   [_ _]
(c) Check oil level.   [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates.  [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ).   [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts   [_ _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the "Work Done" area
of the job sheet. [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap, as the gauge could be
misleading.  [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry.  [_ _]
6. Reference manual, Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP
Electrical Pty Ltd Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI
[M-MCL-ME-20016]
7.  (a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch on the generator
DC panel to "" RUN "" let the engine run for at least 5
minutes, then turn the "" RUN / OFF / AUTO "" Switch
back to "" AUTO ""
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from "" AUTOMATIC CONTROL"" to ""EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST
"" run the generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations.
[_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature.   [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back
to " AUTOMATIC CONTROL" the generator will continue to
run for about 8 minutes before stopping.   [_ _]
(g) Record the hours run, from the hours run meter,  in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet.
8.  (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises.  [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages  [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet.  [_ _]
9. Fill in the Generator Log Book and record anything outside
normal parameters in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet.  Raise a new job for any works requiring further
repairs.  Priority High P1.
10.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
11.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
12.Record the Hours run in Mainpac under "Plant" use RH mouse
click then select "Open"      then select "Meter
Readings" in edit mode add the Meter Reading for the
appropriate TSH Generator.
"

12 M Routine Maint. of Burnley Vent Station Fan
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
WARNINGS:
1. CHECKS SHOULD NOT BE CARRIED OUT IF MORE THAN 2 FANS ARE OPERATING IN
THE SECONDARY VENT STATION.
2. NO PERSON SHALL ENTER THE ACCESS AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM
ALONE.
TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT AT ALL TIMES WHEN WORK IS BEING
CARRIED OUT IN THE AIRLOCK OR VENT STATION
3. TAKE HEED OF NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS.
1. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3,  the ventilation
rooms and to interrupt
operations.
2.  Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.  Maintain
radiocontact at all times.
3.  Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
(M-STG-VE-26058)
4. Access to the Burnley ventilation station is through a locked airlock(Key2-LV)
on the
stairway  adjacent to the south west corner of the Burnley vent
stack.
Access to substation 3 is via external doors adjacent to the Burnley
Portal.
5. Ensure the 3 monthly check of the fans, carried out at the PMCS,
havebeen completed.
6. At the MCC in Substation No 3
Select one axial fan to be operational while the maintenance is being
carried out on
the other fans.  The fan selected can be any fan other than the fan
to be maintained
(preferably a fan located the furthest from the fan to be
maintained).
(a) If the selected fan is not running, then have the TCR start the
selected fan.
(b) Isolate the remaining non-operational axial fans, by switching
the AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switches to the OFF position.  Carry out the
electrical isolation procedures
as defined in the Work Instruction TMI -3012-OP - 0103,  Low
Voltage Isolation
Procedures.
7.  Electrical checks in Substation No 3
(a)  Measure the insulation resistance of the stator windings and
record in the ""Work Done""
section of the Job Sheet.  [_ _]
(b)  Measure the current of the anti-condensation. Heater current
isapprox. 1 amp.
(c)  Visually inspect both internally and externally, the control
panel for damage, corrosion
as well as the ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as
required)
8. (a) Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after equalizing
pressure in airlock.
WARNING: HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION SHOULD BE WORN IN
VENTILATION
FAN CHAMBER
(b) Check CO levels in fan room through doorway before entering and
at intervals during
fan checks.
(c)  WARNING:  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1
METRE
OF AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD.  Airflow strength 35 km/h.
9. Static Fan Checks for each fan.
(a) Confirm that both the fan and motor are electrically and
mechanically isolated prior to
commencing any work on the fan or the motor.
(b) Enter the fan inlet cowl via the entry cowl safety grill hatch.
(c) Examine the impeller for
(i) Dirt and foreign matter on the blades (clean if required)
[_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade tips   [_ _]
(ii) Wear or damage on the blade leading edges   [_ _]
(iv) Loose bolts and or blade fixings at the hub   [_ _]
(d) Examine the electrical cable for security of fixings, damage due
to fraying, scuffing or
similar and for damage at locations where the cables penetrate
panels or
housings.    [_ _]
(e) Check any grease discharged from the motor bearings, since the
last lubrication is not
excessive.   [_ _]
(f ) Examine the discharged grease for any noticeable colour change.
Ensure that the
grease nipples are clean.  [_ _]
(g)  Inspect the cable connections to the motor for evidence of
overheating.  [_ _]
(h) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and heater
windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the motorwindings
and the
winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) Remove supply lines to the motor and carry out an
insulation resistance test
on the motor windings, Between phase winding to phase
winding and between
each phase winding and earth.  Record results in the Work
Done area of the
Job sheet.
(vii) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
the heater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(viii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(x)  Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
""Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
(i) On leaving the fan inlet cowl grill hatch, replace the hatch
cover immediately.  [_ _]
(j) Manually check the operation of the Rotork actuator and
associated linkages that
operate the exit dampers, use the local control panel switch.
(k ) Remove any mechanical interlocks blocking the fan operation.
[__]
10. Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) When the Static Fan Checks are complete, return to substation
3and remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then
removethe fan motor isolation
at the MCC.
Note:  Ensure that all non-operational fans are isolated, in
accordance
TMI-3012-SA-0103, and that the only fan not
isolated, is the fan to be maintained.
(b) Return the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF position
to the AUTO position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room and have TCR start the fan,
thatis being maintained.
Note: The motor must not be started more that four times in
an hour.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
(e) Lubricate the motor bearings with fresh grease, while the motor
running.
DE = 100 gr / NDE - 120 gr  Use Shell Stamina RL2 grease or
equivalent only.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the bearings
using the retrieval
system.  Examine the grease for changes of colour.  [_ _]
(g) Monitor the fan and motor for abnormal noises.      [_ _]
(h) Stop the fan motor using Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.

equalizing the
differential pressures.
12. In Substation No 3

then remove the
motor isolation for all the fans at the MCC.  Return all
theREMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switches to the REMOTE position,  and the
AUTO/OFF/MAN  fan selector
switches to the AUTO position.

13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done' sectionof
the Job Sheet.
14. Notify the control room on the completion of the job.

hasoccurred requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.

position.

position and start
the fan.
