03 M Inspection of Thytec UPS system in WL TSH's
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
3. Refer to Manual: Thytec 30KVA UPS 12 Pulse
[ M-MCL-ME20000/20011 ] Manual.
4. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
5. At By-pass Switch (Wall Mounted)
(a) Press the TRANSFER button, on the UPS control panel, to
transfer the UPS  to the by-pass mode.
(b) Wait until the amber By-Pass led is illuminated.
(c) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet<(>,<)>
to the OFF position, to isolate the batteries.
(d) Press the OFF button, on the UPS control panel,  to
switch OFF the UPS unit.
(e) Switch the EXTERNAL BY-PASS switch (wall mounted above
UPS) to the BY-PASS position.  The UPS unit is now
by-passed.
WARNING: DO NOT USE THE INTERNAL BY-PASS SWITCH, AS THIS
SWITCH IS NOT INTERLOCKED.
(f) Switch the EXTERNAL by-pass switch to the NORMAL
position.
(g) Press the ON button, on the UPS control panel.  An UPS
start is initiated.
(h) Wait for INV. ON green led to illuminate.
(i) Turn the battery circuit breaker, on the battery cabinet<(>,<)>
to the ON position to connect the batteries to the UPS.
(j) After about 30 secconds the BYPASS led will go OFF and
the INVERTER led will illuminate, indicating the load is
on the inverter.  A noticeable change in the operating
noise of the UPS will also indicate the change of load.
6. UPS Unit.
(a) Do not operate the EMERGENCY STOP push button, on the
front of the UPS Panel, unless in extreme emergency, as
damage to the UPS electrical equipment can occur.
(b) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.
[_ _]
(c) Remove the air filter, clean and re-install, ( replace
air filter if necessary )   [_ _]
(d) Check for air flow above grills on top of the panel.
( with fan in operation )   [_ _]
(e) Visual Inspection of capacitors for any oil leaks.  [_ _]
(f) Switch OFF the ""MAIN UPS"" electrical supply.  The load
should then transfer to the UPS, supplying from the
batteries.
(g) Check and monitor, on the UPS display, the load current
(max. 42A per phase 30kVA UPS or max 55A per phase 40kVA
UPS).
(h) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 12.0
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will indicate
a battery fault. ]
(i) Leave the UPS supply the load for at least ten minutes.
(j) Switch the Normal electricity supply isolator to the ON
position.  The load will revert to the Normal power
supply.
7. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
Batteries.
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on Panel
Door, is in the upright position and is not tripped.
[_ _]
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 270V. )    [_ _]
8. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the "" Work
Done "" area of the job sheet.
9.Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10.Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
Works completed as above work plan
"

03 M Inspect & Clean TSH Equipment and Bldgs
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the
cleaning and inspections of the Building and Electrics<(>,<)>
prior to leaving the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum
Cleaner, Cloths, lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and
external lighting, Brooms, Rubbish bags, Filter material<(>,<)>
Ladders, Silicon Lubricant Spray, Rodent Bait Station
This job should be carried in conjunction with the Monthly
job at the Technical Shelters
A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the
electrical installations of Technical Shelters, as well the
cleaning, inspections and maintenance of the relevant
areas.
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( Technical Shelters TSH1-6, TSH10-14 )
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the relevant Technical
shelters.
2. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere<(>,<)>
use your senses of sight, smell and hearing to monitor any
abnormal events.  [_ _]
3. At Technical shelters, fill-in the log-book [_ _]
4. Check the interior and external lighting for operation<(>,<)>
including the operational tube within EXIT signs, replace
faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all
accessible equipment and components within all switchboards
and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of
ambient plus 10°C should be considered abnormal and must be
noted in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of
the abnormality. Raise a new job sheet for any corrective
action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all
cables, terminals, equipment and components  for evidence
of burn marks, unusual odours and overheating.  Record
anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job
Sheet and raise a new jobsheet for any corrective action.
Ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of
the abnormality.  [_ _]
7. While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering, arcing etc.  [_ _]
8. Inspect the surges diverters where applicable, and either
replace spent surge diverters when less than 80% or raise a
new Job Sheet for works to be carried out.   [_ _]
9. At Technical Shelters,  visually inspect external Lightning
Protection System connections for damage and or corrosion.
Record anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the
Job Sheet and raise a new jobsheet for any corrective
action.  Ensure the Team Leader or his representative is
informed of the abnormality.  [_ _]
10.Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware<(>,<)>
gaskets, seals and escutcheons for serviceability and
general operation, lubricate as required.  Carry out
any required repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any
outstanding actions.  [_ _]
11.Inspect single line drawings for legibility.  Record
details of drawings requiring replacement in the ""Work
Done"" area and report to the Team leader or his
representative.
12.Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating<(>,<)>
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
13.Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally
for dust, grime and condensation, clean enclosures of any
accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
14.Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of
obstructions.  Clean or replace filters as required.  [_ _]
15.Inspect systems, mounted within the building or room(s)<(>,<)>
for faulty indicators, faulty meters, damaged switches and
buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding
actions.   [_ _]
16.PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect  the PLC status and error indicators.
Indicators found to indicate abnormal conditions are
to be logged in the ""Work Done"" of the Job Sheet and
a new job sheet raised to invetigate and correct the
error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g.
plug connections, screw connections for security.
[_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and
module security screws are not loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush, ensure the
enclosure and PLC modules are cleaned of accumulated
dust and debris.  [_ _]
17.Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for
accumulated debris, evidence of water accumulation.
18.Inspect the door alarm switches at all external doors for
operation and security.  Check with the Traffic Control
Room Operator to confirm the receipt of an alarm.  Repair
faulty of defective switches.  Record details of
outstanding defects in the Work Done area of the Job
Sheet.  [_ _]
19.Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the
Work Done area of the Job Sheet and Inform the Team
Leader or his representative of any corrective actions.
Include in the Related Job field of the new and this
job, the job number number of the alternate Job.   [_ _]
C. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of
moisture ingress.  Inspect for source of any water.  Record
any details in the Work Done area of the job sheet and
inform the Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]

12 M Inspection of Cast Resin HV Transformers
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All work on High Voltage equipment must be carried out in
accordance with Transfield's procedure number TMI-3012-SA-0102
High Voltage Safety Work Instructions.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. (Cast Resin Dry Type Transformers 1A, 1B, 2A,2B, 3A, 3B, 4A,
4B, 5A & 5B)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to
be recorded and reported to the Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) Examine and clean all bushings, insulators, terminals,
cable connections, for partial discharge, ingress of
moisture or damage.
(b) Inspect Operation of the Winding temperature sensor.
Carry out functional testing to ensure correct Alarming
and trip operation via the PMCS to the Traffic Control
Room.
(c) Check tightness (Torque test) of all earthing and cable
connections (MEN, Bushings and tank) and inspect for
evidence of overheating of broken strands. Tighten
connections where necessary.
(d) Inspect transformer coils, core and frame, for evidence
of corrosion, dirt, or foreign material buildup.  Clean
coils , core and frame and treat and recoat any surface
rust spots.
3. Record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet, inspection
results requiring further corrective actions.  Raise a new
Job Sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative.  Include in the Releated Job
field of the new and this job, the job number of the
alternate Job.   [_ _]
The following torque settings are:
Connections of HV connectors - Connections tightening torque
on the HV terminal and the tapping link bars
Bolts             Tightening Torque Nm
M8                    9.8Nm
M10                  19.6Nm
M12                  34.3Nm
M14                  58.8Nm
Connections of LV connectors - Connection tightening torque
for the LV bars (Both Nut and Bolts).
M8                  12.25Nm
M10                 24.5Nm
M12                 44.0Nm
M14                 68.6Nm
M16                 98.0Nm

03 M Insp of Liebert AC units accessed via the Mezzanine Lvl
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job
2. Access to both ERE 03 and ERW 05 is via the Grant Street
stairwell.  Both equipment rooms are adjacent to Substation
1.  Access from Grant Street is via the mezzanine floor, then
down a ladder to the Domain Tunnel Walkway and then,
10 metres along the walkway to Substation 1 entrance.
Prior to walking along the walkway, be aware of the traffic
conditions and take appropriate precautions.
Use a ladder to climb over the smoke ducts.  DO NOT GO
THROUGH THE SMOKE DUCTS.
ACU Air Conditioning Units are located in the respective
equipment rooms, while the condenser units are mounted on the
Mezzanine level above the equipment rooms.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm.   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary   Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.   [_ _]
4.6. Restart  unit and set for remote operation.   [_ _]
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean the condenser coils if required using compressed
air.   [_ _]
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form  Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347.  Ensure the form Equipment Room
Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347 is returned to the Electrical
Electronics Supervisor or his representative.  Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done  section of the job sheet and
report to the Team Leader or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9.0 Notify the control room on completion of the job.

12 M Lev 2 Inspect of Sub 3B HV system for operatn & Faults
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
All TS procedures in TMI-3012-SA-0102 High Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.
1. Notify the TCRO prior to commencing this job.
2. The following work is to be carried by the sub-contractor under the
supervision of an
electrical/electronics technician.
3. Refer to Manual ""Merlin Gerin Masterpact Instruction Notice""
M-STG-EL-24030
4. Ensure that the Three monthly HV electric inspection has been
carriedout and that
(a) The  ""General Section "" of the above job has been completed and
(b) The number of operation cycles of the circuit breakers has been
recorded and
(c) Inspect the earthing conductors, earthing electrodes and
connections ensuring
all cabling, connections and installation meet the AS 3000
standard.
5. (Schneider SM6 Switchboard, Circuit Breakers and Isolators)
(a) Read and record the number of operation cycles for each of the
circuit breakers
and Isolators.  [_ _]
6. (Substation Earthing Systems)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations including
dateof test, ground and
weather conditions are to be recorded and reported to the
Electrical/electronics team
leader or his representative.
(a) At each substation and HV switchroom, carry out an earthing
resistance test in
accordance with AS3000.
(b) Examine each earthing system in turn and check for tightness of
connections,
and the condition of system components e.g. Earthing
electrodes, earthing
connections, conductors etc.
7. (RMU Battery Supply and Chargers)
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
recorded and reported
to the Electrical/electronics team leader or his representative.
(a) Inspect the battery compartment for damage, appearance and
cleanliness.
(b) Check that the charger is functional.
(c) Check the battery voltage on float charge.
(d) Check that the battery compartment ventilation vents are clean
and clear.
(e) Check the external battery connections for tightness and
corrosion.  Clean and
tighten as required.
(f) Check battery cases and or covers are not cracked or
distorted.
(g) Carry out a performance test of the battery bank.
(i) Discharge the batteries, via a load, over a two hour
period. Record both terminal
and battery voltage and battery temperature prior to
commencing the test as well
as at completion of test.  Where the battery or terminal
voltage at completion of test
is less than 80% of nominal voltage, then the battery is
approaching the end of
it's serviceable life and replacement options should be
recommended.
(h) Check and record the on-load charger output (Voltage and
current)
(i)  Check the charger electrical connections and wiring for damage
etc.
8. (Capacitor Banks at Sub 3 (Indoor))
The result of all tests, inspections and observations are to be
recorded and reported
to the Electrical/electronics team leader or his representative.
(a) Carry out a thorough visual inspection, record and report any
damage.
(b) Visually inspect the outside and inside of the enclosure for
signs of corrosion on
capacitor cans and frames.  Clean and remove accumulated dirt
and dust.
(c) Visually inspect all earthing and cabling connections, check for
signs of overheating
or broken strands.  Check and tighten connections as required.
9. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet, inspection
resultsrequiring
further corrective actions.  Raise a new job sheet for any
outstanding works and
notify the Team Leader or his representative.  Include in the
""Related Job"" field
of the new and this job, the job number of  the alternate Job.   [_
_]
10. At the substations fill-in the log book.  [_ _]
"

(a) Visually inspect the telephone for graffiti, damage and
or insect infestation.
(b) Clean the telephone of grime and residues, use spray-on
Nifty and a clean cloth.
(c) Test the operation of the telephone with the control
room.  Using the Emergency Roadside telephone, contact
the Traffic Control Room and confirm operation of the
phone communication then have the control room call back
to the ERT to check the reverse operation.
4. For each ERT
(a) record the result of the inspection
(b) that the ERT has been cleaned and
(c) the result of the communication test
for each telephone on the attached form METS Inspection
(Monthly) - Southern Link Burnley Tunnel  (Lane 1) Form
No. TMF-3012-OP-0073.
5. Record the details of any further corrective actions that are
required in the comments area of the form.
6. Notify the control room on the completion of the Job.
7. Return the completed job sheet as well as the form METS
(Inspection (Monthly) - Southern Link Burnley Tunnel
(Lane 1) Form No. TMF-3012-OP-0073 to the Electrical /
Electronics Team Leader or his representative.
8. The Electrical ./ Electronics Team leader or his
representative is to raise a new job sheet for any corrective
actions required.

mechanical damage, water ingress, condensation or insect
infestation. Also check inside cabinets for tripped circuit
breakers, disconnected wires, burn marks from excessive heat.
[_ _]

rusted areas, rusted nuts or bolts. Cleans with wire brush
and spray with Cold Gal or equivalent. This should be
done with care and to avoid overspray. [_ _]

dirt and clean with Windex or equivalent  and clean rags
if required.[_ _]

of the Job Sheet and raise new Job Sheet if required.

03 M Insp of Liebert AC units accessed via the Mezzanine Lvl
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job
2. Access to both ERE 03 and ERW 05 is via the Grant Street
stairwell.  Both equipment rooms are adjacent to Substation
1.  Access from Grant Street is via the mezzanine floor, then
down a ladder to the Domain Tunnel Walkway and then,
10 metres along the walkway to Substation 1 entrance.
Prior to walking along the walkway, be aware of the traffic
conditions and take appropriate precautions.
Use a ladder to climb over the smoke ducts.  DO NOT GO
THROUGH THE SMOKE DUCTS.
ACU Air Conditioning Units are located in the respective
equipment rooms, while the condenser units are mounted on the
Mezzanine level above the equipment rooms.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm.   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary   Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.   [_ _]
4.6. Restart  unit and set for remote operation.   [_ _]
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean the condenser coils if required using compressed
air.   [_ _]
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form  Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347.  Ensure the form Equipment Room
Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347 is returned to the Electrical
Electronics Supervisor or his representative.  Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done  section of the job sheet and
report to the Team Leader or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9.0 Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Maint of Gantry Tolling Equipment
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Carry out the three monthly planned maintenance defined in
the CML RSE Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
M-MCL-ET-1225.
2. Perimeter access gate at technical shelter key required.
3. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment
and or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.  Adhere to safety
instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 "Working on Gantry Structures
4. Notify Control Room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
5. Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
Preventative Maintenance No.0301
When carrying out the cleaning of VDC sensors (in 0301),
inspect the area around the connectors for evidence of
corrosion.
If corrosion is evident, then clean the area as described
below.
Where cleaning is to be also carried out, use extreme care
to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter any
connectors.
The Fibre Optic Connector is to be only removed on the
12 Monthly  Cycle (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
Prior to removing any connector or cover socket, clean
surface corrosion and deposits from around connectors,
socket covers and the surrounding surfaces use a tooth
brush to assist if necessary.
Remove the three socket covers (remove only if possible
using fingers) and apply a light spray of silicon to
the three (3) socket covers, replacing and exercising
the threads.
With all caps and plugs re-installed apply a light spray of
silicon to the area around the plugs and caps.
Check for silicon overspray on the VDC sensor window and
clean if necessary.
Where connectors or socket covers cannot be easily removed,
record details in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and
report the fact to the Team Leader or his representative.
0301: Check image quality and
,,,, alignment with CML Clean glass regardless of image.
,,,, Lubrication of mounting bracket carried out on removal
,,,, only.  Lightly spray with lubricant.
0302: Clean external glass of front and rear VR sensors.
Inspect mounting brackets and lubricate as required.
Ensure pins are cleaned and lubricated using silicon
spray prior to installing.
0303: Check VR Illuminator that there are less than 10%
defective IR LEDs,Advice CML if suspect below 10%
0304: Clean front surface of TRX, inspect mtg bracket and
lubricate as required
0305: Clean outside of glass cover of VDC, Replace failed
lamps, Lubricate arms as required.
Inspect VDC arm locating pins and chains. Record any
works required and report any equipment that needs
repair.
0306: Road Markers: Inspect for clarity & Cleanliness.( High ,,
,, contrast between marker & road). (If road markers need
to be changed, inform the Team Leader.)
0307: Clean the glass of VSS sensor
0308: Inspect Distribution Cabinet for loose or damaged   ,,
cables. Clean cabinet for insects or moisture.
6. Record in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet any
outstanding works requiring further attention.  Create a
new Job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative of the outstanding works.
Record the New job number in the "Work Done" area of this
job sheet and in the "Related Job" field of both jobs.
7. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
Shelter."

12 M Minor inspect & test run of the SL TSH generators
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. The generator minor service ""TYPE A"" , as set out in the
Cummins Maintenance Report, shall be carried out by the
sub-contractor on the generator.
2. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
3. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
4. Minor Service TYPE A Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's
Manual 960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012].
The sub-contractor shall carry out the service as per items
listed on the maintenance report column A and test as per
paragraph 5.
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch on the generator DC
panel to RUN let the engine run for at least 5 minutes,
then turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch back to AUTO
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from AUTOMATIC CONTROL to EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST run the
generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared,
and that there are no unusual noises or vibrations. [_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switch board back
to AUTOMATIC CONTROL the generator will continue to run
for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6. Record the hours run for each generator (from the hour run
meter) and record in the Mainpac Hours Run system for the
appropriate machine on the Plant Usage Tab.
7. Fill in the Generator Log Book
8. Record in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
(a) Sub-contractors Maintenance Report No  [________]
(b) Sub-contractors  Field Report No  [__________]
(c) Hours run ( from the hour run meter )  [___________]
9. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

12 M Clean silt out of lake
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Coordinate the planning and completion of other jobs that can be
carriedout whilst the lake is empty.
1. Organise front end loader and tip trucks for handling and
removal of silt and debris from the site.
2. Arrange for the collection of soil samples and the disposal
of the silt and debris to a suitable waste disposal site.
3. Notify the Control room prior to commencing this job.
4. Refer to Work Instruction ORNAMENTAL LAKE MAINTENANCE,
TMI-3012-OP-0024.
WARNING: BE AWARE OF SHARPS AND OTHER HAZARDOUS MATERIALS
THROUGHOUT WORK SITE.
5. Check and monitor the water table level in pits 1, 2, 3 & 4
(Lake can only be drained when the water table is below
200mm) over two consecutive days.  Record the results on
form GROUND WATER  LEVEL MONITOR - TMF-3012-OP-0249.
If the readings are over 200mm do not proceed with draining
the lake, only proceed to draining the lake when the levels
less than 200mm are obtained over two consecutive days.
6. Check the weep holes, at the base of concrete batters, of
creek lining upstream of lake for indication of ground water
flows.
7. Diversion of Creek
(a) Open flap valve, to the Ornamental Lake By-pass
Diversion (Removal of silt and debris may be required).
(b) Place stop log (entry) across entry to the lake.
(c) Check the water of the diversion at the diversion
outflow into the Moonee Ponds Creek.  Ensure the water
flow is unrestricted.
(d) Check to look at the downstream end to ensure water        ,,
backflow considered and can be controlled. Contact ,,     ,,
Melbourne water for assistance as required.
8. Draining the Lake
(a) Thoroughly clean the outflow area of algae prior to
accessing the stop logs (Outflow).
(b) Unbolt and remove the stop logs (outflow) of lake to
allow the lake to drain.
(c) Allow the silt to sufficiently drain, so as to not cause
a dust problem.  During the cleaning process monitor (at
least daily) the Ground Water in Pits 1, 2, 3 & 4 for
any increase of the ground water level.  If there is any
increase in the water level, either the job should be
postponed and the lake allowed to refill or measures put
in place to maintain the water level at a suitable level
below 200mm.
9. Remove all the silt and debris using a front end loader
fitted with rubber tyres.
10. Ensure the silt is disposed of within regulations.
11. Ensure pits 1, 2, 3 & 4 are cleaned of all silt and debris.
12. Refill the Lake
(a) On completion of all cleaning, replace stop logs
(outflow) and bolt into position.
(b) Remove stop log (entry) to allow the water to flow into
the lake.
(c) Close flap valve leading to the diversion pipe.
13. Clean all other litter and debris from around lake area.
14. Record anything outside normal parameters in the area of
the Job Sheet below.
15. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

04 M Insp/cln of  WL CCTV cams, EWP, emerg lane & Grdn bed"
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency
lane or entering the garden bed area.
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane Closure: Emergency Lane or on Garden Bed.
(d) Electrical Cabinet Location:
WL Tollway - exception CCAM 526 & 542 are behind the
noise wall.
SL Tollway - exception CCAM 914 & 915 are behind the
noise wall.
3. Set up the lane closure as per  Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and Translink  Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12, 13, 14, 143.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and the equipment mounted in the
cabinet is secure.  [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary.  [_ _]
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and are securely
fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.
(e) Check if surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is lit, if
not record the fact, for later replacement.  [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO  that picture vision is OK.  If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM 90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly  to the lead from the
camera).
Ensure the   co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT300
module and is secure.  [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V supply to the PTZ controller and disconnect
(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing.  This will prevent movement
of the PTZ .  [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation.
Surface insect spray may be applied if necessary to the
housing exterior but must not be applied to the interior
of the housing or to the housing glass.  If ingress of
moisture or insect infestation is evident then carry out
steps (d) and (e).  [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
Rain-X  cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater
thermostat (HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the
operation of the heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace

01 M Inspection of Substation 1 Supply Exhaust fans
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work and entering
the substations.
2. Refer to the reference manual, Operating and Maintenance
Manual for Mechanical Services at Melbourne Citylink Tunnels.
M-STG-ME-27400.
3. Access is via the Grant Street Stairwell, the mezzanine
floor, then down a ladder to the Domain Tunnel walkway then,
10 metres along the walkway to Substation 1 entrance.
Prior to walking along the walkway, be aware of the traffic
conditions and take appropriate precautions.  Use ladders to
climb over the smoke ducts on the mezzanine level.
DO NOT GO THROUGH THE SMOKE DUCTS.
The supply fan units are mounted on the mezzanine level above
the Substation.
4. Use the special key adjacent to air handling unit door to
obtain access to the fan unit.
The plenum light switch is on the outside of the cabinet.
WARNING.  THE ISOLATION SWITCH FOR THE FAN IS INSIDE THE
CABINET.  THE DOOR IS OPENED UNDER NEGATIVE PRESSURE.  USE THE
HANDLES PROVIDED TO PULL THE DOOR OPEN.  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART
OF THE BODY BETWEEN THE DOOR AND THE DOOR FRAME.
5. Work plan for SF-SS1-1
Note: The fan duty is changed weekly by the DDC. The procedure
below assumes SF-SS1-1 is the duty fan.
(a) At the switchboard, switch the fan OFF using the circuit
breaker in control panel (SUB1 A/C 1A MEB) or (SUB1 A/C
1B MEB).  Isolate and tag in accordance
TMI-3012-SA-01013, Low Voltage Safety Work
Instruction.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the fan housing, ducting and roof penetration
flashing for damage.    [_ _]
(c) Check the fan panels and fixings for damage, corrosion
and fixings that may be loose or missing.   [_ _]
(d) Check the fan cowls and grilles for debris blocking the
passage of air.   [_ _]
(e) Check the fan for free movement and any damage to the
blade.   [_ _]
(f) Check the fan belts and pulleys for serviceability and
tension.  Adjust or replace as necessary.   [_ _]
(g) Check the fan and motor mountings for security.  [_ _]
(h) Check and replace filters as required.
(9 off Air-Guard CP9-4-610x610x555mm and
9 off Air-Guard DP2-610x610x100mm)
(i) Switch the fan ON, using the circuit breaker in control
panel (SUB1 A/C 1A MEB)
or (SUB1 A/C 1B MEB).   [_ _]
(j) Check the fan for correct rotation.   [_ _]
(k) Check for fan and motor for unusual noises and
vibrations.   [_ _]
(l) Check the motor bearings, lubricate if required.   [_ _]
SF-SS1-2
(m) Switch OFF the circuit breaker for the fan SF-SS1-2 and
tagout in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-01013, Low Voltage
Safety Work Instruction.
(n) Inspect the fan housing, ducting and roof penetration
flashing for damage.    [_ _]
(o) Check the fan panels and fixings for damage, corrosion
and fixings that may be loose or missing.   [_ _]
(n) Check the fan cowls and grilles for debris blocking the
passage of air.   [_ _]
(p) Check the fan for free movement and any damage to the
blade.   [_ _]
(q) Check the fan belts and pulleys for serviceability and
tension.  Adjust or replace as necessary.     [_ _]
NOTE:  Belts must be replaced as matched set. Replaced all
belts if any belt needs replacement
(r) Check the fan and motor mountings for security.  [_ _]
(s) Check and replace filters as required.
(9 off Air-Guard CP9-4-610x610x555mm and
9 off Air-Guard DP2-610x610x100mm)
(t) Switch the fan SF-SS1-2 ON, using the circuit breaker in

(v) Check the fan for correct rotation.   [_ _]
(w) Check for fan and motor for unusual noises and
vibrations.   [_ _]
(x) Check the motor bearings, lubricate if required.   [_ _]
(y) Switch circuit breaker for fan SF-SS1-1 ON, fan SF-SS1-2
will go OFF and SF-SS1-1 will start.

03 M Inspect of Liebert A/C units at Substation 2.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Access to the Air Conditioning units in the Substation 2
building is via external doors into the SS02 building in Swan
Street. The condenser units are located on the roof of the
building.
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at  Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out,  and verify that
temperature shown on unit is consistent with new
setpoint and verify temperature is consistent with
ambient (+ or - 1 deg) using portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when new set
point is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm.   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary.   Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm.   [_ _]
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.   [_ _]
4.6. Restart  unit and set for remote operation.   [_ _]
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1.  Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean the condenser coils, if required using compressed
air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the Equipment room and
equipment etc,  in the Work Done section of the job sheet
and report to the Team Leader or his representative and
raise a new job for any repairs.
8. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

06 M Inspection of shared pathway sump pits & pumps
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate keys and access bollard padlock keys
are  required..
2. Provide signs warning the public of restricted pathway
access.

Instruction TMI-3012-OP-0005.
4. Inspection and Cleaning of  the Bath Tub.
(a) Be aware that sump pits could constitute a confined space
and appropriate safety measures should be taken.
(b) Clean out the bath tub and remove all silt, rubbish and
debris.
(d) Check the pump outlet pipe is not blocked (clear blockage
if necessary).

(a) Electrically isolate the pump prior to its removal from
the sump.
(b) Clean out the pump pit and grate, remove all silt,
rubbish and debris.

(a) Check that the visible parts of the pump e.g. lead,
enclosure, outlet pipe connection are in good condition.
(b) Check that the impellor can move freely.
(c) On completion of the check reinstate power supply to the
pump.

(a) Carry out visual internal and external inspection of
control panel for damage, evidence of insect infestation,
ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as required).
(b) Check cable connections for tightness and signs of
overheating and inspect electrical contral equipment.
(c) Check for correct operation of level switch and alarm
light (Flashing Amber).
8. Record any corrective action required, in the "Work Done"
area of the job sheet.

03 M Load test of the MGE UPS
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the work.
2. Check with the control room if any UPS alarms are relevant.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual
E-679380XT/FA, M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel
Electrical Services Training Notes, M-STG-EL-24001,
Section 9.
WARNING
THE UPS BATTERY POTENTIAL IS APPROXIMATELY 380 VOLTS AND IS
EARTHED.  THE BATTERIES CAN DELIVER A FAULT CURRENT OF
APPROXIMATELY 9000 AMPS.  EXPOSED BATTERY TERMINALS ARE
DANGEROUS AND MUST NOT BE TOUCHED.  IN THE VICINITY OF THE
BATTERIES USE ONLY TOOLS WHICH ARE FULLY INSULATED.
SAFETY GLASSES MUST BE WORN WHEN CARRYING OUT  MEASUREMENTS
ON THE BATTERIES.
4. Check the UPS control panel readout for alarms and or normal
status.  If an alarm is found, record the alarm in the Work
Done Area of the Job Sheet. Do Not Continue with this Job if
an alarm is present.  [_ _]
5. Record measurements on form 03 M MGE Uninterruptible Power
Supply Battery Inspection and Test, TMF-3012-OP-0099.
6. Measure and record the UPS room temperature.   [_ _]
7. Check and record DC voltage and AC ripple voltage for each
bank of batteries.  If a discrepancy is found then record in
the Work Done Area of the Job Sheet.  Do Not Continue
this job sheet if there is a discrepancy in the readings
recorded and the readings expected.  [_ _]
8. To simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the
UPS operation will change to the batteries.  [_ _]
9. Operate the UPS, in this mode, for at least 10
minutes.  [_ _]
10. Measure and record the DC voltage for each shelf of the
battery banks.
11. Measure and record the DC current flow in each battery bank.
12. Return the UPS to normal operation by closing Mains 1
Isolator Q1.  [_ _]
13. With an Optical thermometer measure the temperature of the
batteries and their inter-connections.  Temperature readings
should approximate ambient room temperature.  When a
connection is found to having a temperature greater than 5
degrees above room  temperature, in the Work Done Area of
the Job Sheet, record the battery location, terminal
identification, measured  temperature.  [_ _]
14. With an Optical thermometer measure the average temperature
of the two (AC & DC) capacitor banks and record the result.
15. With an anemometer measure and record the airflow from each
of the UPS cooling fans.
16. With the Optical thermometer measure and record the
temperature of each of the UPS cooling fans.  [_ _]
17. Ensure Normal operation of the UPS.  [_ _]
18. Sweep and clean the UPS room:
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated webs from the
walls.   [___]
Sweep the control panel room floors as well, vacuum the
control panel enclosures and any surfaces that will collect
dust deposits.   [___]
Clean the front panel of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish.   [_ _]
19. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the UPS room and
equipment etc,  in the "Work Done"section of the job
sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
20. Leave a duplicate 03M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Battery Inspection and  test form in the UPS room.  Compare
previously recorded data and record in the Work Done
Area of the Job Sheet any data that shows any degradation.
21. Notify the control room on completion of the job."

01 W Mon, m'sure & report  Swan St pump stn flows
The measure of water flowing from the Swan Street pump station
is a measure of all the water collected in the Burnley Tunnel
drainage systems, from both dirty and Groundwater sources.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. For detail of Job, refer to Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL
DRAINAGE TMI-3012-OP-0031.
3. The Civil Team leader is to provide a copy of the previous
WEEKLY BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS TMF-3012-OP-0233 for
detail of the previous readings.
4. At the Swan Street Pump Station Motor Control Centre, record
the Time and the Total flow in kilo litres for the pump
station on the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS
TMF-3012-OP-0233.
5. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
6. Ensure a copy of the form BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE FLOWS
TMF-3012-OP-0233 is forwarded to the Civil Team Leader for
evaluation on completion  of the job.
Note:  An increase or decrease in the pump station outflows
in excess of  0.5 litres/s could indicate a problem.  Raise a
job to investigate to check the various bay flows for the
reason to the change in water flowrate.

02 W Record Piezometer Readings BT water table pressures
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control prior to commencing the work.
2. Lane closures to access the Burnley tunnel shall be as per
Work Instruction, Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 25 or 26.
3. Reference documents:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Melbourne CityLink Project, Southern Link, Operations and
Maintenance Manual Tunnel Drainage Stage 2. R-STG-EN-006
and Transfield Obayashi JV<(>,<)>
(c) Operations & Maintenance Tanked Tunnel Drainage Works
Report PSM407.R34 December 2000 R-SDG-TU-134.
(d) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture, Burnley Tunnel Long
Term Monitoring of Twin Anchored Slabs.  Report
PSM407.R30 September 2000, R-SDG-TU-130.
(e) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture Extensometer and
Piezometer Readings Procedures Report PSM500.R11  June
2001   R-SDG-TU-211  Rev A.
4. Location:
Eighty-six piezometers are located along the length of the
tanked section of the Burnley Tunnel.  Forty-three are
mounted on the south side wall, and Forty-three mounted on
the north side wall.  They highest test point is located up
to 3.5m above the road surface on the tunnel walls.
5. Purpose:
The Piezometer test points are used to monitor groundwater
pressures on the outside of the tunnel wall.  The pressure
reading is then directly related to the groundwater head.
6. Carry out Piezometer readings:
6.1 (a) Loosen the bolt on one side of the stainless steel cover
and rotate the cover to reveal the quick connect
pressure coupling behind.
(b) Wipe the quick connect pressure coupling clean with a
rag.
(c) A ladder will be required to reach the piezometers in
the central section of the tunnel.  A second person may
be required to hold the ladder in place.
6.2 (a) Prior to each reading, Vent the Druck digital pressure
indicator using the tap on the hose of the machine to
allow the pressures within the instrument to equalise.
(b) Connect the Druck digital pressure indicator to the
quick connect coupling.  Pull back the sleeve on the
Druck digital pressure indicator connection and then
push the connection of the Druck digital pressure
indicator connection onto the piezometer connection.
6.3 (a) Press the  I/O button to switch the unit on.
(b) Ensure the reading is set to Kilopascals (kpa) and set
to zero.
(c) To obtain consistent readings, hold the Druck digital
pressure indicator at the same level as the piezometer
tip during the reading.
(d) Allow the reading to stabilise, and record reading on
form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL - GROUNDWATER PRESSURE
TMF-3012-OP-0229.
Note that some of  the readings may stabilise in a few
seconds, although some other readings may require a few
minutes to stabilise.
(e) Vent the Druck digital pressure indicator between
readings.
6.4 Record the results on form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
GROUNDWATER PRESSURE"" TMF-3012-OP-0229.
6.5 Replace the stainless steel cover and re-tighten the bolt.
7. Repeat Step 6 for the balance of the piezometer test points.
8. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet & also ,,inform the
Team Leader.
9. Notify the Control room on completion of the Job.
10. Ensure a copy of the completed form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
GROUNDWATER PRESSURE TMF-3012-OP-0229 is forwarded to the
Civil Team Leader or his representative for evaluation on
completion of the job.  Results that are not in accordance
with baseline values would indicate a change in the state of
the groundwater storage.  The operation of the Groundwater
recharge systems should be checked for correct operation.
Work completed as above work plan.

01 M Check, Replace blown lamps in the Burnley Tunnel."

required are 1070665 (TF000377) (150W), 1070666 (TF000378)
(250W), 1070664 (TF000376) (400W) and fluorescent lamps are
1070720 (TF000372) (35W).
(a) Priority given to replace lamps if the lamps in three
consecutive light fittings are not operational.
(b) If a tunnel closure is planned for the month that the job
sheet is issued, priority is to be given to replacing
portal and ramp lighting.
(c) Light fitting diffuser cleaning, where possible, shall be
carried out during the planned tunnel closures at six
monthly intervals, in May and November approximately.

and Translink Operations Procedure PR-RS-OP-IR-020 plan 27,

centre lane, and 122 for tunnel closure).
4. Use the EWP in the 'B' mode.
5. Before replacing faulty lamps either unplug from power box or
remove the fuse for isolation.

both ran the same amount of hours.
7. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable,
Leaky  Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework,
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the Work
Done area of the Job Sheet and bring to the attention of
the Team Leader Electrical or his representative.
8. Notify the TCR on completion of the work.

01 M Check of  Burnley Vent Station Primary Axial Fans
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Works to carried out at non-peak times.
2. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3, the
ventilation rooms and to interrupt operations.
3. Inform the control room prior to commencing the work and
brief TCRO's on interruptions and expected alarms.  Maintain
radio contact at all times.
4. Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual (M-STG-VE-26058)
5. At the PMCS in the control room.
(a) Check the motor balance vibration readings on the PMCS
for all fans.  If any reading is in excess of 6.5mm/s<(>,<)>
record the result in the "Work Done" area of the job
sheet for further action.   [_ _]
(b) Check the trend log for the last month, looking for
abnormal events.   Any events and or trends that are
abnormal are to be recorded in the work done area of the
Jobsheets and a new job sheet raised to investigate and
correct the abnormality.  [_ _]
(c) Check the running current and record in the "Work Done"
area if greater than Primary fans FLC 349A    Secondary
fans FLC 310A.
(d) Check the drive and non drive end bearing temperatures
for the operating fan motor.  Record the details for
those bearings with a temperature greater then 80°C in
the "Work Done" area of the job sheet for further
action   [_ _]
(e) Record Hours run in Work Done.  [_ _]
6. Access to the  Burnley ventilation station is through the
locked airlock on stairway adjacent to the south west corner
of the Burnley vent stack.  Access to substation 3 is via
external doors adjacent to the Burnley Portal.
WARNING:
DO NOT CARRY OUT THESE CHECK WHENEVER MORE THAN 2 FANS ARE
OPERATIONAL
DO NOT ENTER THE ACCESS AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM
ALONE.  TWO OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT WHENEVER WORK IS
BEING CARRIED OUT IN THIS AREA.  OBSERVE ALL NOTICES ON THE
AIRLOCK DOORS.
7. In substation 3;
(a) Switch the Main Isolator for EFE 01 OFF.  (NOTE:- The
order of fan selection is dependant on fan requirements.
A minimum of one fan must be running at any time).  Open
the starter cubicle & inspect the cubicle & wiring
connections.  Upon completion close the door, and return
the Main Isolator to the ON position.  [_ _]
(b) Switch the Main Isolators for all the other non
operational axial fans, one at a time EFE 02 thru to
EFE10 to the OFF position, then inspect the starter
cubicles.  Once the inspections are complete, ensure the
cabinet doors are closed and the isolators are returned
to the ON positions.  [_ _]
8.1 Fan Room Access
(a)  Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after
equalizing differential pressure in the airlock.
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1 METRE OF
AN OPERATING FAN INLET GUARD, AS THE AIR IS FLOWING AT APPROX
35kmh .
8.2 Static Checks
(a) Press the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton adjacent to the
motor.
(b) Check the condition of anti-vibration mountings and
ensure that the rubber bushing is moved freely, adjust if
required.  [_ _]
(c) Examine the grease that has been discharged from the
motor bearings for any noticeable colour changes.  [_ _]
(d) Open the local electrical junction box, inspect the
electrical wiring and connections, inspect all glands for
tightness.  [_ _]
(e) Visually inspect the motor for evidence of condensation<(>,<)>
white powder or similar.  Record in the "Work Done" area
of the Job Sheet any evidence of condensation, powder and
the like and notify the Team Leader or his
representative.  [_ _]
(f) Carry out the following insulation/resistance test of the
motor and heater windings.
(i)  Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has
been isolated and is to remain isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motor windings and the winding heater bridge.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out an Insulation resistance
test between this common bridge and earth.  Record
the result in the "Work Done" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) If the heater was connected on arrival, then
re-instate the heater connections, otherwise leave the
motor winding heater terminations isolated.
(vii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(viii) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than
2 megohm, then Record in the "Work Done"area of the
Job Sheet and raise a new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
"Related Job" field as well as in the alternate.
Notify the Team Leader or his representative of any
outstanding works.
8.3  Running Checks.
(a) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton and contact the TCR
to start the fan.  [_ _]
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(c) Check the fan for any abnormal noise or vibrations.  _ _]
(d) Check the flexible connections for wear and leakage of
air.  [_ _]
(e) Check anti-vibration mountings for operation and
structural soundness [_ _]
(f ) Check the operation of the local vibration
monitor.   [_ _]
(g) Record any abnormalities in the "Work Done" area of the
Job Sheet for further action.  [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the Local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
8.4 Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) On completion of  the Static Fan Checks, return to
substation 3, then remove the safety tags, in accordance
with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then remove the fan motor
isolation at the MCC.
Note: Ensure that only one non-operational fan is
isolated at any one time.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF
position to the MANUAL and the  REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switch from the REMOTE position to the LOCAL
position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room; there start the fan<(>,<)>
that is being maintained, by releasing the local STOP
pushbutton at the fan and then pressing START
pushbutton.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(e) Add Shell Stamina RL2 grease or equivalent, to the
bearings, only while the fan is running.  Ten pumps per
bearing.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the
bearings, using the retrieval system.  Examine the
grease for changes of colour.   [_ _]
(g) Check the fan for any abnormal noises or
vibrations.     [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
9. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 02.  [_ _]
10. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 03.  [_ _]
11. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 04.  [_ _]
12. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 05.  [_ _]
13. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 06.  [_ _]
14. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 07.  [_ _]
15. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 08.  [_ _]
16. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 09.  [_ _]
17. Repeat step 8 for fan EFE 10.  [_ _]
18. (a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are
disengaged.  [_ _]
(b) Collect all tools and materials, leave the fan room<(>,<)>
again equalise the corridor and the fan room pressures.
19. (a) Check the lighting within the fan chamber for
operation.  [_ _]
(b) Repair any light found to be not operating or raise a
new jobsheet for the repair of the fan chamber lighting.
20. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done'
section of the Job Sheet.
21. Notify the control room on completion of work.
22. Return to the control room and ensure all fans are
operational.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident has
occurred requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
Note:  Depending on the position of an event, Substation 1 may be
inaccessible.
1. If Substation 3 is not accessible
(a). If a fan that is being checked is running,  advise the
traffic control room that the fan  is running under
LOCAL control. Unless advice is received, from the
control room,  that fan should remain under LOCAL
control.
(b). Vacate the ventilation fan chamber, ensuring the sliding
door to the airlock is closed and sealed.
(c). Advise the traffic control room when all personnel are
in or have left the air lock.
2. Substation 3 is accessible
(a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are disengaged
(b) Return to substation 3 and switch all the fan
REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switches to the REMOTE position
and switch all the fan  AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switches to
the AUTO position.
(c) Notify the traffic control room operators that they have
control of the fans.

06 M Jet Fan maintenance and lubrication.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1.  Works to be carried out on one jet fan at a time so as to
not affect the operation of total tunnel ventilation
2.  Notify control room prior to commencing work.
3.  Set up lane closure as per Work Instruction TMI-3012-OP-0002
and Translink Operations Procedure PR-RS-OP-IR-020 Plan 27
or 28.
4.  Reference Manual;  Witt & Sohn, Operations and Maintenance
Manual , Certificate 18. (M-STG-VE-29047 )
5.  In associated equipment room switch jet fan AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switch to MAN and REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL switch to LOCAL
to enable control adjacent to jet fan.  [_ _]
6.  Running visual inspection
WARNING:  DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF BODY IN INLET OR OUTLET
AIR STREAM WHEN FAN IS RUNNING.
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN.
(a) Start fan locally by pressing the START button on the
panel adjacent to the fan.   [_ _]
(b) Check for any abnormal noise or movement from the
fan.  [_ _]
(c) Check the fan unit vibration mountings and safety rods
for loose nuts and bolts.  [_ _]
(d) Stop fan locally with the EMERGENCY STOP button.  [_ _]
(e) If any non-conforming items are found, investigate
further in the static fan inspection.  [_ _]
7.  Static fan inspection
(a) Ensure the local  EMERGENCY STOP button is engaged. [_ _]
(b) Conduct a thorough visual inspection for damage and
corrosion of the silencers, impeller, inlet cone, cable
connections, mounting frame and vibration attenuators.
Any cracks identified in the vicinity must be noted in
the "Work done" area of the job sheet for
further investigation.   [_ _] Photo of Cracks found
will be required.
Any damage, especially to surface protection, must be
noted in the "Work done" area of the job sheet for
further investigation.   [_ _]
(c) Carry out careful inspection of all supporting hardware
and screw connections, including the eight vibration bracket
installations and the four safety rod brackets.  Using a
torque wrench, ensure that the accessible supporting screw
connections are secured and fixed with the correct torque
settings.  [_ _]
NOTE: Torque Settings
M10 = 37Nm
M12 = 65Nm
M16 = 150Nm
M20 = 300Nm      as per reference manual
in step 4
Bolts with Nylon washers should only be checked for
tightness. Do not torque as nylon washer get damaged
Do not torque anchor bolts in tunnel roof. Check for
tightness only.
(d) If any non-conforming items are found, record in the
"Work Done" area of the job sheet and rectify immediately
where possible to the requirements of the Witt & Sohn <(>,<)>
Operations and Maintenance Manual , Certificate 18.
(M-STG-VE-29047).   This inspection is carried out
externally via the inlet and exhaust ends using a
torch.  [_ _]
(e) Remove cover to motor junction box and check the cable
connections visually for tightness and evidence of
overheating.
8.  Lubrication
(a) Release the key operated EMERGENCY STOP button, restart
fan  locally.
(b) Regrease bearings using grease gun on nipples onside of
fan with  Mobilith SHC220 (TF000021) grease, 10 pumps of
hand grease gun per grease nipple.
Note:  Lubrication should be carried out between 3,000
and 4,000 hours running time when access is available.
Do not over grease.    [_ _]
(c) Stop fan using local EMERGENCY STOP button
(d) Release the EMERGENCY STOP button using a Key.  (Remove
the key)   [_ _]
9.  Equipment Room Control Panel.
(a) Switch fan REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch to REMOTE to
enable control at panel
(b) Carry out visual internal and external inspection of the
control panel for damage evidence of insect infestation<(>,<)>
ingress of moisture, dust and grime (clean as
required).  [_ _]
(c) Check cable connections visually for tightness and signs
of overheating and inspect electrical control
equipment [_ _]
(d) Start fan with START pushbutton on panel and leave
running for approximately 5 minutes
(e) Check ammeter at electrical panel to verify fan is
operating within current limits FLC 100A.  [_ _]
(f ) Using an infra red thermometer check the temperature of
the connections and power cables to the motor.   Record in
the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet if the temperature
recorded is more that 10º to 15º C above ambient.   [_ _]
(g) Record the "hours run" from the Jet Fan hour run meter
on the panel door in the "Work Done"" area of the job
sheet.   [_ _]
Note:  Hour run meters are on the control panels for
non-reversing fans only.
Reversing fans hour run readings are obtainable
from the PMCS screens in the control room
10. Return the LOCAL/OFF/REMOTE switch to the OFF position and
the AUTO/OFF/MAN  fan selector switch to the AUTO
position.   [_ _]
11. Advise the Traffic control room operator that control of the
fan is returned to the control room.    [_ _]
12. If carrying out maintenance duties adjacent to the AM Cable<(>,<)>
Leaky  Co-axial cable, Fibrolazer cable, deluge pipework<(>,<)>
public address loud speakers and cables and any other
equipment mounted on tunnel upper walls and roof.
(a) Check for any abnormal conditions and record in the
"Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and bring to the attention
of the Team Leader Electrical or his representative.
13. Notify control room on completion of work.
14. Enter the hours run for the jet fan into the Plant item
screen, then select the usage tab.

01 M L1 Inspect of fire doors within the OMB
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. This work is to be carried out by suitably qualified personnel.
2. This work is for the OMB building.
3. Inspect the OMB fire doors to AS 1851.7 Type 1 inspection.  The
inspection shall consist of
an examination of the condition of the door set and a check that it
is operating satisfactorily.
In particular, the following routine should be followed.
3.1 Inspect for any remedial work that is outstanding and unfinished andrecord
works to be
completed in the comments field.
3.2 Remove any obstructions or non-approved devices such as wedges,
heavy objects or
hooks that are used to hold the door open.
3.3 Check that the door and all it's components, hardware and functions
are correct.
3.4 While the door is open, check that all screws are firm in the
hinges, latch set faceplate,
striking plate and the door closer body and bracket.
3.5 Inspect that the door identification data notice, required by the
regulatory authority is firmly
attached.  The notice is generally mounted on the door edge and
onthe door frame.
3.6 Check the closing and latching action (on the closing), and that
thedoor stopping action
(fully open limit) is functioning (on the opening).
3.7 With the door closed, check that the leaf is a reasonably even fit
in the frame.

A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
installations of Equipment
Room ERW00 as well the cleaning, inspections and maintenance of the
relevant area.
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( ERW00 )
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the Equipment room.
2. On entering Equipment room, temporarily switch OFF ventilation fans,
if operating (fans not
required to be  switched OFF in technical shelters and appropriate
equipment
rooms).   [_ _]
3. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere, use your
senses of sight, smell
and hearing to monitor any abnormal events.  [_ _]
4. Check the interior lighting for operation, including the operational
tube within EXIT signs,
replace faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting fixture.  [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all accessible
equipment and
components within all switchboards and distribution panels mounted
with the equipment
room.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient plus
10°C should be
considered abnormal and must be noted in the ""Work Done"" area of
the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. Raise a new
job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and
components  for evidence of burn marks, unusual odours and
overheating.  Record anything
abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and raise a new
jobsheet for any
corrective action. Ensure the Team Leader or his representative is
informed of the
abnormality.  [_ _]
7.  While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering,
arcing etc.  [_ _]
8. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware, gaskets,
seals and escutcheons
for serviceability and general operation, lubricate as required.
Carry out any required repairs
or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding actions.  [_ _]
9. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and damage.  [_ _]
10. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for dust,
grime and condensation,
clean enclosures of any accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
11. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.  Clean
or replace  filters as
required.  [_ _]
12. Inspect systems, mounted within the room(s), for faulty indicators,
faulty meters,
damaged switches and buttons etc, carry out repairs or indicator
lamp replacement or
raise a new job sheet for any outstanding actions.   [_ _]
13.  PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators found
toindicate abnormal
conditions are to be logged in the work done area of the job
sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw
connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and module
security screws are not
loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the enclosure
andPLC modules
are cleaned of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
14. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for accumulated
debris, evidence of water
accumulation.
15.   Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the ""Work
Done"" area of the Job
Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative of any
corrective actions.  [_ _]
C. Equipment room Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture ingress.
Inspect for source of
any water.  Record any details in the ""Work Done"" area of the job
sheet and inform the Team
Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check that the room(s) are not obstructed by furnishings and or
stored items.  Remove
any obstruction.  [_ _]
3. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets, ledges,
cable trays,
cables, etc.   Note: Dust will settle on all ledges and surfaces,
e.g. Tops of cabinets, tops
of cabinet doors, tops of meter escutcheons etc.  [_ _]
4. Clean all exterior surfaces of cabinets using approved cleaning
materials .  [_ _]
5. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets, light fittings,cable
trays and
ceilings.  [_ _]
6. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris.   [_ _]
7. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces.  [_ _]
8. In the Exhaust Fan (6, 7 & 8) area check the lighting for operation.
Remove all debris
paying special attention to the drain for blockage and any
potentialblockage.  [ _ _]
9.  Visually inspect rodent bait stations for bait.  Replace bait
station if bait is near
exhausted.  [_ _]
10. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.   Record
any abnormal parameter
in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet.   Raise a new jobsheet
for any outstanding
corrective actions.  [_ _]
11. Prior to leaving the site ensure:
(a)  All plant turned OFF has been returned to service e.g. Fans,
Air Conditioners.  [_ _]
(b)  All Enclosures closed and locked.  [_ _]
(c)  All Lighting turned OFF  [_ _]
12.  Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the ""Work
Done"" area of the Job
Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative of any
corrective actions.  [_ _]
13. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to departing.

06 M DT Lighting Levels Measurement
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**

inspection.

thermometer and marker strips prior to carrying out lighting
levels measurement.
4. Location nominated for carrying out lighting measurement
includes the following fire box locations:
D10, D15 , D20, D23
To assist with identifying the exact points of measurement,
eight (8) marker strips should be laid out at 4m interval at
the location being measured. At each location, the 4m
intervals have been marked on site with studs embedded into
line marking on edge of the carriageway. The marker strips
should be placed adjacent to the studs.
5. Measurement area should be bollarded off.
6. At each measurement location:
a. Measure ambient temperature
b. Check for the following external factor prior to taking
measurements:
i.   Car Headlights - should be at least 120m (2 fire boxes)
from measurement location.
ii.  Headlights and flashing beacons on the work vehicle
should be switched off when taking measurement.
iii. Illuminated arrow sign boards should be used on work
vehicles and should be facing away from measurement
location.
iv.  Shadowing from people - no persons to be within 20m of
measurement point, except person taking measurement,
who should be in crouched position.
c. Measure Lighting Levels and record value on Form
TMF-3012-OP-0393.
7. Record any outstanding works required.
8. Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.

04 M Insp/cln of  WL CCTV cams, EWP, Centre of Road"
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the right hand
lane or mounting the median strip
2. Access to this camera group is:
(a) Access Vehicle: EWP.
(b) Position 0 and 1.
(c) Lane Closure: RHS lane
(d) Electrical Cabinet Location: Tollway
3. Set up the lane closure as per  Work Instruction, Traffic
Control, TMI-3012-OP-00002 and Translink  Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
4. Reference Manual, Chubb, Operations and Maintenance Manual,
Section 4.1 (M-MCL-TM-1511)
5. Camera Junction Box / Controller Cabinet;
(a) Check for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation, clean if
necessary.   [_ _]
(b) Inspect the cabinet and the equipment mounted in the
cabinet is secure.  [_ _]
(c) Check cables and terminations for signs of degradation,
re-terminate if necessary.  [_ _]
(d) Check fibre patch leads for damage and are securely
fastened to the PT300.
WARNING: DO NOT LOOK DIRECTLY INTO THE END OF FIBRE OPTIC
CABLE AS DAMAGE TO EYE SIGHT CAN RESULT.
(e) Check if surge suppressor red LED (on the GPO) is lit, if
not record the fact, for later replacement.  [_ _]
(f) Check with TCRO  that picture vision is OK.  If not check
the signal from the camera using the WFM  90 meter.
(Connect the WFM90 directly  to the lead from the camera).
Ensure the co-axial cable is reconnected to the PT300
module and is secure.  [_ _]
6. Isolate the 240V supply to the PTZ controller and disconnect
(unplug) the control cable to the PTZ controller prior to
inspecting the camera housing.  This will prevent movement
of the PTZ .  [_ _]
7. Camera and Camera Housing;
WARNING: 240V SUPPLY TO THE CAMERA AND CAMERA HEATER IS STILL
ALIVE.
(a) Check  for vandalism, damage, corrosion, ingress of
moisture and any insect infestation.  Surface insect
spray may be applied if necessary to the housing exterior
but must not be applied to the interior of the housing or
to the housing glass.  If ingress of moisture or insect
infestation is evident then carry out
steps (d) and (e).  [_ _]
(b) Check that the camera housing is firmly secured to pole
mounts. [_ _]
(c) Clean the glass of the environmental enclosure with
"Rain-X " cleaning fluid.  [_ _]
(d) Check if camera heaters are operational, ie warm.
WARNING: HEATERS ARE HOT AND DUE CARE SHOULD BE TAKEN.
If the heaters are not warm, spray the heater thermostat
(HTR) with FREEZE IT, then again check the operation of the
heater. [_ _]
(e) Discard the previously used Silica Gel pack and replace
with a new uncontaminated Silica Gel Pack.
8. Reconnect the PTZ control cable to the PTZ controller and
