the CML RSE Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
M-MCL-ET-1225.
2. Perimeter access gate at technical shelter key required.
3. To access the 400W VDC lamps on the right hand side, set up a
lane closure as per work instruction TMI-3012-OP-0002 and the
TLO procedure PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 17, 18 and Plan 12 for the
left hand side access.
Note: In locations where a rear gantry exists the 400W VDC
lamps are located and accessed via the rear gantry structure.
Note: Any changes made to the closure in Work Done area of
the Job Sheet.
4. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment and
or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.
Adhere to safety instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 ""Working on
Gantry Structures"".
5. Notify Control Room prior to entering the Technical Shelter.
6. Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plkan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
Preventative Maintenance No:
1201: Inspect electrical Pump set
1202: No procedure to check bolts are tightened.  Visually
check accessible bolt markings to ascertain if any movement,
inspect for corrosion.
1204: Inspect cabinets for cleanliness, corrosion , damage,
evidence of possible electrical malfunction, Inspect for
corrosion, ingress of moisture, insect infestation, damage
and security of all fasteners
1205: Checking VDC sensors and connectors.
The following Task is to be also carried out using extreme
care to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter the Fibre
Optic connectors or cables, ensure sufficient fibre optic
cable is available to allow removal of the fibre optic
connector (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
NOTE: Ensure the fibre Optic Connector remains free of
foreign matter.
Carefully remove the Fibre Optic Connector, clean the
connector body of any deposits. Take care to not touch the
Fibre Optic pins within the connector (if touched or dirty,
clean pins with Fibre Optic cleaner).
Apply a light  coating of silicon spray to a cloth and wipe
onto the Fibre Optic connector body, replace and exercise the
Fibre Optic Connector release collar.
Where connectors cannot be easily removed, record details in
the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and report the fact
to the Team Leader or his representative.
1206: Clean VR Sensor Unit Vent with brush or similar
7. Record in the area of the Job Sheet below any outstanding
works requiring further attention.  Create a new Job sheet
for any outstanding works and notify the Team Leader or his
representative of the outstanding works.  Record the New job
number in the "Work Done" area of this job sheet and in the
"Related Job" field of both jobs.
8. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
Shelter.

CML - BBridge Aerofoil Inspection
25.08.2014 12:59:13 Jason Ng (NGJ)
From: Jacqui Laverick [mailto:ggemel@bigpond.net.au]
Sent: Monday, 25 August 2014 10:19 AM
To: Reeves, David
Subject: Bolte Bridge Aerofoil Inspection
Morning David
Starting on the 12 August 2014, G<(>&<)>G Engineering conducted an
inspection of the Bolte Bridge Aerofoil rivets, we had two teams working
along the Aerofoil to complete the inspection. Team 1 worked with the
Vic Roads underbridge unit to inspect the underside panels of the
aerofoil (bottom half of panel 3 and panels 4, 5 and 6) Team 2 worked
using a 45 foot boom lift inspected the top panels of the aerofoil
(panels 1, 2 and top half of panel 3) the bulk of the inspection was
conducted over 3 nights working from the road within a single slow lane
closure.
On this first night (12-8-2014) both teams started on the Outbound
(Northbound) Carriageway at the southernmost tip of the aerofoil, panel
segment number 5N-13.
Team 1 inspected up to the North expansion joint, panel segment number
1N, Team 2 inspected up to and including panel segment number 3NS21.
The second night (13-8-2014) both teams started on the Inbound
(Southbound) Carriageway, Team 1 started at the North expansion joint,
panel segment number 1S and inspected up to the southernmost end of the
aerofoil, panel segment number 5S-13.
Team 2 started at the northernmost tip of the aerofoil, panel segment
number 1S-13 and inspected up to and including panel segment number
3SN15.
With the majority of the underside completed at both outbound and
inbound a decision was made not to have the Vic Roads underbridge unit
return to complete the remaining 13 panels segments at the north end of
both inbound and outbound as these panels could be accessed via a boom
lift from ground level, ideally during the next expansion joint wing
inspection
The third night (14-8-2014) Team 2 along with an additional person
returned to the Outbound (Northbound) Carriageway and continued the
inspection of the top panels and completed to the last northernmost
panel segment 1N-13, by midnight traffic management was swapped over to
Inbound (Southbound) Carriageway and continued the inspection of the top
panels and completed to the last southernmost panel segment 5S-13.
Then on Thursday 21-8-2014 the underside of the remaining 13 panels
segments at the north end of both inbound and outbound aerofoil was
inspected using the truck mounted boom lift that was onsite providing
access to inspect the wing areas of the expansion joints.
A total of 306 rivets were replaced during these works. The outbound
aerofoil had a quantity of 181 rivets changed. The inbound aerofoil had
a quantity of 125 rivets changed.
Attached is a spreadsheet detailing the aerofoil panel segment numbers,
panel numbers and number of rivets replaced.
Kind Regards
Graeme Gilliland

101 Brooklyn Rd
Melton South  Vic  3338
P:  03 9743 6907
F:  03 9743 9916

03 M Inspection of SL TSH UPS - Fentons systems
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to entering each Technical
Shelter.
2. Three Month Service Plan Reference :  Fenton Users
Manual - Uninterruptible Power Supplies""  On-Line Series
UME V. 5.2 4kVA, 6kVA, 8kVA, 10kVA.
3. Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
charged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 13.5
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will
indicate a battery fault. ]
4. (a) Press the ""Control"" button on the UPS, followed by the
"Down Arrow"" button until the message  CONTROL BYPASS MODE
appears.
(b) Press the "Control" button and "Enter" button
simultaneously, the UPS will transfer into the bypass
mode.
,,   **If at anytime during load transfer the UPS ,,,,,,
malfunctions, notify TCR prior to continuing.**
c) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.  The
"Bypass O/P" indicator should be illuminated.   [_ _]
(d) Contact the Traffic Control Room to confirm receipt of
alarm condition.   [_ _]
(e) Scroll through menu using the "Display" button followed
by the "Down Arrow"
(f) Remove side covers from the UPS.   WARNING THE UPS IS
STILL ALIVE.
(g) Visually inspect the interior of the UPS for accumulated
dust, connections or other components that may show
obvious distress.   [_ _]
(h) Check that both the front and rear fans are operating
(The front fan is thermostatically controlled).    [_ _]
(i) Press the "Control" button, then press the "Down Arrow"
until the message "CONTROL INVERTOR MODE" appears. [_ _]
(j) Press the "Control" button and the "Enter" button
simultaneously, wait approx 10 seconds  until the UPS
reverts back to its normal operation.   [_ _]
5. (a) Contact TCR prior to isolating.
,,   Switch to the OFF position the wall mounted isolator or
CB1, on the rear  of the UPS to transfer the load to the
batteries. Check with TCR once load has been transferred
to batteries that a power failure has not occurred.
,,   **Do not turn isolator back on for 20 seconds as this may
cause damage to the equipment.**
NOTE: Ensure that the Circuit breaker (C/B2) on the rear of
the UPS is not accidentally turned off at  this stage
as CB2 isolates the batteries.
(b) Continue with the UPS supplying the load from the
batteries for at least 10 minutes.
(c) Measure the voltage across each battery, ( whilst being
discharged ) record results in the in the UPS Battery
Test Sheet TMF-3012-OP-0037.  [_ _]
[ Each battery should have a nominal charge between 13.5
and 13.6 volts:  A voltage above 13.8 volts will
indicate a battery fault. ]
(d) Check the front LCD panel for any alarm conditions.  The
"On Battery " indicator should be illuminated.    [_ _]
(e) Scroll through menu using the "Display" button followed
by the "Down Arrow".  Record the voltage and current
details on form UPS Battery Test Sheet
TMF-3012-OP-0037   [_ _].
(f) Switch to the ON position the wall mounted isolator or
CB1, on the rear  of the UPS to transfer the load to the
normal supply.
6. Battery Panel.
(a) Wear Safety Glasses when carrying out measurements on the
Batteries.
(b) Ensure the Circuit Breaker operating handle, on side
panel door, is in the upright position and is not
tripped.  [_ _]
(c) Measure and record the overall charge voltage across the
CB ( nominally 217V. )    [_ _]
7. Record any result outside normal parameters, in the " Work
Done " area of the job sheet.
8. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
9. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.
"

structures and fixtures for evidence of corrosion or

03 M Inspect of O & M B HVAC System
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
2. Reference Manual A. E. Smith & Son Pty Ltd, O & M Manual for
Mechanical Services
serving Melbourne City Link Project Southern Link, Operations &
Maintenance Building.
M-OMB-OM-20000.
3. This work is to be carried by the sub-contractor under the
supervision of the
Electrical / Electronic Technician.
4. The sub-contractor shall provide a service report setting out the
work performed, as
well as, the result of any tests.  A copy is to be provided to the
overseeing tradesperson.
5. Work plan for AHU 1
5.1 Check the unit for damage, corrosion as well as, damage to the
ducting and
connections.   [_ _]
5.2 Check the unit, whilst in operation, for any unusual noise and any
vibration.    [_ _]
5.3 Check air filters, fit new filter media as required.  8 off Filters
610mm X 610mm X 570mm.
Clean and refit  wire retaining frame.     [_ _]
5.4 Check pressure drop across the filter media.    [_ _]
5.5 Check fan mounts, keys, grub screws and fastenings for security.
[_ _]
5.6 Check the fan motor and the fan bearings for leaks of grease.
Remove excess grease
and clean.    [_ _]
5.7 Check the condition and tension of the vee belts, as well as the
pulley wear, adjust of
fit new vee-belts if required.    [_ _]
5.8 Check that the drip tray is clean and that the drain is clear of
blockages.    [_ _]
5.9 Check hot water heat exchanger for leaks.  [_ _]
5.10 Check the hot water piping and control valves for damage and leaks.
[_ _]
5.11 Check dampers for operation, damage and or corrosion, repair faultycomponents.
[_ _]
6. Work plan for Chiller Unit - CH 1
6.1. Check the unit for undue noise and vibration whilst the unit is
running e.g .Noisy fan
motors, noisy compressor unit, loose access panels, loose piping.
[_ _]
6.2. Clear any accumulated debris from condenser airflow inlet.    [_ _]
6.3. Check condenser coils for damage.  Clean with compressed air if
necessary.    [_ _]
6.4. Measure and record the output air temperature of the condenser.
[_ _]
6.5 Check the compressor for gas leaks and ensure there is sufficient
oil in
compressor.  [_ _]
6.6 Check the compressor sump heaters for operation.  [_ _]
6.7  Inspect the compressor and its components for damage or corroded
components.  [_ _]
6.8  Check the compressor flexible mounts for serviceability, replace
damaged or ineffective
flexible mounts.   [_ _]
6.9 Check the operation of all safety controls, e.g. HP, LP and oil
safety switches.  [_ _]
6.10 Check all electrical cables for security and fixings.  [_ _]
6.11 Check the sight glass for level of oil, and the presence or not,
ofbubbles in the
refrigerant flow.  Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the job
sheet, if the oil level is low
or if bubbles are present in the refrigerant flow.    [___]
7. Repeat Step 6 for Chiller Unit  - CH 2.
8. Work plan for the Condenser Unit - CU 1
8.1. With fan operating, check the condenser unit for noise and
vibration.     [_ _]
8.2. Clear any accumulated debris from the airflow path. Clean the
coilsof excess dirt and
grime using compressed air.       [_ _]
8.3. Check the condenser coils for damage.      [_ _]
8.4. Check and record the temperature of the air expelled from the
condenser.      [_ _]
8.5. Check complement of operating fans is representitive of thermal
load.  [___]
9. Work Plan for the  Hot Water Boiler - B1
9.1 Check the boiler for unusual combustion noise.   [_ _]
9.2 Be aware of leaking or unburnt gas.   [_ _]
9.3 Check the gas supply pressure.   [_ _]
9.4 Check the pilot lamp and the gas burner (whilst in operation) for a
blue flame.  Record in
the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet, if either flame is
yellow or a bright orange colour.
Arrange for a serviceman to rectify the problem.   [_ _]
9.5 Check the burners, cabinet and air louvres are free of lint or
debris.  Clean if
required.   [_ _]
9.6 Check the burner and the combustion chamber for soot deposits.
Record in the ""Work
Done"" area of the job sheet.  Arrange for a serviceman to
rectify the problem.   [_ _]
9.7 Check and record the flow and return water temperature.   [_ _]
9.8 Check and record the pressure drop across the boiler.   [_ _]
9.9 Check the pressure relief valves (3) operate and close again
successfully.   [_ _]
10 Work Plan for the Chiller Control Panel.
10.1 Check the control panel connections are tight and secure.     [_ _]
10.2 Check the cabling and the control components for evidence of
overheating.  Repair any
faults found.     [_ _]
10.3 Operate the control panel through its control sequence.    [_ _]
10.5 Check for any operational alarms that are current.    [_ _]
10.6 Check all indicator lamps are functional, install new indicators
ifrequired.    [_ _]
10.7 Check the control panel for cleanliness, accumulated debris and
dust, corrosion or
ingress of water.  Clean if required.    [_ _]
11. Work plan for Hot Water  Header Tank - H 1
11.1 Check the level operated valve for correct setting and operation.
[_ _]
11.2 Check that the expansion tank overflow drain is clear.       [_ _]
11.3 Check that the overflow tray is clean of accumulated dust and
debris.  [_ _]
11.4 Check that the drain from the overflow tray is clear.   [_ _]
11.5 Check for leaks and damage to the tank.       [_ _]
11.6 Check that all valves are in the correct status.       [_ _]
11.7 Check that the expansion tank cover is correctly fitted.  [_ _]
12. Repeat Step 11 for Chilled Water Header Tank - H2
13. Work plan for Hot Water Circulating Pump - HWP 1
13.1 Check the motor and bearings for unusual noise and any vibration.
[_ _]
13.2 Check that the motor cooling air  has an unimpeded flow.  Clean if
required.       [_ _]
13.3 Check the  pump and bearings for unusual noises and any vibration
from the
pump.      [_ _]
13.4 Check for loose bolts, leaking from joints and cavitation within
the pump.      [_ _]
13.5 Check that there is water dripping from the pump gland. (1 to 2
drips per minute).      [_ _]
13.6 Record the reading of the inlet and outlet pressure gauges for the
pump.       [_ _]
14. Repeat Step 13 for Chilled Water Circulating Pump - CHWP 1
15. Repeat Step 13 for Chilled Water Circulating Pump - CHWP 2
16. Work Plan for the Fan Cooling Unit 1, mounted in ceiling of EDP
Processing room - FCU 1.
16.1 Check the motor, fan and bearings for any unusual noise and or
vibrations.   [_ _]
16.2 Check the air filters, install new or clean filters as required.
[_ _]
16.3 Check mounts, keys, grub screws and fastenings for security.  [_ _]
16.4 Check for leaks of oil or grease.   [_ _]
16.5 Check the drip tray for accumulated dirt and dust.  Ensure the
drain is clear.  Clean if
required.   [_ _]
16.6 Inspect the drain alarm sensor for operation, dirt and or debris,
clean as required.   [_ _]
16.7 Check the fan speed control circuit for operation.   [_ _]
16.8 Change out filter cells when pressure drop exceeds 130 Pa.   [_ _]
17. Repeat Step 16 for FCU 2 mounted in ceiling of EDP Processing room.
18. Repeat Step 16 for FCU 3 mounted in the ceiling of the Traffic
Managers office.
19. Repeat Step 16 for FCU 4 mounted in the ceiling of the Traffic
Control room.
20. Repeat Step 16 for FCU 5 mounted in the ceiling of the Traffic
Control room.
21. Repeat Step 16 for FCU 6 mounted in the ceiling of the OMB UPS room.
22. Work Plan for Air Conditioner 6 -  mounted in the CIRO's Office -
AC6
22.1 Check for unusual noises and any vibrations.    [_ _]
22.2 Check that the oil sump heater operates when the compressor is not
running and
that the oil is warm.    [_ _]
22.3 Check that the filters are not blocked.  Install new filters if
necessary.    [_ _]
22.4 Measure the ambient temperature of the room.    [_ _]
22.5 Check the thermostat setting. The room temperature should be
within±2°C of the
thermostat setting.    [_ _]
23. Record the date and the number(s) of the contracor Service report
inthe ""Work Done""
area of the Job Sheet.
24. Record anything outside normal parameters  in the ""Work Done""
areaof the job
sheet.
25. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
"

03 M Electrical Inspection and Clean LV Switchboards
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
Ensure sufficient items are in hand to carry out the cleaning and
inspections of the Building
and Electrics, prior to leaving the workshop, e.g. CRC, Rags, Vacuum
Cleaner, Cloths,
lamps for fluorescent, emergency, Exit and external lighting, Brooms,
Rubbish bags, Filter
material, Ladders, Silicon Lubricant Spray, Cold Gal, Wire Brush,
Thinners, Absorbent,
Rodent bait station
A  INTRODUCTION
This job is a combined job for the inspection of the electrical
installations of
Equipment Rooms, as well the cleaning, inspections and maintenance of
the relevant areas.
B  ELECTRICAL INSPECTIONS and MAINTENANCE
( Equipment Rooms ERE01 - ERE 16 and ERW 01 - ERW 06)
1. Notify the TCRO prior to entering the Equipment rooms, Technical
shelters and
Substations.
2. On entering switchrooms, temporarily switch OFF ventilation fans, if
operating (fans not
required to be  switched OFF in technical shelters and appropriate
equipment
rooms).   [_ _]
3. On entering the relevant area, be aware of the atmosphere, use your
senses of sight, smell
and hearing to monitor any abnormal events.  [_ _]
4. Check the interior and external lighting for operation, including theoperational
tube within
EXIT signs, replace faulty lamps or repair any faulty lighting
fixture.  [_ _]
5. Check the temperature of cables and connections on all accessible
equipment and
components within all switchboards and distribution panels.
Use an Infra-red temperature sensor.  Temperatures of ambient plus
10°C should be
considered abnormal and must be noted in the ""Work Done"" area of
the Job Sheet and
ensure the Team Leader or his representative is informed of the
abnormality. Raise a new
job sheet for any corrective action [_ _]
6. While carrying out the temperature check, Inspect all cables,
terminals, equipment and
components  for evidence of burn marks, unusual odours and
overheating.  Record
anything abnormal in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet and
raise a new jobsheet
for any corrective action. Ensure the Team Leader or his
representative is informed of
the abnormality.  [_ _]
7.  While carrying out the temperature check, Check relays and
contactors for chattering,
arcing etc.  [_ _]
8. Visually inspect all enclosure doors, hinges, hardware, gaskets,
seals and escutcheons
for serviceability and general operation, lubricate as required.
Carry out any required
repairs or raise a new jobsheet for any outstanding actions.  [_ _]
9. Check cable and glandings at enclosure entries for heating,
looseness, and
damage.  [_ _]
10. Inspect all electrical switchboard enclosures internally for dust,
grime and condensation,
clean enclosures of any accumulated dust, dirt and debris.  [_ _]
11. Ensure cabinets ventilation paths are clear of obstructions.  Clean
or replace filters as
required. [_ _]
12. Inspect systems, mounted within the building or room(s), for faulty
indicators,
faulty meters, damaged switches and buttons etc, carry out
repairsor indicator lamp
replacement or raise a new job sheet for any outstanding actions.
[_ _]
13.  PLC Equipment shall be inspected for the following
(a) Inspect the PLC status and error indicators.  Indicators found
toindicate abnormal
conditions are to be logged in the work done area of the job
sheet and a new job sheet
raised to investigate and correct the error.  [_ _]
(b) Inspect connections to the PLC including power e.g. plug
connections, screw
connections, for security.  [_ _]
(c) Ensure all modules are secure in their mounting and module
security screws are not
loose.  [_ _]
(d) Using a vacuum cleaner and a small brush ensure the enclosure and
PLC modules
are cleaned of accumulated dust and debris.  [_ _]
14. Check and clean cable troughs (in floor ducts) for accumulated
debris, evidence of water
accumulation, where applicable.
15. Inspect the door alarm switches at all external doors for operation
and security.  Check
with the Traffic Control Room Operator to confirm the receipt of
analarm.  Repair
faulty of defective switches.  Record details of outstanding
defects in the ""Work Done""
area of the Job Sheet.  [_ _]
16.   Record anything abnormal from the above inspections in the ""Work
Done"" area of the
Job Sheet and Inform the Team Leader or his representative of any
corrective
actions.  Include in the ""Related Job"" field of the new and
thisjob, the job number
of the alternate Job.   [_ _]
C. Building Inspections, Cleaning and Maintenance
1. Check the interior walls and floors for evidence of moisture ingress.
Inspect for source of
any water.  Record any details in the ""Work Done"" area of the job
sheet and inform the
Team Leader or his representative.  [_ _]
2. Check that the room(s) are not obstructed by furnishings and or
stored items.  Remove
any obstruction.  [_ _]
3. Remove by vacuuming, dust and debris from tops of cabinets, ledges,
cable trays,
cables, etc.   Note: Dust will settle on all ledges and surfaces,
e.g. Tops of cabinets, tops
of cabinet doors,  tops of meter escutcheons etc.  [_ _]
4. At equipment rooms (ERE03 - ERE16 & ERW 02 - ERW 05), replace
Absorbent.  [_ _]
5. Visually inspect rodent bait station for bait.  Replace bait station
if bait is near
exhausted.  [_ _]
6. Check telephone for operation.  [_ _]
7. Inspect all metal work for corrosion, clean of corrosion and recover
with cold gal area
cleaned.   [_ _]
8. Clean all exterior surfaces of cabinets using approved cleaning
materials .  [_ _]
9. Clean dust and cobwebs from interior walls, cabinets, light fittings
,cable trays and
ceilings.  [_ _]
10. Remove any accumulated rubbish and debris.  [_ _]
11. Sweep and vacuum all floor surfaces.  [_ _]
12. Be aware for any evidence of insect or rodent infestation.   Record
any abnormal
parameter in the ""Work Done"" area of the job sheet.   Raise a
new jobsheet for any
outstanding corrective actions.  [_ _]

02 W Record Piezometer Readings BT water table pressures
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control prior to commencing the work.
2. Lane closures to access the Burnley tunnel shall be as per
Work Instruction, Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and
Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 25 or 26.
3. Reference documents:
(a) Work Instruction, BURNLEY TUNNEL DRAINAGE
TMI-3012-OP-0031.
(b) Melbourne CityLink Project, Southern Link, Operations and
Maintenance Manual Tunnel Drainage Stage 2. R-STG-EN-006
and Transfield Obayashi JV,
(c) Operations & Maintenance Tanked Tunnel Drainage Works
Report PSM407.R34 December 2000 R-SDG-TU-134.
(d) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture, Burnley Tunnel Long
Term Monitoring of Twin Anchored Slabs.  Report
PSM407.R30 September 2000, R-SDG-TU-130.
(e) Transfield Obayashi Joint Venture Extensometer and
Piezometer Readings Procedures Report PSM500.R11  June
2001   R-SDG-TU-211  Rev A.
4. Location:
Eighty-six piezometers are located along the length of the
tanked section of the Burnley Tunnel.  Forty-three are
mounted on the south side wall, and Forty-three mounted on
the north side wall.  They highest test point is located up
to 3.5m above the road surface on the tunnel walls.
5. Purpose:
The Piezometer test points are used to monitor groundwater
pressures on the outside of the tunnel wall.  The pressure
reading is then directly related to the groundwater head.
6. Carry out Piezometer readings:
6.1 (a) Loosen the bolt on one side of the stainless steel cover
and rotate the cover to reveal the quick connect
pressure coupling behind.
(b) Wipe the quick connect pressure coupling clean with a
rag.
(c) A ladder will be required to reach the piezometers in
the central section of the tunnel.  A second person may
be required to hold the ladder in place.
6.2 (a) Prior to each reading, Vent the Druck digital pressure
indicator using the tap on the hose of the machine to
allow the pressures within the instrument to equalise.
(b) Connect the Druck digital pressure indicator to the
quick connect coupling.  Pull back the sleeve on the
Druck digital pressure indicator connection and then
push the connection of the Druck digital pressure
indicator connection onto the piezometer connection.
6.3 (a) Press the  I/O button to switch the unit on.
(b) Ensure the reading is set to Kilopascals (kpa) and set
to zero.
(c) To obtain consistent readings, hold the Druck digital
pressure indicator at the same level as the piezometer
tip during the reading.
(d) Allow the reading to stabilise, and record reading on
form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL - GROUNDWATER PRESSURE
TMF-3012-OP-0229.
Note that some of  the readings may stabilise in a few
seconds, although some other readings may require a few
minutes to stabilise.
(e) Vent the Druck digital pressure indicator between
readings.
6.4 Record the results on form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
GROUNDWATER PRESSURE"" TMF-3012-OP-0229.
6.5 Replace the stainless steel cover and re-tighten the bolt.
7. Repeat Step 6 for the balance of the piezometer test points.
8. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet & also ,,
inform the Team Leader.
9. Notify the Control room on completion of the Job.
10. Ensure a copy of the completed form MONTHLY BURNLEY TUNNEL -
GROUNDWATER PRESSURE TMF-3012-OP-0229 is forwarded to the
Civil Team Leader or his representative for evaluation on
completion of the job.  Results that are not in accordance
with baseline values would indicate a change in the state of
the groundwater storage.  The operation of the Groundwater
recharge systems should be checked for correct operation.

12 M Routine Maint. of Tunnel Smoke Duct damper actuator
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Approximately 10% of smoke dampers in the tunnel are to be
inspected annually.
The Team Leader Electrical shall obtain the previous year
check sheet TMF-3012-OP-0260 and use to allocate dampers to
be inspected with this job sheet.

3. Notify the control room prior to commencing this job.
4. Reference Manual: TROX Technik - Melbourne City Link Tunnel
Project, Operating & Maintenance Instructions Manual
M-STG-VE-26100.
5. Access to the tunnel shall be as per Work Instruction,
Traffic Control, TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 23,24,25, and 26.  Use the Plan best suited
to the smoke dampers circled for inspection on check sheet
BURNLEY TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF
BURNLEY TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION"" TMF-3012-OP-0260

BURNLEY TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF
BURNLEY TUNNEL SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION"" TMF-3012-OP-0260
using the elevated work platform in B mode.
Note that  either the LHS or the RHS or both sides of a
nominated damper may require inspection.
7. Request the TCRO to open and then close the smoke dampers
that are to be inspected.
8. Observe the damper blades for non-standard operation such as
(a) dampers that open or close sluggishly
(b) dampers that  fail to open or close completely
(c) dampers that move sluggishly.
(d) Record an OK or FAIL result on check sheet  BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION TMF-3012-OP-0260
9.  Repeat step 8 for all dampers to be inspected.
10. Note the Condition Rating for the dampers tested.
11. Record in Work done area of Job sheet any dampers that have
failed operation and raise new job sheet for repair.
Priority High P1.
12. Notify the TCR on completion of the job.
13. On completion of the job, forward check sheet BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER INSPECTION - 12 M INSPECTION OF BURNLEY TUNNEL
SMOKE DAMPER OPERATION TMF-3012-OP-0260   to the Team Leader
Electrical or representative for sign off.

01 M L1 Inspect of fire doors within the Tunnel environs
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. This work is to be carried out by suitably qualified
personnel.
2. This work is for the various equipment rooms, substations and
refuges throughout the tunnel complex.  Access to sub-station
door shall be under the supervision of an electrical
electronics technician.
3. Inform TCRO prior to commencing work.
Set up the lane closure as per Work Instruction Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plan 20, 22 or 23.
In the work done area record:
(a) Any deviations from the plan.
(b) Lane closure start time.
(c) Lane closure finish time.
(d) Weather conditions.
4. Inspect the fire doors listed on:
TMF-3012-OP-0280 Substation 1 and Mezzanine level fire doors
TMF-3012-OP-0281 Substation 2, Swan St Shaft and Refuge 3
fire doors
TMF-3012-OP-0282 Substation 3 & Burnley Fan Chamber fire
doors
TMF-3012-OP-0283 Substation 4 & Yarra Crossing fire doors
TMF-3012-OP-0284 Substation 5, ERW 01 & Olympic Park Pump
Station
TMF-3012-OP-0285 Burnley Tunnel Fire Doors
TMF-3012-OP-0286 Domain Tunnel Fire Doors
to AS 1851.7 Type 1 inspection.  The inspection shall consist
of an examination of the condition of the doorset and a check
that it is operating satisfactorily.
In particular, the following routine should be followed for
hinged fire doors.
5.1 Inspect for any remedial work that is outstanding and
unfinished and record works to be completed in the comments
field.
5.2 Remove any obstructions or non-approved devices such as
wedges, heavy objects or hooks that are used to hold the
door open.
5.3 Check that the door and all it's components, hardware and
functions are correct.
5.4 While the door is open, check that all screws are firm in
the hinges, latchset faceplate, striking plate and door
closer body and bracket.
5.5 Inspect the door identification data notice, required by the
regulatory authority is firmly attached.  The notice is
mounted in the door edge and on the door frame.
5.6 Check the closing and latching action (on the closing), and
that the door stopping action (fully open limit) is
functioning (on the opening).
5.7 The door having closed, check that the leaf is a reasonably
even fit in the frame.
For sliding or doors that are suspended on rollers.
6.1 Inspect for any remedial work that is outstanding and
unfinished and record works to be completed in the comments
field.
6.2 Remove any obstructions or non-approved devices such as
wedges, heavy objects or hooks that are used to hold the
door open.
6.3 Check that the door and all it's components, hardware and
functions are correct.
6.4 With the door in both the open and closed position, check
that all screws are firm in the supports, handles, brackets,
rollers, runners, guides and counterweights.
6.5 Inspect the door identification data notice, required by the
regulatory authority is firmly attached.  The notice is
mounted in the door edge and on the door frame.
6.6 Check the closing and latching action (on the closing), and
that the door stopping action is functioning.
6.7 With the door closed, check that the door is a reasonably
even fit over the opening.
7. Record the inspection results and the sub-contractors Work
Report No. for each fire door on the appropriate inspection
forms:
TMF-3012-OP-0280 Substation 1 and Mezzanine level fire doors
TMF-3012-OP-0281 Substation 2, Swan St Shaft and Refuge 3
fire doors
TMF-3012-OP-0282 Substation 3 & Burnley Fan Chamber fire
doors
TMF-3012-OP-0283 Substation 4 & Yarra Crossing fire doors
TMF-3012-OP-0284 Substation 5, ERW 01 & Olympic Park Pump
Station
TMF-3012-OP-0285 Burnley Tunnel Fire Doors
TMF-3012-OP-0286 Domain Tunnel Fire Doors
8. Record any abnormal conditions in the Work Done area of the
Job Sheet.  Raise a new job sheet for any corrective action
that is required.   P2 - Medium Priority.

(i) Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits
for cleanliness and the accumulation of calcites.
(ii) Record the build up of calcites in the pipes and pits
in Millimetres (mm).  When a build up of 50mm occurs
in a 200mm pipe or a 25mm in a 100mm pipe cleaning is
required.
(iii) Record a description of the calcite. e.g. slimy,
milky or hard etc.
(iv) Record the results on form  DOMAIN TUNNEL GROUNDWATER
PIT INSPECTIONS TMF-3012-OP-0231.
(b) Inspect the Dirtywater pits circled on DOMAIN TUNNEL
DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTION  TMF-3012-OP-0255.
Use a torch to inspect each pipe and associated pits for
cleanliness and the accumulation of debris.  Record the
related details regarding accumulation of silts, debris,
and other foreign materials within pits on the form.
(c) Ensure pit covers are replaced and seated correctly after
each pit inspection.
6. V-Notch Readings
(a) Prior to taking readings of ground water (Right hand side
of tunnel) pit numbers 325, 323, 321 & 316  and the dirty
water (Left hand side of tunnel) pit numbers 142, 139,
137 & 124, ensure the V-notch weir is clear of calcites
and debris.  Clean thoroughly if required.
(b) Use a measuring stick obtain the depth of the V-notch
flow by
(i) Place the stick in the cup
(ii) Remove the stick and measure the height of the water
mark on the stick.
(c) Record the depth of water flowing over the V-Notch weir
in mm on the form DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS,
GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING GROUNDWATER PIT
INFLOW  TMF-3012-OP-0204.
(d) If readings differ markedly from previous readings, then
take measurement again to confirm  results.
(e) Note that inspection V-Notch pits is to be carried out
as per step 5.
7. (a) Once V-Notch 323 has been read, then proceed to the sump
pumping room to take a water inflow reading.
(b) Proceed up the exit stairs to the pump control room
(c) Notify the control room that all pumps are to be switched
OFF.
(d) Switch OFF all the pumps (Have an electrician perform
this duty).
(e) Return back down to the sump pumping room and close all
three gate valves
(f) Return back up stairs to the pump control room and start
by recording the sump level, then 10 minutes later take
another reading of the sump level.
(g) Record the sump start and finish level, in millimetres,
on the form DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS,
GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING GROUNDWATER PIT
INFLOW  TMF-3012-OP-0204.
(h) Record on the inspection sheet anything out of the
ordinary.
(i) Return all  gate valves to their normal OPEN condition
and switch the pumps back to automatic operation.  Then
proceed with the rest of the readings and inspections.
8. Domain Tunnel Groundwater Bore Level (located between fire
cabinets D16 & D17 LHS).
(a) Remove the DT bore-hole cover, then lower a string with a
weight attached into the bore-hole until the weight
touches the bottom of the bore-hole.
(b) Mark the string with a marker or pen, ensuring that the
weight is just touching the bottom and that there is no
undue slack in the string.
(c) Measure and record the total length of the string (Total
depth of bore-hole in millimetres)
(d) Measure and record the total length of the string that
was submerged in the bore-hole water (Depth of
groundwater in bore-hole in millimetres).
(e) Record the details on the form DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE -
SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING
GROUNDWATER PIT INFLOW TMF-3012-OP-0204..
(f ) Ensure the cover is replaced and seated correctly.
9. Notify the control room on completion of the job.
10. Ensure a completed copy of the forms
DOMAIN TUNNEL GROUNDWATER PIT INSPECTION TMF-3012-OP-0231,
DOMAIN TUNNEL DIRTY WATER PIT INSPECTIONS  TMF-3012-OP-0255
and DOMAIN TUNNEL DRAINAGE - SEGMENT FLOWS, GROUNDWATER BORE
LEVELS & YARRA CROSSING GROUNDWATER PIT INFLOW
TMF-3012-OP-0204. are forwarded to the Civil Team Leader or
his representative on completion of the job and prior to end
of shift.  Civil Team Leader or representative is to record
and sign off each form and raise any actions (job sheets)
for further inspection or cleaning

03 M inspect of Liebert A/C units accessed via the tunnel
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing work.
2. Set up the traffic control measures as per Work Instruction,
Traffic Control, MI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure,
PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 20
3. Reference manual, Entire Mechanical Services, Operating and
Maintenance Manual for Mechanical Services at  Melbourne City
Link Tunnel Project.  M-STG-ME-27400.
4. Work plan for ACU Air Conditioning Units
4.1. With the unit running, Check for undue noise and any
vibration.   [_ _]
4.2. Check the temperature set points as follows
a. Check that the temperature shown on the microprocessor
LED display is consistent with the ambient temperature
measured with a portable thermometer.  Ambient
temperature should be within 2 degrees of the thermostat
setting.   [_ _]
b. Check that the system accepts changes in the setpoint by
the following steps
(i) Hold control SEL key down for 5 seconds (St1 will be
displayed)
(ii) Release key and current setpoint blinks
(iii) Use down key to adjust setpoint 5 deg lower and note
setting.
(iv) Press SEL key to confirm setting
(v) Press SEL key twice to exit setpoint mode.
(vi) Wait until unit cuts out, and verify that temperature
shown on unit  is consistent with new setpoint and
verify temperature is consistent with ambient
(+ or - 1 deg) using portable  thermometer.   [_ _]
c. Repeat the above steps to restore the setpoint to the
original setting.   [_ _]
d. Verify that unit cooling cycle cuts in when the new
setpoint is reached and verify that the temperature is
consistent with ambient using the portable
thermometer.   [_ _]
NOTE:  LED display blinks in reverse mode during heating
cycle.
4.3. Shut down unit and check that the air flow alarm operates
and that the control room receives the alarm..   [_ _]
4.4. Check filters and replace if necessary. - Filter type
Liebert size 650x590x75 mm
4.5. Remove and clean condensate tray and confirm the drain line
is clear.
4.6. Restart unit and set for remote operation.
5. Work plan for the ACC Condenser Unit
5.1. Inspect the condenser unit and check for undue cycling
operation.   [_ _]
5.2. Check for undue noise or any vibration while the fan is
running.   [_ _]
5.3. Switch the fan OFF using the local fan isolating
switch.   [_ _]
5.4. Inspect  for loose connections or leaking coils.   [_ _]
5.5. Remove debris and dirt build up from fan and coil area
5.6. Clean condenser coils, if required using compressed air.
5.7. Switch the fan ON at the local fan isolator.   [_ _]
5.8. Check for normal operation at the Air Conditioner
Unit.   [_ _]
6.0 Sweep and clean the Equipment room and associated adjacent
thoroughfares:
6.1 Sweep the floor and remove accumulated cob webs from the
walls.   [___]
6.2 Vacuum the control panel enclosures and any surfaces that
will collect dust deposits.   [___]
6.3 Vacuum interiors of any wall mounted control
enclosure.  [___]
6.4 Clean the front panels of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
6.5 Note and record any evidence of water or drainage problems.
Clear any blockages.
6.6 Remove from site all accumulated debris and
rubbish.   [_ _]
7.0. Carry out an inspection of the equipment room and record
the results on form Equipment Room Inspections
TMF-3012-OP-0347.  Ensure the form Equipment Room
Inspections TMF-3012-OP-0347 is returned to the Electrical
Electronics Supervisor or his representative.  Raise a new
jobsheet for any outstanding works.
8.0 On completion of job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done section of the job sheet and
report to the Supervisor or his representative and raise a
new job for any repairs.
9.0. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Inspect and maintain Batman Ave Escape Stair Fan
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job as well as prior
to entering the stairwell.
2. (a) Refer to Maintenance Manual, ""Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical
Services - MCL Tunnels"" M-STG-ME-27400.
(b) Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation
commissioning tests.
3. Check under the fan cowl and the exit grills for debris that could
restrict the airflow.  [_ _]
4. Ensure the door between Domain Tunnel and the stairwell is closed.
[_ _]
5. Request the TCO to start the fan ESF-P05 from the TCR.  Ensure the
fan starts.  Check
that the airflow direction is into the stairwell.  [_ _]
6. (a) NOTE: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire brigade.  It
will register on the local FIP
and the CCCS as a local alarm.
(b) Remove the access cover over the smoke detector, direct ""test
smoke"" from a smoke
generator, as specified on the container, onto the smoke
detector (on the inlet duct).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local fire indicator panel.
The smoke detector must
be in fault for approx 2½ mins for the fan to stop and for an
alarm to genrate on
the CCCS.  [_ _]
7. Check and inspect the Stairwell area.
(a) Check each door for damage, as well check the rollers, runners,
hinges, handles,
catches, and counter-weights for efficient operation.  [_ _]
(d) With the supply air fan (ESF-P05) operating, record the
differential air pressure within
the stairwell and at substation level.  Record readings less
than 50Pa in the ""Work Done'
area of the Job sheet. Notify the superintendent for further
investigation.  [_ _]
(e) At each of the doors, starting from the tunnel and working
towards the fan.
Arrange the door catch to be non-functioning, then using a
spring balance, measure the
force required to open the door.  Record the results in the
""Work Done"" area of the Job
sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required, as well
advisethe maintenance
superintendent for further investigation.   [_ _]
(f ) Check the time taken for the air pressure to return to the
static reading.  Record in the
""Work Done"" area of the job sheet if time is greater than 2
minutes. Notify the
superintendent for further investigation.
(g) Chock each door open, then using an anemometer, measure the
velocity of air out of the
open door.  The reading is to be with the door fully open and
with no obstructions.
Record the results in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job sheet
if the air flow is less than
1 metre /sec as well advise the maintenance superintendent for
further investigation.  [_ _]
(h) Check the fan and motor for undue noise and vibrations.   [_ _]
(i ) Check the fan bearings for noise.   [_ _]
(j ) Check the fan unit for damage, corrosion, missing panel
fixings, as well as checking
the fixings of the unit for security.  [_ _]
8. Ensure the action of opening a stairwell door;
(a) Generates an alarm at the TCR workstation.
(b) Causes the fan speed to vary to maintain a positive pressure inthe
stairwell.
(c) To replicate the action of the smoke detector, remove the
BATMAN AVENUE FAN alarm
relay (mounted in the rear compartment  of the FIP) for at
least two and a half minutes to
ensure the fan stops.  Replace the relay once the action is
confirmed  [_ _].  The fire
brigade will not be called)
9. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes, with the door in both the open
and the closed position
then advise the traffic control room to shut the fan down and to turnOFF
the lighting after
leaving the stairwell, ensuring that the door to the tunnel is
closed.
10. Ensure the stairwell is clean and all rubbish and debris is removed
from the stairwell.  [_ _]
11. Record anything outside normal parameters in the ""Work Done"" area
of the Job Sheet.
12. Ensure the door between the stairwell and the Domain Tunnel is
closed.
13. Notify the Control Room on completion of the job.
"

01 W Inspect & report of Egress tunnel features
Before you start the inspection, make sure that you are carrying the
camera, so that you can take any photographs of your observations.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the Traffic Control Room prior to commencing this work.
2. Have the Traffic Control Room turn all lights on.
3. Enter the Burnley Tunnel Emergency Egress Tunnel (EET) at the Burnley
Stairwell and
carry out the following inspections over the entire length of the
EET.
4. Visually inspect the EXIT signs for operation (12 off).  Record on
the form ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 any  EXIT
sign that is not functioning correctly.
5. Visually inspect the stairwell and EET lighting for operation.
Record  on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
all instances of three (3) successive light fittings not functional.
6. Visually inspect all signage for cleanliness, damage and or damage
tofixings. Record
on the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly
Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 any signage requiring further attention.
7. Visually inspect walls, floors and roofs for ground water leaks.
Record on the form
""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374
any leaks. Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage), LEAK TYPE
(Drip, Spray,
Running), POSITION (Roof, North wall, South wall, Floor).
8. Visually inspect floor for Trip Hazards e.g. raised grates,
accumulated debris, deposits of
leak sealant, water puddles etc.  Remove temporary hazards and
recordall occurrences
of hazards and their location on the form  ""Emergency  Egress Tunnel
Inspection Record  -
Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
9. Visually inspect
(a) and operate all emergency egress doors (e.g. Tunnel to EET - at
each cross passage
and
(b) doors within egress tunnel - for operation and or damage and
(c)  ensure all doors to equipment rooms are locked.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection""  TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the
door location and a description of the repairs required.
10. Visually inspect all drainage and pits for evidence of blockage and
water over the floor.
Record LOCATION (chainage, Cross passage) TYPE (Pit, Drain, Pipe)
POSITION (North side, South side, Centre).  Record on the form
""Emergency Egress
Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF- 3012-OP-0374
the location and
description of any blockage or flooding.
11. Visually inspect all EET and Stairwell fitments for damage,
corrosion, trip hazards,
obstructions (from walls or roofs) that are apparent.  Record on
the form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
and a description of the repairs and or obstruction.
12. Visually inspect for evidence of rodent infestation.  Record on the
form  ""Emergency
Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  - Weekly Inspection"" TMF-
3012-OP-0374 the location
of any sightings.
13. Remove all accumulated debris from the egress tunnel.
14. On completion have the Traffic Control Room switch all lights OFF.
15. Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any abnormal
parameters found.
Raise a new job sheet for any outstanding works.
16. Ensure the form  ""Emergency Egress Tunnel Inspection Record  -
Weekly  Inspection""
TMF- 3012-OP-0374 is returned to the CIVIL team leader or his
representative for
evaluation and recording of new leaks onto the Burnley Tunnel
Emergency Egress
Tunnel Leak Repair programme.  The Civil team leader is to ensure
any
outstanding works are scheduled.
17. Notify the Traffic Control Room on completion of the work."

03 M Maint of the Variable Message Sign
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in emergency lane.
2. Access keys required for Sound Wall Gate, to access VMS 07.
Set up lane closure as per Work Instruction, Traffic Control,
TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059
Plan 12 or 13 (Short term and low traffic volume).  Vic Roads
approval required prior to doing job.
Access to VMS 6 is from the car park below the elevated road.
3. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment and
or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.  Adhere to Safety
Instructions  TMI-3012-SA-0101, Working  on Gantry
Structures.
4. Arrange with the TCR for a Test Message to be displayed on
the VMS.  Monitor operation and repair as required.  Monitor
the LED Arrays and the Flashers for failed LEDS and
record in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet if the failed
LEDs exceed 10% of the array.
Arrange a new Job sheet for any outstanding works, recording
the appropriate Job numbers in the Related Jobs  field
and Notify the Team Leader or his representative
of any outstanding works.  [_ _]
5. Carry out visual inspection externally and internally of the
cabinets, sign, external cables and conduits for vandalism,
mechanical damage, water ingress, condensation or insect
infestation. Also check inside cabinets for tripped circuit
breakers, disconnected wires, burn marks from excessive heat.
[_ _]
6. Visually check for loose or missing nuts and bolts, and for
rusted areas, rusted nuts or bolts. Cleans with wire brush
and spray with Cold Gal or equivalent. This should be
done with care and to avoid overspray. [_ _]
7. Inspect the external face of the lenses (for each pixel) for
dirt and clean with Windex or equivalent  and clean rags
if required.[_ _]
8. Note any corrective action required in the Work Done area
of the Job Sheet and raise new Job Sheet if required.
9. Notify control room on departure.
"

03 M Maint of Gantry Tolling Equipment
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Carry out the three monthly planned maintenance defined in
the CML RSE Users Manual maintenance schedule, document no.
M-MCL-ET-1225.
2. Perimeter access gate at technical shelter key required.
3. Use caution when working above traffic, ensure equipment
and or tools do not fall from the gantry.  Only essential
equipment is to be taken onto the Gantry.  Adhere to safety
instructions TMI-3012-SA-0101 "Working on Gantry Structures
4. Notify Control Room prior to entering the Technical
Shelter.
5. Complete CML RSE Maintenance Plan PL-MCL-ET-100001.
Preventative Maintenance No.0301
When carrying out the cleaning of VDC sensors (in 0301),
inspect the area around the connectors for evidence of
corrosion.
If corrosion is evident, then clean the area as described
below.
Where cleaning is to be also carried out, use extreme care
to ensure any greases or sprays do not enter any
connectors.
The Fibre Optic Connector is to be only removed on the
12 Monthly  Cycle (Do not damage fibre optic cable).
Prior to removing any connector or cover socket, clean
surface corrosion and deposits from around connectors,
socket covers and the surrounding surfaces use a tooth
brush to assist if necessary.
Remove the three socket covers (remove only if possible
using fingers) and apply a light spray of silicon to
the three (3) socket covers, replacing and exercising
the threads.
With all caps and plugs re-installed apply a light spray of
silicon to the area around the plugs and caps.
Check for silicon overspray on the VDC sensor window and
clean if necessary.
Where connectors or socket covers cannot be easily removed,
record details in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet and
report the fact to the Team Leader or his representative.
0301: Check image quality and
,,,, alignment with CML Clean glass regardless of image.
,,,, Lubrication of mounting bracket carried out on removal
,,,, only.  Lightly spray with lubricant.
0302: Clean external glass of front and rear VR sensors.
Inspect mounting brackets and lubricate as required.
Ensure pins are cleaned and lubricated using silicon
spray prior to installing.
0303: Check VR Illuminator that there are less than 10%
defective IR LEDs,Advice CML if suspect below 10%
0304: Clean front surface of TRX, inspect mtg bracket and
lubricate as required
0305: Clean outside of glass cover of VDC, Replace failed
lamps, Lubricate arms as required.
Inspect VDC arm locating pins and chains. Record any
works required and report any equipment that needs
repair.
0306: Road Markers: Inspect for clarity & Cleanliness.( High ,,
,, contrast between marker & road). (If road markers need
to be changed, inform the Team Leader.)
0307: Clean the glass of VSS sensor
0308: Inspect Distribution Cabinet for loose or damaged   ,,
cables. Clean cabinet for insects or moisture.
6. Record in the "Work Done" area of the Job Sheet any
outstanding works requiring further attention.  Create a
new Job sheet for any outstanding works and notify the Team
Leader or his representative of the outstanding works.
Record the New job number in the "Work Done" area of this
job sheet and in the "Related Job" field of both jobs.
7. Notify Control Room prior to departing from the Technical
Shelter."

03 M Measure & report on DT GW TNL Bay flows in drainage sys
The frequency of this job can be adjusted as history of
groundwater flows are established.
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Set up the lane closure, as per Work Instruction, Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP-0002 and Translink Procedure PR-RS-IR-059
Plans 25 & 26.
3. For detail of Job, refer to Work Instruction, DOMAIN TUNNEL
DRAINAGE TMI-3012-OP-0025
4. At each groundwater pit:record the Volume/time water flow
from each agi-pipe into each groundwater  pit (and it's
direction of flow).
At each groundwater pit, to obtain readings;
(a) Readings are carried out by collecting the water, from
the agi-pipe, in a calibrated measuring container for 5
to 10 seconds.
e.g. 800 mls/10 secs
450 mls/10 secs
1 litre /8 secs.
Record the details on the Form DOMAIN TUNNEL - BAY FLOW
MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0205.
5. Inspect the pits and pipes using a torch and mirror and or by
observation, looking for Calcite deposits or debris that
could restrict water flow.  Record the details on the Form
DOMAIN TUNNEL - BAY FLOW MONITORING  TMF-3012-OP-0205.
6. Ensure the completed copy of the form DOMAIN TUNNEL - BAY
FLOW MONITORING TMF-3012-OP-0205 is forwarded to the Civil
Team Leader for evaluation on completion of the job.
Increased flows could indicate a new or increased source of
groundwater entering the tunnel, and would need to be
investigated.
6. Record anything outside normal parameters in the Work Done
area of the job sheet.
7. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

01 M Inspection & test running of the generator
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Perimeter access gate & Technical Shelter keys are required.
2. Notify the control room prior to entering the technical
shelter.
3. Check the operating condition of the Uninterruptible Power
Supply  to ensure it is operating in the normal
standby-back-up mode.  [_ _]
DO NOT CARRY OUT THE GENERATOR TEST IF THE UPS IS IN BYPASS
MODE.
4. General inspection. Reference: Cummins Onan Operator's Manual
960-01707B 10-98 [M-MCL-ME-20012]
(a) Check that the generator was left in  "" AUTO ""  [_ _]
(b) Check for any leaks of oils, fuels and water.  [_ _]
(c) Check oil level.  [_ _]
(d) Check battery electrolyte is above the plates.  [_ _]
(e) Check engine block heaters ( engine is warm ).  [_ _]
(f) Check battery voltage on Battery Charger Meter is
between 12.5 and 13.5 Volts  [_  _]
(g) Record the battery voltage in the Work Done area of the
job sheet.  [_ _]
(h) Check coolant level & fuel level in generator tank.
Physically open the cap,as gauge could be
misleading.  [_ _]
(j) Fill in the Generator Log Book, compare engine hours
with the last entry.  [_ _]
5. Simulated test operation. Reference: MGP Electrical Pty Ltd
Main Switchboard O&M Manual Section PI [M-MCL-ME-20016]
(a) Hearing and eye protection to be worn.
(b) Turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch on the generator DC
panel to RUN let the engine run for at least 5 minutes,
then turn the RUN / OFF / AUTO Switch back to AUTO
(c) Turn the Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard
from AUTOMATIC CONTROL to EMERGENCY SUPPLY & TEST run the
generator for 10 minutes.
(d) Check while running no alarms or leaks have appeared, and
that there are no unusual noises or vibrations. [_ _]
(e) Check voltage, load per phase, frequency, oil pressure,
water temperature. [_ _]
(f) Turn Mode Selector Switch on the Main Switchboard back to
AUTOMATIC CONTROL, the generator will continune to run
for about 8 minutes before stopping. [_ _]
6.  Record the hours run for the generator (from the hour run
meter) and update the Plant Usage in Mainpac from Plant
RHMouse click select Open then Meter Readings in edit mode
add Usage   [_________hrs].
7. (a) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
any unusual noises.  [_ _]
(b) Check the air conditioning unit and ventilation fans for
general operation, any oil deposits from refrigerant
leakages  [_ _]
(c) Report any abnormalities in the Work Done area of the
job sheet, inform the Team Leader and/or raise a
corrective job sheet.  [_ _]
8. Fill in the Generator Log Book  and record anything outside
normal parameters in the Work Done area of the job sheet.
Raise a new job for any works requiring further repairs.
Priority High P1.
9. Fill in the Technical Shelter Log Book.
10. Notify control room on departure from the Technical Shelter.

03 M Inspect and maintain Swan St Shaft Stairwell Fan
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the job.
2. Refer to Maintenance Manual, Operating and Maintenance manual
for Mechanical Services - MCL Tunnels M-STG-ME-27400.
3. Refer to AS 1668.1 - Appendix A for detail and methodology of
stair pressurisation commissioning tests.
4. The fans are accessed via a ladder to the roof of Sub-station
2.
5. (a) Check the inlet grill, on the roof, for damage and debris
that would restrict air flow.  [_ _]
(b) Check the roof mounted ducts for damage, corrosion and
fixings.  [_ _]
(c) Check the wall mounted air supply grill, in the shaft,
for damage, corrosion, damage and debris.  [_ _]
6. Work plan confirming the operation of the Swan St Shaft
stairwell pressurisation fan  (SF-SS2-7) (2A ESF P03).
(a) Ensure all doors are closed, e.g. Burnley Tunnel to
stairwell, Refuge Area and head of stairs.  [_ _]
(b) Request the traffic control room operator to start the
fan, ensure the air flow is into the egress stairs.  [_ _]
(c) Note: The alarm to be raised will not call the fire
brigade.  It will register on the local FIP and the CCCS
as an alarm.   Remove the cover over the smoke detector,
direct test smoke from a smoke generator, as specified on
the container, onto the smoke detector (on the ducting).
Check that an alarm actuates on the local fire panel.
(The fan will not stop due to a time delay)  [_ _]
(d) Request the traffic control room operator to start the
fan.  [_ _]
(e) Remove the relay mounted in the rear compartment of the
fire indicator panel.  The relay is labelled Swan Street
Escape Stair Relay.  Check that the fan stops after
approx. two and a half minutes.   [_ _]
(f) Replace the relay and request the traffic control room
operator to start the fan again and confirm fan
operation.   [_ _]
(g) Request the traffic control room opertor to turn the fan
OFF, and advise the traffic control room operator that you
will be controlling it locally.   [_ _]
(h) Switch the fan control switch AUTO OFF MANUAL to manual
and then start the fan locally.  The speed of the fan can
be controlled using the variable control on the cabinet
door.  Confirm operation.   [_ _]
(i) Switch the fan OFF and switch the fan control switch AUTO
OFF MANUAL to the AUTO position and request the traffic
control room operator to start the fan again.  [_ _]
7. Check the operation of controls and alarms.
(a) Open in turn, the Tunnel door, door to refuge 3, the
stairwell entry door at foot of stairwell and the exit
door at the head of the stiarwell.  Confirm an alarm at
the TCR workstation.   [_ _]
(b) Check the doors for damage, as well check the roller,
runners, handles, stops, counter-weight ropes, tube and
counter-weights for efficient operation.   [_ _]
(c) In turn, chock open the each door, then using an
anemometer, measure the velocity of air out of the open
door.  The reading is to be taken with the door fully
open and with no obstructions.
Record results in Work Done Area of the job sheet if less
than 1 metre per  second and advise the maintenance
superintendent for further investigation.  [_ _]
(d) Arrange the door catches to be non-functioning, then
using a spring balance measure the force required to open
the doors.  Record results in the Work Done area of the
job sheet if a force greater than 11kg is required.
Advise the superintendent for further
investigation.  [_ _]
(e) With all the doors to the egress stairs closed, check the
differential pressure on the Diff Press gauge.  Record
readings of less than 50Pa  in the Work Done area of the
jobsheet.  Advise the superintendent for further
investigation.  Record traffic control room reading
also.   [_ _]
(f) After closing the door, check the time taken for the
stair air pressure to return its static level.  Record in
the Work Done area of the job sheet if the time is
greater than 2 minutes.  Advise the superintendent for
further investigation.  [_ _]
8. Check the fire door and its operation.
(a) Remove all equipment installed to facilitate the above
test.  Ensure the door functions and closes correctly.
Confirm with the Traffic Control room that the door
status indication in the control room is
correct.   [_ _].
9. Run the fan for a further 5 minutes then request the traffic
control room operator to shut the fan down prior to leaving
the cross passage.
10. Check the condition of the flexible duct connections. [_ _]
11. Check the fan enclosure and mounts for security of
fastenings and tension. [_ _]
12. Check the fan impellor for build-up of dirt, clearances from
the housing and alignment.  [_ _]
13. On completion of the job, record anything outside normal
parameters in the Work Done area of the Job Sheet.  [_ _]
14. Notify the control room on completion of the job.

03 M Load test of the MGE UPS
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to commencing the work.
2. Check with the control room if any UPS alarms are relevant.
3. Refer to MGE UPS Systems Manual, Galaxy User Manual
E-679380XT/FA, M-STG-EL-24009, and Schnieder Electric Tunnel
Electrical Services Training Notes, M-STG-EL-24001,
Section 9.
WARNING
THE UPS BATTERY POTENTIAL IS APPROXIMATELY 380 VOLTS AND IS
EARTHED.  THE BATTERIES CAN DELIVER A FAULT CURRENT OF
APPROXIMATELY 9000 AMPS.  EXPOSED BATTERY TERMINALS ARE
DANGEROUS AND MUST NOT BE TOUCHED.  IN THE VICINITY OF THE
BATTERIES USE ONLY TOOLS WHICH ARE FULLY INSULATED.
SAFETY GLASSES MUST BE WORN WHEN CARRYING OUT  MEASUREMENTS
ON THE BATTERIES.
4. Check the UPS control panel readout for alarms and or normal
status.  If an alarm is found, record the alarm in the Work
Done Area of the Job Sheet. Do Not Continue with this Job if
an alarm is present.  [_ _]
5. Record measurements on form 03 M MGE Uninterruptible Power
Supply Battery Inspection and Test, TMF-3012-OP-0099.
6. Measure and record the UPS room temperature.   [_ _]
7. Check and record DC voltage and AC ripple voltage for each
bank of batteries.  If a discrepancy is found then record in
the Work Done Area of the Job Sheet.  Do Not Continue
this job sheet if there is a discrepancy in the readings
recorded and the readings expected.  [_ _]
8. To simulate a power failure, Open Mains 1 Isolator (Q1), the
UPS operation will change to the batteries.  [_ _]
9. Operate the UPS, in this mode, for at least 10
minutes.  [_ _]
10. Measure and record the DC voltage for each shelf of the
battery banks.
11. Measure and record the DC current flow in each battery bank.
12. Return the UPS to normal operation by closing Mains 1
Isolator Q1.  [_ _]
13. With an Optical thermometer measure the temperature of the
batteries and their inter-connections.  Temperature readings
should approximate ambient room temperature.  When a
connection is found to having a temperature greater than 5
degrees above room  temperature, in the Work Done Area of
the Job Sheet, record the battery location, terminal
identification, measured  temperature.  [_ _]
14. With an Optical thermometer measure the average temperature
of the two (AC & DC) capacitor banks and record the result.
15. With an anemometer measure and record the airflow from each
of the UPS cooling fans.
16. With the Optical thermometer measure and record the
temperature of each of the UPS cooling fans.  [_ _]
17. Ensure Normal operation of the UPS.  [_ _]
18. Sweep and clean the UPS room:
Sweep the floor and remove accumulated webs from the
walls.   [___]
Sweep the control panel room floors as well, vacuum the
control panel enclosures and any surfaces that will collect
dust deposits.   [___]
Clean the front panel of all accumulated dirt and
dust.   [___]
Remove from site all accumulated debris and rubbish.   [_ _]
19. On completion of job record anything outside normal
parameters
e.g. Damaged equipment enclosures
leaks
lighting faults
door damage
evidence of structural damage to the UPS room and
equipment etc,  in the "Work Done"section of the job
sheet and report to the Team Leader or his
representative and raise a new job for any repairs.
20. Leave a duplicate 03M MGE Uninterruptible Power Supply
Battery Inspection and  test form in the UPS room.  Compare
previously recorded data and record in the Work Done
Area of the Job Sheet any data that shows any degradation.
21. Notify the control room on completion of the job."

03 M Inspection of WIM & TCS Systems on the WL Tollway
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Notify the control room prior to stopping in the emergency lane.
2. Set up short term emergency lane closure incorporating, symbolic
worker, lateral shift,
vehicle arrow board and cones as per Work Instruction , Traffic
Control TMI-3012-OP 0002
and Translink Procedure, PR-RS-IR-059 Plan 12.
3. Reference: Central Weighing Australasia, Roadside Maintenance
Training Manual, Doc.
PL-MCL-TM-1631, Rev 0 and for operation of laptop computer,
Weigh-in-Motion & Counting
Stations, Operator's  Manual for WIMS Front End Computer, Doc.
PL-MCL-TM-1630,
Rev A,
Section 3 Telecom- DOS operator's Manual . (Status Information 6.1.2
page 145)
4. At WIM/TCS System 01A control cabinet, check the following;
(a) Internal and external condition of the cabinet.   [_ _]
(b) Check wiring for tightness and for any evidence of overheating.
[_ _]
(c) Check that the Tx and Rx LEDs (on the modem) flash at least each
minute.  [_ _]
(d) Check that the battery charger LED is ON.  [_ _]
(e) Using a vacuum cleaner, clean the cabinet interior.   [_ _]
5. Use laptop computer to carry out the following:
(a) Plug the 9 pin serial lead from the computer to the controller
input/output board.
(b) Switch ON the computer.
(c) Click on Telecom WIMS Icon
(d) Select Comms by pressing the 'C' Key
(e) Select LOGGER/ONLINE, then press Enter.
(f) Check that the laptop computer communicates with the logger
correctly.  [_ _]
(g) Confirm the logger parameters, shown in the ""CURRENT SITE
(MCL)"" on page no. 1,
area match those listed in the document  ""Site Configuration
and Set up Details"" (stored
in cabinet).  [_ _]
(h) Press key ""Page Down"" to go to screen page 2. [_ _]
(i) Record on the form attached loop frequencies and weigh responses.
[_ _]
(j)  Record value of ""Power Status"" on page 2 of the computer
screen.  The battery should
read approx 13 volts. [_ _]
(k)  When a truck crosses the sensors check on page 2 (computer
screen) that all sensors,
in each lane are operating correctly (an asterisk will appear
momentarily alongside the
appropriate loops as the truck crosses).  This check  should
only be done with trucks
and not cars (weighing sites only), as all sensors may not be
displayed for cars.  [_ _]
(l) Select LOGGER/OFFLINE, then press Enter
(m) Select 'Quit', then press Enter
(n) Then select 'Quit' again, press Enter again.
(o) Select 'Yes' to quit Telecom system.
6. Switch computer OFF and then unplug the 9 pin serial lead. [_ _]
7. From the side of the road, visually check the conditions of the road
sensors, for condition,
no (loose bolts) metal vibration or exposed wires visible. [_ _]
8. Repeat steps 4 through to 7 for WIM/TCS system 01B   [_ _].
9. Repeat steps 4 through to 7 for WIM/TCS system 02A   [_ _].
10. Repeat steps 4 through to 7 for WIM/TCS system 02B   [_ _].
11. Repeat steps 4 through to 7 for WIM/TCS system 03A   [_ _].
12. Repeat steps 4 through to 7 for WIM/TCS system 03B   [_ _].
13. On completion of job record anything outside normal parameters in

area of  the job sheet.

03 M WTP Backwash water testing

01 M Check of Swan St. Vent Station Axial Fans
**COMPLETE JOBSTART BEFORE COMMENCEMENT OF WORK**
1. Works to carried out between 21:00 & 05:00. Three days notice of
pending works is to be
given verbally to the TLO Maintenance Manager.
2. Obtain a Permit to Work for entry to substation 3, the ventilation
rooms and to interrupt
operations. TLO Maintenance Manager to sign Work Permit and the works
are to be carried
out only within times specified on the Work permit..
3. Inform the control room prior to commencing the work and brief
TCRO'son interruptions
and expected alarms.  Maintain radio contact at all times.
4. Reference manual:  ABB Installation, Operating & Maintenance
Instructions Manual
(M-STG-VE-26060).
5. At the PMCS in the control room.
(a) Check the motor balance vibration readings on the PMCS for all
fans.  If any reading is in
excess of 6.5mm/s, record the result in the ""Work Done"" area
of the job sheet for further
action.   [_ _]
(b) Check the trend log for the last month, looking for abnormal
events.  Record any
abnormalities in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job sheet.
report any events and or trends
to the Maintenance Superintendant that may suggest some
abnormal function.  [_ _]
(c) Check the running current and record in the ""Work Done"" area
if greater than FLC 403A.
(d) Check the drive and non drive end bearing temperatures for the
operating fan motor.
Record the details for those bearings with a temperature
greater then 80°C in the ""Work
Done"" area of the job sheet  for further action.  [_ _]
(e) Check the CO levels in the tunnel and the Swan St Vent Stack on
the PMCS screen in
control room and ensure less than 30 ppm prior to commencing
work.  [_ _]
6. Access to the Swan St. ventilation station is through double locked
doors at rear
of  Substation 2 and then by a ladder down the shaft.
(a) The fan inlet is on Level 4,
(b) The fan motor is accessed from level 5,
(c) The fan damper is accessed from level 6.
(d) Substation 2 can be accessed from ground level at Swan St.
WARNING:
DO NOT CARRY OUT THESE CHECK WHENEVER MORE THAN 2 FANS ARE
OPERATIONAL
DO NOT ENTER THE ACCESS AIRLOCK TO THE VENTILATION FAN ROOM ALONE.
TWO
OR MORE PEOPLE MUST BE PRESENT WHENEVER WORK IS BEING CARRIED OUT IN
THIS AREA.
OBSERVE ALL NOTICES ON THE AIRLOCK DOORS.
DO NOT ENTER A SMOKE DUCT UNLESS A PERMIT HAS BEEN OBTAINED FOR
WORKIN
THIS AREA.  TO CROSS A SMOKE DUCT A SERVICE LADDER MUST BE USED AT
ALL
TIMES.
7. In substation 2;
(a) Switch the Main Isolator for SFE 01 OFF.  (NOTE:- The order of
fan selection is dependant
on fan requirements.  A minimum of one fan must be running at
any time).  Open the
starter cubicle & inspect the cubicle & wiring connections.
Upon completion close the
door, and return the Main Isolator to the ON position.  [_ _]
(b) Switch the Main Isolators for all the other non operational axial
fans, one at a time SFE 02
and 03 to the OFF position, then inspect the starter cubicles.
Once the inspections
are complete, ensure the cabinet doors are closed and the
isolators are returned to the
ON positions.  [_ _]
8.1 Fan Room Access
(a)  Enter the fan room from the entry stairway after equalizing
differential pressure in
the airlock.
WARNING:
HEARING AND EYE PROTECTION MUST BE WORN WHEN YOU ARE IN THE FAN
CHAMBER.
DO NOT PLACE ANY PART OF THE BODY OR MATERIALS WITHIN 1 METRE OF AN
OPERATING
FAN INLET GUARD, AS THE AIR IS FLOWING AT APPROX 35kmh.
8.2 Static Checks
(a) Press the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton adjacent to the motor.
(b) Check the condition of anti-vibration mountings and ensure that
the rubber bushing
is moved freely, adjust if required.  [_ _]
(c) Examine the grease that has been discharged from the motor
bearings for any noticeable
colour changes.  [_ _]
(d) Open the local electrical junction box, inspect the electrical
wiring and connections,
inspect all glands for tightness.  [_ _]
(e) Visually inspect the motor for evidence of condensation,
whitepowder or similar.
Record in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job Sheet any
evidence of condensation,
powder and the like and notify the Team Leader or his
representative.  [_ _]
(f) Carry out an insulation/resistance test of the motor and
heater windings.
(i) Ensure fan motor is isolated.
(ii) At a suitable location, for each fan motor
Note: The motor winding heater for axial fans has been
isolated and is to remain
isolated.
(a) Disconnect neutral from the motor winding heater
(where connected) and
bridge heater terminals.
(b) Apply a reliable bridge to the three motor winding
terminals.
(iii) Carry out an Insulation resistance test between the
motorwindings and the
winding heater bridge.  Record the result in the ""Work
Done"" area.
(iv) Bridge the motor windings and the winding heater
connections and carry out
an Insulation resistance test between this common bridge
and earth.  Record
the result in the ""Work Done"" area.
(v) Remove all temporary connections.
(vi) If the heater was connected on arrival, then re-instate
theheater connections,
otherwise leave the motor winding heater terminations
isolated.
(vii) Ensure fan motor is serviceable on completion.
(viii) Where any insulation resistance reading is less than 2
megohm, then Record
in the ""Work Done""area of the Job Sheet and raise a
new job for the outstanding
works.  Include the Job Number of the new job in the
""Related Job"" field as well
as in the alternate.  Notify the Team Leader or his
representative of any
outstanding works.
8.3  Running Checks.
(a) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton and contact the TCR to startthe
fan.  [_ _]
(b) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan starts.
(c) Check the fan for any abnormal noise or vibrations.     [_ _]
(d) Check the flexible connections for wear and leakage of air.  [_ _]
(e) Check anti-vibration mountings for operation and structural
soundness [_ _]
(f ) Check the operation of the local vibration monitor.   [_ _]
(g) Record any abnormalities in the ""Work Done"" area of the Job
Sheet for further action.  [_ _]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the Local EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
(i) Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
8.4 Running Fan Check and Lubrication
CAUTION:  ALLOW THE MOTOR TO COOL FOR ONE HOUR IF A START IS
REQUIRED
AFTER FOUR STARTS IN ONE HOUR.
(a) On completion of  the Static Fan Checks, return to
substation2, then remove the
safety tags, in accordance with TMI-3012-SA-0103, then remove
the fan motor isolation
at  the MCC.
Note:  Ensure that only one non-operational fan is isolated at
any one time.
(b) Switch the AUTO/OFF/MAN selector switch from the OFF
positionto the MANUAL and
the  REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL selector switch from the REMOTE position
to the LOCAL
position.
(c) Return to the ventilation room; there start the fan, that is
being maintained,  by                           releasing th e local
STOP pushbutton at the fan and then pressing START
pushbutton.
(d) Check that the outlet damper opens immediately the fan
starts.
(e) Add Shell Stamina RL2 grease or equivalent, to the bearings,
only while the fan is
running.  Ten pumps per bearing.
(f ) Remove the old grease, that was discharged from the
bearings, using the retrieval
system.  Examine the grease for changes of colour.   [_ _]
(g) Check the fan for any abnormal noises or vibrations.     [_
_]
(h) Shutdown the fan motor using the local EMERGENCY STOP
pushbutton.
(i)  Release the EMERGENCY STOP pushbutton.
9. Repeat step 8 for fan SFE 02.  [_ _]
10. Repeat step 8 for fan SFE 03.  [_ _]
11. (a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are disengaged.  [_ _]
(b) Collect all tools and materials, leave the fan room, again
equalise the corridor and the
fan room pressures.
12. (a) Check the lighting within the fan chamber for operation.  [_ _]
(b) Repair any light found to be not operating or raise a new
jobsheet for the repair of
the fan chamber lighting.
13. Record anything outside normal parameters in the 'Work Done'
sectionof the Job Sheet.
14. Notify the control room on completion of work.
15. Return to the control room and ensure all fans are operational.
EMERGENCY OPERATION
In the event of notification by TCR Operators that a tunnel incident hasoccurred
requiring the
use of fans for smoke extraction.
Note:  Depending on the position of an event, Substation 1 may be
inaccessible.
1. If Substation 2 is not accessible
(a). If a fan that is being checked is running,  advise the traffic
control room that the fan  is
running under LOCAL control. Unless advice is received, from
the control room,  that fan
should remain under LOCAL control.
(b). Vacate the ventilation fan chamber, ensuring the sliding door tothe
airlock is closed and
sealed.
(c). Advise the traffic control room when all personnel are in or
have left the air lock.
2. Substation 2 is accessible
(a) Ensure all EMERGENCY STOP pushbuttons are disengaged
(b) Return to substation 2 and switch all the fan REMOTE/OFF/LOCAL
selector switches to
the  REMOTE position and switch all the fan  AUTO/OFF/MAN
selector switches to the
AUTO   position.
(c) Notify the traffic control room operators that they have control
of the fans.
